text: Had this on tap as part of a flight at first draft. Black with sticky brown head. Very boozy. Cocoa and vanilla notes. Big

Bells Hell Hath No Fury enters some strange territory but it does so with a sense of cohesion. There are a few breweries that have tried pairing darkness with Belgian flavors (Ommegang and Stillwater are the more successful ones that come to mind) but its rarely been so well as with Hell Hath No Fury. Theres notes of coffee roast, char, earth, cocoa, cherry, candy, fruit cake, and Belgian spices. Full-bodied but not heavy feel. Not your typical Abbey Dubbel but a rather tasty one.

Draft.

A- Roasty, cocoa, subtle dark fruit.

A- Black color, black liquid, tan head.

T- Roasty, cocoa.

P- Full body, average texture, average carbonation, roasty finish.

O- Thought this was a stout when I ordered it. Even tasted like it for the most part. Honestly, pretty unmemorable.

12 ounce bottle from House of Bottles in Marengo, IL, served a bit below cellar temp in a Chouffe tulip. Pours a very dark molasses color, nearly opaque, with a massive light crème brulee head that takes minutes to dissipate, leaving mostly clean glass as it decays...light yeasty nose with touches of toffee, faint grapiness...sweet body offers candy or brown sugar and a growing roasty character, with again fairly light yeast throughout, turning to somewhat bitter, a touch drier (thought still somewhat sweet) and burnt at the finish...milky texture to the mouthfeel, strong-ish, lively carbonation. As the description says, its more like a stout than a dubbel I think. Pretty decent overall.

Inky, with khaki head. Nice semi-sweet raisiny, leathery, peaty aroma. Dark fruit, raisins, dates, a bit dusty, mildly acidic but buffered, some smoky notes, maybe some cocoa. Creamy mouthfeel. A little creosote at the end. Quaffable and quite good. On tap, Gaines Street Pies.

Lovely black pour w/ reddish hues that has a retaining tan head & good lacing. The aroma rich, roasty, & bold. The flavor is a cross of a stout & black ipa. Its roasty, hoppy, & rather complex. The body is chewy yet still quite drinkable at 7.5%. Tasty & overall a very good beer!
Bottle. Pours a dark brown. Aroma and taste are malts, some spices, and some roast.

Bottle from andersons. Nose is malty and rich. Smooth body for an ale and more like a porter. Well balanced. Starts with smoky cocoa and malt fullness and morphs to bit of nuts and dark sugars and cherry. Pretty good.

Bottle from Market Street Wine Shop, Uptown. Pours deep reddish brown with a small tan head. Smells of black cherry, bubblegum, metal. Taste is light metal, light glue, but nice dark cherry and other dark fruits, clove, earth, wood. Nice.

Pours dark brown with a mocha colored head. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee, dark fruit, and a light clove yeastiness. Flavor is roasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee, dark dried fruit. Finishes with dried plums and Belgian yeast. Really nice!

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2016 12oz bottle, poured into a Belgian tulip. The aroma is initially a roasty and chocolate blend with undertones of nuts. coffee comes through eventually, then turns to a fruity, fig and dates tone with a woody spice. It pours a rich, deep mahogany with soft, brown foam that has a great amount of retention and leaves a dense lace. The taste is a medium high sweet and medium low bitter blend. It?s smooth, with foamy, soft carbonation. The texture is like that of a light weight syrup with a medium body. Flavors of chocolate, caramel, and cream soda are noted first with a mild woody spice, nuts, and a bit of mocha. It finishes smooth with cacao, then vanilla, root beer, raisin, spices, a light leather, and some coffee notes tha arise late with a sweet, sugary grape jelly. The aftertaste is smokey and sticky with chocolate and a late molasses and sarsaparilla.

Tap at Ginger Man, New York. Originally rated 20160212. Colour is dark brown with brownish white head. Aromas and flavours: Grain, some sweetnss, ripe fruits, Belgian yeast and malts. Pretty good for American dubbel.
Stout black pour with brown head. Aroma: slightly roasty with Belgian yeast hints. Flavor: nice combo of sweet stout roast with Belgian dubbel malty slightly boozy character. Herbal yeast notes.
Sample at Bells on 1/28/16. Darkest brown pour with a thick tan head. Aroma of malt, banana, clove and roast. Malty flavor with banana, clove and chocolate accents before a roasted malt finish.

Tap - fair size tan foamy head, very dark Amber/almost black color, big malty aroma and flavor, slightly roasty, slightly fruity, fair yeasty spice, creamy finish, really good overall

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2015 On tap at Busters. Definitely one of the best beer bars in the Twin Cities. Consumed in a 12 oz pour with samadouche. Cola brown nearing the black threshold. Minimal tan head. Roasty, nutty aroma with some chocolate undertones. Taste comes forward as more of a stout than a dubbel. The roasted coffee and chocolate plays a big role almost overshadowing the Belgian qualities I crave. Some cherry found in the sip. Alcohol presence felt...almost a bourbon warmth. Its a very good beer but seemingly mislabeled as an abbey dubbel...should be an abbey dubbel stout.

Dark brown color with a full beige head. Earthy sweet malt and mild fruit aromas. Flavors of dark currants, raisin, mild pepper and hints of spice. Very much a dubbel. Some yeasty undertones and very mild esters make this one true to form

Bottle. Pours black with nice tan head. Nose is coffee, chocolate and dark fruit. Taste is creamy raisins and chocolate.

Bottle (Aug 28, 2015 bottling). Head is initially small, frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing. Body is dark brown to black. Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (chocolate, caramel, roasted grain), with notes of vanilla, marshmallow, gum, alcohol. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, lightly to moderately alcoholic.
Pleasant but somewhat sugary smelling. Pretty sweet in the mouth, as portended, and some not-so-enjoyable acidity as well. Overall ok but not that interesting.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a deep ruby red, almost black. Very thin tan head that disappears very quickly. Complex aroma of roasted malt, alcohol, chocolate & dried fruit. Full bodied, taste is a combination of coffee and chocolate with a slightly sweet finish. Very good!

Bottle. Pours deep brown to black. Minimal tan head. Aroma of roasted malt with some Belgian yeast. Opens with hint of alcohol that quickly develops into toasted malt flavors, some biscuit. Somewhat earthy and sweet. Rich, velvety mouthfeel. Slightly warming finish. Pleasant and complex flavors, very enjoyable.
Bottle. Pours a deep brown color with khaki head. Roasty, toffee, cocoa aromas. Roasty, cocoa, sweet, caramel flavors. Not really a dubbel of any sort. Not too bad overall.

12 ounce bottle. Pours a translucent dark brown color. Small tan head. Faint roasted malt nose. Sweet roasted malt flavor has dark cherry and cocoa notes. Very Porter like. Finishes sweet with dried fruits and sweet cocoa.

Malty yeasty fruity come through after the coffee and molasses. Pleasantly thin for such a sweet beer. A light Porter, actually very good but saying this "started as a dubbel" is like saying an IPA started as a wheat.

12oz bottle from the Malt Shoppe in Tosa. Cola colored pour with maybe a touch of red leaving light lacing from the off-white head. Aroma has quite a mix - molasses, chocolate and sweet caramel plus a solid spicy yeast base. Taste is of sweet caramel, chocolate, tangy spices. Very much a belgian stout instead of a dubbel. Medium bodied with a touch of alcohol. Finishes sweetly tangy. A solid, quite different, effort. 14.5

Dark brown color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, yeast, caramel, dark fruit, & some spice; Flavor of sweet malt, yeast, caramel, molasses, dark fruit, and chocolate; Soft carbonation; More stout like - but pretty decent.

Theres no recognized style of Belgian Stout, though if there was I suppose Bells Hell Hath No Fury Ale might be a good example of one. It appears to be a rather typical strong stout thats fermented with traditional Abbey yeast. The net result is a beer thats at worst good, and at best interesting. 

I poured a 12oz bottle into a tulip glass. It was bottled on 8/28/15 and cost $4.35 ($0.36 per ounce).

Appearance: Dark black body all around. Initially pours to a large, brown, foamy head, but it evaporates quickly and leaves no lacing on the glass.

Smell: Familiar stout scent with notes of roasted malt, but a noticeable fruity presence as well from the yeast esters.

Taste: Since this beer is rather experimental in style, its a little difficult to wrap my head around it. On one hand it tastes like a classic American stout: plenty of sweet dark maltiness along with some roasted notes. On the other hand, its a bit more continental with the presence of rum-soaked raisins, plum, and treacle. I even detect a smokey astringency on the finish. Theres a bit of alcohol in here as well, though its not entirely distracting. I enjoy the sweet and stout-like characteristics here, but that finish is rather odd. All in all, its a fine beer but nothing amazing.

Drinkability: The palette to Bells Hell Hath No Fury Ale is an odd duck to be sure, though the palate itself is not. The mouthfeel is fairly thick, but in no way viscous or sticky. Not quite velvety smooth like a pub stout on nitro; though it is still smooth going down. I do notice the 7.5% ABV in the form of flavor and warmth. It finishes surprisingly clean. Id enjoy this as a dessert.

RATING: 7/10

pours very dark with a dark cocoa head. Aroma is malt, raisins, plums, coffee and spice. dark fruit flavors with spice and a little roasted coffee. medium body. slick texture with a slight bitter finish. Not bad but overpriced for the quality
Pours dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is dark fruit, chocolate and slightly nutty. Taste follows suit with some caramel, honey and roast charred malt. Very nice Ameri-Belgian.
Smells and tastes like malt and raisins. Medium body, light carbonation, and no foam.

Bottle. Pours dark brown almost black, medium tan head. Nose is chocolate and coffee but the tart smelling Belgian yeast comes through as well. Taste is medium-high sweetness. Medium body, texture is more on the thin side, yeasty tart finish as well as the malt sweetness. A little metallic aftertaste. Good overall.
Draft at Pour it Black. Pours nearly black with a beige head. Aroma is dark chocolate, charred oak. Flavor is dark chocolate, coffee, a hint of clove.

Tasted from bottle. Pours a very dark brown with thick khacki head. Aroma is dark fruits of plum and raisins and herbal. Taste is moderate sweet with minimal bitterness. Syrupy and clingy mouthfeel. Flavors of plum, raisins, caramel, toffee, biscuits, earthy. Very good dubbel.

bottle & tap at cafe. had previous yet forget to rate. killer Belgian with everything i like in the style. awesome beer

Aromas of dark fruit, some malt, some roasty notes, spices, a bit of caramel. Tastes of dark fruit, light roast, caramel, spices, some chocolate as it warms. Pretty spot on with the deScription, dubbel-y with a hint of stout-like characteristics.
On nitro tap, into cold pint glass. Didnt know what this was; seemed like a mix between a stout and a black ipa (though without much hop bite). Really tasty, though I didnt keep real notes.
Sweet malt body of caramel, black plum and fig. Dark and rich, finishing with hints of chocolate, roasted coffee and brown sugar. Medium length.
30 sept 2015, tap. Black. Nose is dark roasted malt. Ned body and mildly fizzy. Leather, tobacco, burnt malt, bitter burnt molasses finish. Nice.

Appearance: Black pour with a foamy light mocha head that fades into a healthy ring. Flavor: Molasses sugars up front developing a little more roast character; fruits are dialed back, but come in a little towards the finish, which dries out well without any bitterness. Palate: Full body, creamy texture, soft carbonation, abrupt finish. Overall: Not too wild about this, but its not bad, either. Fine as a winter warmer.

Bottled August 28, 2015 and enjoyed September 27, 2015 in a Med Elf tulip/snifter. 

"A brew that gives you either sympathy for the devil or the courage to face him. Goes especially well with your favorite lost my girl/truck/dog/trailer song."

Smell - Sweet coffee. Chocolate. Raisins. Bread. Malt. Dark fruit. 

Taste - Fig. Honey. Bread. Nut. Char.

Feel - Heavy carbonation. Doesnt sit well in the stomach. Syrupy.

Overall - Looking at reviews it looks like we are drinking many different versions of this. I like Belgian darks. This is okay. No head but a lot of fiz.

There is a nice roast and a little coffee. The Belgian dubbel aspects of this are just huge. I'm not a fan at all. Here we go. The flavor is heavy on roast and dark chocolate. There is a definite clove and Belgian yeast. It does fall off pretty quickly. The mouth feel is thin and light with a soft carbonation that you would expect to be much thicker. The aftertaste is lingeringly roasty clove and I'm not a fan.

Taste is light roasted malt, nutty, then clove and spice. Mouthfeel is thin, good carbonation but just thin. Overall, Im not a fan of this style so it didnt stand much of a chance.
Anise, sweet orange, spice, cocoa, dark bread, turron, pecan, light roasty.
Very nice. Near black pour with thin tan head. Aroma is sweet molasses and caramel. Taste adds mellow coffee. Creamy mouth full.

Smells like sweaty feet. Taste is better than the smell, coffee mostly, with some Belgian spice flavor. This one just doesnt work for me. The flavors clash. Its clearly well put together and technically good, I just dont like the Dubbel/stout hybrid.

Very malty and lightly sweet underneath everything else that is going on in this beer. Extremely complex. Spices seem to grow as the beer warms. A nice sipper.

Aroma of dark roasted malt, taste is malty, dark chocolate, espresso, very balanced, great beer. Appearance is dark as hell. No pun intended.

Draft at Hopcat GR - pours an oily dark brown - sweet dried fruit aroma . Figs and dried dark fruit flavors . Very good .

Alcohol presence is pretty mild, likely attributed to the 2+ years of cellar time. Ive yet to have an American dubbel or strong dark ale that stands up to the Belgian greats. Taste is a thin, flat, sweet, malt sugary mess. a light bit of chocolate, with some alcohol warming in the finish. overall, not bad for 6 years old, but I wont finish the glass either.

Smells of roasted malt candied sugar and some fruity essence.
Tastes sweet with candied sugar and alcohol, roasted malts and some light fruit, similar to its aroma.

Tap at Happy Gnome. Black with a medium khaki head. Light coffee, belgian yeast, bourbon, vanilla and figs. Burnt sugar sweetness with a bourbon dryness. Heavier with a sticky feel.

Bottle from Kalamazoo dated 10/03/12 poured on 4/20/14. Pours an opaque brown to black with a thin creamy tan head that lingered and left nice lacing. Aroma is chocolate and slight dark fruit. Slight tobacco. Flavor is roasty with some sweetness and dark fruits. No Belgian yeast at all. Extremely smooth creamy body. Not at all a dubbel but a great beer nonetheless. Fantastic.
bottle. deep brown with small head. very malty base, with dark fruit, chocolate, and lots of flavor. very well done.

Let me just say first and foremost that I fucking hate abbey dubbels and I damn to hell whomever sent me this garbage sauce. Thanks. Pours a deep brown/almost black with no head. I should mention that this was bottled on 10/18/11A, and consumed today, 03/14/14. So, really not that fresh. Aromas of tobacco (red man plug) and some cigarette butts. Not a bad start. I may even like this beer. First sip reveals a pretty dry and refined brew. Whatever this abbey dubbel was,it has matured into a fine beer with all the qualities of a world class Baltic porter. This is totally unexpected. I get ash, cigarette butts, straight cut skoal spit, dark fruit. Nice! Pretty dry and roasty. No bitterness. Some vegetal character,but thats whats to be expected. This is pretty fucken good. Tastes pretty much like Boss Porter. Fantastic. Finishes with a dry, lingering ratman197 finish. Awesome. I love this beer.

Bottle. Pours black with a short tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate and dark fruit. Creamy smooth flavor of chocolate, dark fruit, coffee, belgian yeast, raisins and light caramel. Medium bodied, minimal carbonation. a solid dubbel

"A brownish-black colored beer with a big foamy textured, light brown head. good hang time on this one. a thin ringlet is whats left behind. Fruity, dark roastiness in the nose. Some grassy notes to the profile in the tasting of a light bodied beer. Overall good."
Wow strong aroma of dark fruits and yeast... great flavor really holds on..really good!
Poured a deep brown with an instantly disappearing tan head. Aroma of sweet dark fruit, alcohol soaked spice. Medium body, flavour is sweet caramel, vanilla, latte with a sweet end.

Bottle. Very dark pour, thin mocha head. Aroma is deep roasted malt, coffee, some light citrus notes. Taste is rich malt, smokey coffee, lemon and light citrus, deep yeasty bread. Caramel and molasses come through.
December 2011. Bottle. Pours dark brown with a tan head. Aromas of dark fruit, sugars, spice and malt. Yeasty flavors with fruit and coffee.

bottle, chocolatety brown pour, nutty flavor, hazelnut, chocolate, light coffee, cloves, dark fruits. a lot going on here. roast, german cake/ brown bread, belgian fruity yeast, interesting take on the dubbel-hybrid. didnt care for at first, 3.3 but raising rating as i move through.
Pours dark black with very minimal tan head. Smella of malt with strong coffee. Tastes of vanilla, coffee and dark fruits. Good not great

Trade with Silphium.  If anyone from Bells reads these reviews, please consider CO distribution, you have a lot of fans here!  Was not expecting a  deep black pour with a quickly dissipating tan head.  Yeasty and tropical fruit nose with alcohol obvious.  Roast malt and chicory dominate the taste, with the warm fruit lingering.  Nice!
Aged beer for 7 months and it rounded out nicely, removing the sharp notes I previously experienced
Very nice beer. Dark appearance with roasted nuttiness, some dark fruit, chocolate, and earthy aftertaste.

Smell of dark roasted malt, fruit, spiciness. Great roasted malt character, with fruits and nice lingering spiciness. Light carbonation, smooth. Great complexity that is phenomenal. This is excellent.

Bottle. Deep mahogany with a thin, tan head that dissipates almost immediately. Caramel, toffee, malt and a hint if grain on the aromas. Similar flavors with added tartness and maybe smoked meat (that's throwing me a bit). Silky body.

Slight roasted coffee, nuts, banana, clove, and musty earthiness in the aroma after a pour.  It does not retain its head very long, and seems a bit thin for the style. Thank you Bells

Pours black. Nose is light coffee and taste is sweet malt at first and is overtaken by roasted coffee an tart cherry. Awesome beer, Bells does it again!

Very nice, sweet coffee cake aroma.  Hell hath no fury like a woman scorned, the saying goes.  Scorned in favor of beer?  Is this a tribute to the rage of scorned women?  Jet black pour.  A pleasantly sweet brew, similar to some porters, with coffee and herb flavors.  Another fine brew from Bells.
Dark brown with a thick brown head. Aroma is roast malt. Flavor of smugly bittersweet caramel with slight notes of toffee. Finishes clean with a sweet but not cloying aftertaste.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of Queenholly. Nice eye appeal in a Trappist glass, I also really like the label on the bottle. Thin lasting tan head in the glass. No is stout like. Rich, deep roasted malts with just a bit of candy sugar. Tastes of figs, fruity Belgian yeast, and chocolate malt. Palate is soft, fuller in body with a creamy texture. Nice.

Appearance: I poured as aggressively as I could, but it made no difference. Poured like a cola, and the head fizzled away with the sound of one. The color of the beer is just a pitch black, laceless, headless disappointment. Hell Hath No Fury is unfiltered, and some sediment can be seen, which helps a little bit.

Smell: HHNF smells strange, but it smells really good. Such an interesting aroma... I get a clove smell mostly, and some malts. A very sweet smell.

Taste/feel: Has a taste of coriander and clove... it really just tastes a lot like a witbier or dunkelweizen to me, just with a dark malt aftertaste. Keep in mind, Im not at all familiar with the style "Belgian Strong Dark", so this could very well be typical. Thats just what I get. It doesnt taste like I thought this would at all -- its very sweet, with a verrry slight bitterness and sourness on the finish (the latter no doubt due to the Belgian yeast). It doesnt have a super interesting depth of flavor, but its still tasty. However, a single bottle is more than enough for me during a session. The sweetness and overall feeling of this one is too thick and heavy for me to have too much of. By the bottom of the glass, it almost feels syrupy.

A very interesting beer, and Im not entirely sure what to make of it. Its pretty tasty, but not at all like I thought it would.

Pretty nice dubbel. Pours black with mocha head. Aroma of floral hops and dark chocolate. Taste has bitterness and a little sweetness. Kind of like a hybrid between funnel and doppelbock. Interesting animal, if not necessarily a funnel. Bottle.

As I get further into it, its very hard to get it down.  Honestly, this ended up a drainpour (but admittedly, I already downed a DIPA bomber and a 12 oz impy).

Mouthfeel is smooth and silky with minimal carbonation.  Body is medium to full.  A very good, if unclassifiable dark beer from a favorite brewery.

Medium body and medium carbonation.

(bottle - STLCOB tasting) black with tan head. Slightly sweet fruity roast malt aroma. Flavor is slightly sweet malt, some dark fruits.
12 oz bottle. Pours dark black with very minimal tan head. Malty aroma with strong coffee. Vanilla coffee and dark fruits taste.

Reminiscent of Grimbergen Dubbel but with stout-like qualities of bitter coffee.

The taste is much the same. Chocolate and plenty of chewy caramel. Sweet cinnamon and general belgian yeast notes. Roasted malts. Light licorice and toasted tobacco on the finish. Thanks to wimperoo for this.  Pours a dark brown with a small frothy brown top.  Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate and spice.  Taste is a good mouthfeel with roasted malts and dark chocolate and mild bitterness.
Pours dark brown with little head. Chocolate, oatmeal, plum, molasses, and a clean dry hoppy finish. I like this a lot. I also LOVE the label!!!!

Pours thick, black, with a small head that quickly dissipates. 
Aroma. Cocoa, fruit, molasses
Taste: same as smell. Thick syrupy finish with very little bitter finish...slightly boozy  
Palate: smooth, syrupy, Can definitely feel the buzz/tingle of the alcohol down the throat. 
Overall: Great winter warmer and nice addition to Bells lineup. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
dark black with no head. Chocolate aroma with some oat as well. Very smooth tasting, lost of malt and chocolate. Oats on the finish
12oz bottle, pours opaque brown, no measurable head, aroma of spices, malts, and yeast.  Roasty, slightly fruity taste, mostly from the yeast.  A little boozy, but really a fantastic beer.
12 ounce bottle that pours a dark brown, almost black, with aromas of chocolate, coffee, raisins, clove, and some figs.  Flavors are the same, decent beer over all, with a boozy aftertaste.

Bottle from total wine sterling. Pours the color of coca cola with a thin khaki head. Not much on the nose but alcohol and a touch of brown sugar. The taste had notes of raisin. Finishes clean. Not my fave from Bells.
Pours a black color with a small light brown head. Aroma of roasted malts and light spice. Flavor of cloves, roasted malts, and light fruity sweetness.

Bottle. A typical aroma, similar to Guiness, of malty coffee stoutness, but surprising for this ale. The appearance also was similar to a stout, very dark, almost black, with little movement or carbonation once poured, almost zero head, and no lacing at all. 

The palate was silky and medium bodied, and I found the taste to be chocolaty sweet at first followed by an almost earthy aftertaste. 

Ill be getting more.

Pour from a 12 oz bottle. Dark brew with virtually no head - even an agressive pour plop down the middle of the glass results in only a half inch of foam. Aroma of spice, begain yeast, roasted grains. Flavor is sweet at first transitioning to a fruity, spciey, roasted coffee dominance. Roasted grains, dark fruits, cloves, tart fruit, ending with tart fruit and burnt coffee finish. Interesting and different and not bad, not something that really speaks to me though.

Bottle purchased at West Lakeview Liquors in Chicago Illinois. Pours a dark murky brown, with a fast to dissipate tan head. Fast acting lacing. Aroma is super faint, dark fruit and a little chocolate malt. Booze. Taste is dark fruite and bitter. Its like port. Real awesome on a few levels.

Pour dark brown with lighter edges thin dark tan head. Aroma spice, clove, yeast, cereal, caramel, roast, chocolate. Taste lots of intense spices, chocolatey, roast, cereal, toasty, burnt sugar, light notes of caramel. MF medium to full body with fine carb. Solid brew pretty intense flavor profile would like to see how it mellowed with age.
UPDATED: FEB 19, 2015 Thanks to Dad for this one. Somewhat like a sweet stout rather than a dubbel a lot of roasted flavor.  Serving: Bottle

On Tap....Pours pitch black with brownish head. Aroma is toffee, licorice and roast malt. Picking up currants in the taste as well as deep roasted malts. Very tasty with slight alcohol burn in the aftertaste.

12oz bottle from Holiday Market. Could of sworn I had this before. Pours very dark hazy brown with tan head. Looks more like a quad than a dubbel. Aromas of raisins, dark fruit, belgain yeast, bread, and some roast. Flavors of dark fruit, figs, raisins, yeast, and some chocolate and roast. Body was medium and carbonation was appropriate. Solid beer from Bells.
Bottle. Pours almost black with brown head. Nose/taste of grape, chocolate, raisin, dark fruit, fig, coffee and dry grain. Dryish finish - interesting dubbel/stout hybrid. Medium body.

Refrigerated bottle, 7.5% abv, poured into a trappist glass.  Pours opaque black with very small beige head.  A little lacing, medium body, medium/light carbonation.  Taste is roasted malt (milk chocolate with a hint of coffee), molasses, a little fig, and a hint of bitterness in finish.  Pretty good, the marriage of stout with a dubbel.

Bottle.  The listing above says Abbey Dubbel but this drinks more like a Quad.  Lots of dark fruit, raisins, maybe a touch of chocolate, and Belgian yeast strains.  Nice mouthfeel that is typical of the style

I think ratebeer hates me, I know Ive rated this one!  

Decent Dubbel, make sure it doesnt age too long though a couple of bottles I had for a while got pretty flat.  Dark fruit is present throughout, medium body with a dry finish.  good value if you want the style
Dark with a thin tannish head. Slightly roasty with a malty lean, but holding some spice as well. Roasted malt, toast, chocolate, and a hint of hops.

From bottle into New Belgium stemware. Deep brown pour with a thin tan head. Aroma is roast, smoky meat, and some typical stout notes. Flavor is...well, delicious. Much complexity, much to enjoy. Coffee, chocolate, dark fruit, alcohol, and Belgian funky yeast all harmonize into a beautiful balance of flavor. Finish is long, bitter, and sticky. Another really nice beer from Bells.
This has been my favorite beer for years!  Recently i have been getting into IPA?s but when i run a spell if mediocre beers i fall back ti old faithful.  dark, thick and just dam good!
Bottle from Wine & Cheese in Clayton, MO. Pours dark brown with a transient head. Aroma of dark fruit? Treacle? Med + body. Flavor is treacle, dark fruit,maybe cola, dark malt. Smooth. Tasty. Subtle.
Bottle shared by bhensonb. Pours dark brown with a tiny beige head and a treacle aroma. There is a dark molasses, anise and dark fruit flavor that is slightly sour and dry. Complex and tasty.

Date: December 16, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Heritage Description: Opaque dark brown pour with minimal head. Aroma was bready/yeast, licorice, spice and smoke.  Taste was similar to aroma.  Some carbonation and medium bodied.  Very interesting, liked how the smokiness came out as it warmed.
Your standard, dark fruits, spices, candi sugars. Decent amount of smoke on the palate with actually balances the sweetness of the style wonderfully

Bottle - Pours...wow...really dark with a mahogany tint and a medium tan head. Nose is a mix of dark fruit and stout notes, most notably raisin, plum, and dark chocolate. Yeasty and sweet, with a touch of light spiciness. Taste is much of the same. The dark fruits are present up front, with a smooth brown sugar sweetness, transitioning into some light roast and chocolate. The finish oscillates back to dark fruitiness and warms all the way down the throat. Thick and smooth in the mouth, with a little overaggressive carbonation, but thats a small nit. Very good stuff when youre in the mood for something a little bolder and sweeter than the traditional dubbel.

12 oz bottle (10/18/11 on the label, sampled Dec 2011): pours extremely dark brown with a off-tan that collects at the edges, but doesnt go away 100%...aroma like a milk stout: roasted chocolate malts and bitter tanins...subtle banana undertones.  Great, lively palate attached to fruity plum and roasted coffee flavours.  One of the first unique beers I have had in ages...the combination of roasted malts and sweet fruit combines the things I like most from stouts and Belgian Dubbels: the roasted aroma of the stouts and the raisiny fruit flavour of the dubbel...this works!  Nice job.  Thanks for sharing, Adam!

[4111-20111112] Tap. Roasted wood panel malt and grainy caramel hints in the aroma. Black body with a medium-lasting foamy tan head. Sweetened and slightly charred wood in the flavour with a hint of bitterness. Medium-full body. Tasty, quite repeatable. (7/3/8/4/16) 3.8~
(@ Ashleys, Ann Arbor, MI)
This was a very enjoyable abbey dubbel. Dark in color and a sweet alcohol scent. This beer had a hefty body and was pretty sticky. Nice for the winter.
Pours a dark brown color with a reddish tint.  Has a small brown head that disappears quickly.  Smells of malts and some roasty goodness.  Has a nice taste to it.  I am enjoying it.

Did not work for me. Aroma of clove and roasted malts. Appearance is that of a stout. Taste is what you would expect when crossing a dubbel and stout. You get the roasted coffee taste up front with a sweet fruity alcohol induced finish. Would not purchase this beer again.

Bottle; pour is murky brown in this tulip, with a very mild beige head that doesnt retain well at all really. The nose is heavier on the roasty notes, with a hint of dark fruits, the flavor profile is indeed a fusion of belgian and stout notes (roast coffee, plums, caramel, bittersweet morsels), with a hop bitterness present as well. i can also say that i wasnt very impressed with this one

Pours a dark black color with a very small head that fades completely away in seconds. Aroma is cherries, cloves, and an astringent/alcohol smell. The taste is slightly sweet cherries, some belgian yeast flavors, slight bitter roasted malts, and maybe a touch of hops. Pretty decent and unique.

Pours a very dark appearance with a low, thin, tan filmy head. Aroma is more on the light side with toasted notes, light coffee roasted aromatics late, some light bitter dark chocolate and a very faint clove spiciness at the finish. Flavor starts off with a solid toasted malt kick but is quickly overtaken by the clove and generic yeasty spiciness seen in some Belgian brews. Roasted notes follow this with some very light chocolate and dark fruit notes. Finishes with a slight hot alcohol kick. Body is thick with a modest carbonation rate the consists of fine bubbles. Overall an okay brew. The combination of the yeast spiciness and overall roastedness of the brew is an almost "love it or hate it" combination. This fury was much more akin to my hos than my wifes.

Almost brown head that didnt last long.  notes are toffee, chocolate, nice hop aroma in there, honey, maybe some wheat.  Mouthfeel is medium to light... smooth.  The complexity of this beer is very unique.  Taste is a good amount of cherry, chocolate, some smoke flavor in there, toffee sweetness and some definite hops on the finish.  Well Made and Excellent.  Enjoyability 5/5.

Its so dark you cant see through it with a spotlight behind the glass.  It reminds me of a cross between the expedition stout -without the nasty alcohol kick- and a spicy holiday brew.  Its deceivingly medium bodied, despite the pitch black appearance. The carbonation is just right, not to airy, but not flat either. The nut aroma and maltiness add to the complex mix of flavors.  Good stuff.

12oz bottle. Really nice pitch-black color, brown head that fades to minimal. This is suprisingly dark, like the expedition stout, it seems. Really nice hop profile, like a creamy, rich black IPA. complex flavor, hard to define. Some dark fruit. Crisp carbonation, good texture. Nice light chocolate taste. Awesome. So complex. Light sweetness, bitter, spices... Nice and rich. Super awesome with this spicy curry that Im enjoying. Really good.

Pours a dark brown with a healthy beige head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, molasses and yeast. Sweet taste of choclate, caramel, coffee and dried fruit, with a slight bitterness from that roasty notes. Medium bodied with good amount of carbonation. Very nice beer for the cold weather, and a very interesting one as well.
very dark brown in color. slight smoke flavor with roast malt and some fig and toffee.

12 ounce bottle - $2.99 at Total Wine & More in Alpharetta, Georgia. Batch #10735.

Appearance: Pours a dark brown, near black body with a moderate-sized, beige head.

Smell: Roasty and fairly sweet-scented all around, implying sugary promises of gooey chocolates and caramels rounded with cooked fruits, phenolic spices, drizzled molasses and a small shot of alcohol.

Taste: Sweet chocolate morsels and coffee dosed with a fair amount of table sugar evolve into tastes of smoky molasses brushed berries, plump raisins, toasted pumpernickel, cracked cloves, and understated resins. Restrained bitterness. Some burnt caramel opening up as it warms. Drying, fruity, spicy finish thats reasonably smooth.

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Medium carbonation. A little bit chewy, even.

Overall: Something different, I liked it, and the overall flavor profile made me think of a Schmaltz anniversary brew. I went in a bit uncertain of the style, merely buying it as Im a fan of Bells, but enjoyed the malt-forward, stout-like elements blended with the Belgian qualities for a beer that seemed bigger than the listed 7.7%.

Black pour little brown hue thin tan head .... aroma is mostly just roasted malts ..... taste is roasted and sweet with light coffee and a fruity yeast and spicy clove that lingers into a dry and spicy finish .... there is a little warming abv in the finish .... elements of both styles but pretty average

Pours black with tan head.  Aroma is caramel, chocolate and some plum.  Taste is sweet with very faint bitters due to the roastyness.  Slick mouthfeel with a lighter then expected body.  Overall i enjoyed the roasty notes with a sweet side.

(bottle - 12 oz) Dark brown pour with a head that quickly dissipates. Fruity and slightly spicy aroma with a sweet note of that Belgian yeast. Some fruits and spices at the beginning of the flavor. Some chocolate and clove and coffee comes through at the middle with a sweet and slightly roasty finish. Definitely wouldve thought a stout if I didnt know any better.

Bottle pours very dark brown with brief tan head.  Aroma dark fruits, malts.  Taste dark fruits, licorice, malts, cloves, smoke.  Brief finish of licorice and clove.  Nice creamy palate with soft carbonation.  Alcohol slightly apparent.
Odd beer.  There is potential for this combination (dubbel and stout) but Im not sure Bells pulls it off.
Sweet roasted malt aroma.... Deep black in color.... Flavor is roasted malts, Belgian yeast... Notes of coffee and dark chocolate... Pretty good beer.

Opaque dark brown, good head, mild lace.  Taste isnt complex, mostly dried fruit and chalky chocolate balancing roasted malt.  Somewhat filling, probably best for sipping.  Reasonable, but certainly not as good as I expected.

Pours  black with a fleeting light brown head.  Chocolate, toffee, malt aromas, earthy aromas.  Dark fruit, licorice, chocolate, roasted malt, and cherry flavors.  Earthy hop finish with a sweet lingering aftertaste.  Nice creamy mouthfeel.  Medium body and carbonation.

Bottle thanks to Solan/GodofThunder: Poured a deep dark black brown with a thin bubble light brown/tan head. Aroma is dark and roast malts. Taste is burnt roasted malts with some fruits and light ridged cloves that breaks it up.

12oz pour almost black with a coffee colored head that is thin and disappears quickly. not alot of carbonation. the aroma is of roasted toasty malt with hints of coffee and chocolate.  the first taste is truly unique you are expecting that same roastiness and you are not denied but then you have that belgium style abbey intertwined into beautiful goodness.  you can taste the smoky roasted malty goodness with the blend of belgium yeast in there. very light alcohol burn. a very good beer.

12 oz bottle. Pours a pitch black color with little-to-no head; surprisingly dark for a dubbel. Smells of dried fruit (raisin?), caramel, malt, some roasted smells, and maybe some dough or yeast aroma too. Tastes of dried citrus fruits, hint of caramel only, and a definite yeast taste to it. Not terribly strong mouth feel, but goes down smooth. Interesting take of a dubbel by Bells.
Very dark Belgian Dubbel, this has plenty of rich flavor but isnt too overwhelming.  The 7.7 ABV is just right too, and encourages refills.

2011-11-12. Black body with a small tan head. 3+ Black body with a nice tan head. 3+ Flavour is not what I am expecting from a dubbel, slightly off-putting dusty malt character up front fades thankfully, sweet malt, kiss of caramel, still a bit of an undercurrent of the dust malt notes. Aroma has dusty malt overtones, with allusions to cocoa. Smooth medium bodied palate suits the beer. 3+ Nice beer that was not quite what I was looking for tonight and might fare better on another day. On tap at Ashleys, Ann Arbor

Aroma is dark fruit and raspberries, as well as dark malt.  The flavor is dark fruit up front with roasted maltiness and a bit of alcohol into the finish.  Normally I dont care for Belgian-style stouts, typically the yeast meets roasted malts are too odd of styles to combine but this was very good, it seemed more subtle than others and more leaning towards the Belgian style Abbey Ale with some roasted malts than trying to mix the style together equally.

Dark pour with small beige head. Aroma of malts, banana and a bit of coffee. Taste is banana, cloves, slightly malty, touch of roastiness. Nice carbonation and mouthfeel. This beer leans more to being a stout than a dubbel.

12oz bottle from Picks poured into a Trappist glass. Batch 10735. Pours black with a small bit of dark brown head. Aroma is mostly coffee with a lot of fruit. Plum, banana, and a little citrus. Cloves and chocolate. Taste is medium bitter and very light sweet. It tastes like a cup of coffee with a banana dunked in it. Sounds bad but it is absolutely awesome. Full bodied with a thick and creamy texture. Lively carbonation and a long, coffee-bitter finish. Overall, awesome. I would gladly drink it every day if it wasnt for the 15.49 per 6er price point.

Totally opaque dark dark brown with a decent tan colored head.  Aroma is espresso and brown sugar.  Lots of different flavors happening here, licorice, dark bakers chocolate, sweet burnt malt, and dried dark fruit.  Very good, but an Abby Dubbel?  If it looks like a stout, smells like a stout and tastes like a stout, guess what?

This is the darkest abbey dubbel that I have ever seen, it pours dark mahogany black with sediment, bubbles, and a tan head. The aroma is raisins, burnt caramel, and brown sugar. It has flavors of roasted malts, a subtle creaminess on the body, and dark fruits as an abbey dubbel would normally have. Personally to my palate tastes like roasty stout, but delicious overall.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with an off-white head. Aroma is roasted with some chocolate, licorice, green apples and malt. Flavor is sweet and malty with some warming and roasted malt. Medium body, average carbonation.

Batch 9999! Still awaiting news of what Batch 10000 will be.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Snifter.

Appearance: Almost pure black with thin tan head and a couple of lacing tendrils.

Aroma: Chocolate and anise accented roasted malts, dark musty and sweet fruit, clove and alcohol.

Taste: Strange mix of musty sweet fruit and roasted malt. Notes of clove, plum, raisins, licorice and chocolate. Improves as it warms somewhat.

Palate: Creamy and chewy but slightly chalky body, moderate carbonation.

Overall: Interesting beer overall with lots of different flavors and smells kicking around. This is a more than solid "Belgian Stout".

Had this at a summer beer festival and the thought of a dark, heavy beer wasnt real appealing in the hot summer sun, but oh, man was I wrong! This beautiful, silky black brew was wonderful. Extremely complex, had a hard time figuring out the style (none of us guessed Dubbel). This beer is a huge win for a brewer that has been getting its ass handed to it by newer micros in Michigan.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Bloomington, Indiana, USA

text: Pours a very deep brown almost black with a nice deep brown head. The aroma is loads of fruit most specifically banana with a nice mild coffee like roastiness, the nuttiness I expect from a dubbel is not really present in the aroma here. The flavor is mildly roasty with a lot of fruit flavors (lots of banana again) and some booze. The Banana makes me think of weizenbock, this is a many faced beer no doubt.

Tap at Bells Circus, el Bait Shop. The nose has anise, lots of roast and some coffee. The body is lightly smooth for the abv. The taste is roasted coffee with hints of plum. Good drinking, like a stout with a little funk.

Draft at Haze.  Opaque brown blackish.  Steady oily head.  Full bodied.  Chocolate raisin tones, with a hint of warming alcohol.  Solid fruity Belgian yeast taste, but the body doesnt really strike me as Belgian at all..more Porter like.  Sweet, quite tasty, but not a great example of the style.  Choco-Dubbel.

Batch 9999, so its a couple months past its prime, but if anything, its mellowed some from this fall when I tried it fresh. Pours coffee black (anyone see Semi-Pro? Haha) with a miniscule tan head forming a ring around my glass. Im definitely getting some dark fruit and slight coffee on the nose. Has some quite active yet light carbonation and some oily sediment action. Despite the heavy malt, this is very well balanced with some hop bite still present on the finish. I feel this has aged well, as i remember it being a little hot on the palate when I first tried it. A strange brew as a Belgian Dubbel/Stout hybrid, but well worth trying.

Tasted on 6/21/11 from a 12oz bottle purchased at Lush West Town, probably a little less than a year ago, batch #9999.  Pours a completely opaque dark coffee brown with a red tint and an average light brown head that slowly recedes to spotty lace.  The nose is roasted coffee and caramel malt along with clove and cinnamon, dark chocolate, and a dark prune juice fruitiness.  The flavor is more of the same with some lightly sweet caramel and dark fruity malts up front along with the clove and cinnamon showing nicely and then finishing with the more bitter roasted notes of roasted coffee and dark chocolate.  The body is full and creamy with average mouth-filling carbonation that helps perpetuate the creamy feel and a long roasted coffee, caramel, and dark fruit finish.
(bottle) clear dark brown with small brown head; aroma of dried fruit, smoked fruit, flavor a bit on the sweet side, good

Draft.  Pours very dark brown with a dense, medium-sized tan head.  Aroma is very mild, but I get a some roasted malt, chocolate, and a vague yeastiness.  Flavor is big:  roasted malt, chocolate, nuts, a touch of coffee, dark fruit, some banana and bubble gum, a yeasty earthiness, some vanilla, and a touch of smoke. Finish is long and chocolatey and showcases some of the Belgian flavors.  Mouthfeel is full and creamy.   Aroma gets stronger and the flavor opens up a bit as it warms.  This beer is all over the place, inhabiting some strange nether region nexus of an Abbey dubbel, a nut brown, and a dry stout.  But I like it.

pours a dark brown with a medium tan head. the nose is interesting, resembling a stout, with caramel, raisins, and belgian yeast notes. the taste is kinda where it starts crumbling down. dark fruits, raisins, caramel, and banana. overall a decent beer but it certainly disappointed.

Batch 9999.  Brown sugar, earthy barnyard, some tanned leather, toasted hazelnut.  Very dark brown, small tan head.  Heavy body, lots of leather tannic wood, some maple syrup, nearly sticky in its concentrated malt forward body.  Hint of a briny oyster.  Just a hint.

Batch 8739; bottle courtesy of natedoggkc. Pours a deep mahogany with a short-lived khaki head that diminishes to a ring of bubbles clinging to the glass. The nose is an interesting hybrid of dark roasted malt, like a stout, with the fruity raisin and spicy (clove) notes more typical in a dubbel: a tad odd at first, but it grew on me. Medium-bodied and oily with a thinning finish that highlights a mildly drying hop bitterness. The flavor is of raisiny and roasty malt notes with supporting clove spiciness and drying, resinous, piny hops. Overall, this is an enjoyable beer, but it comes across fairly disjointed. I will need to make sure that I try this again with a little less age on it. Thanks again for the bottle, Nate.

Pours a dark mahogany with a with a tan head that circles the glass. A whiff of pepper, caramel and chocolate malt in the nose and some spicy hops. Medium-bodied and a lasting finish. Sweet and malty with a dry, peppery finish. Unique.

Poured a black color with medium head.  More sweet aromas of cloves and candied sugars and fruit.  Taste was medium sweetness with a lite bitterness.  Palate -  Medium body, creamy texture (silky), carbonation on softer side.  What a nice blend by Bells.  Its definitely in the abbey style family, with the slight coffee stout flavors coming through near end.

Bottled sample. Very dark brown in colour with medium carbonation.  Aromas are of pale malt, tar, stewed fruit, and maple smoke. More smoked malt in the mouth, along with notes of caramel and orchard fruit. Medium bodied and quite smooth. Balanced overall, but still maintains some strong flavours.Good.

12oz bottle. Dark brown with a thin bubbly head. Slight oily lacing and pretty good carbonation. Aroma has slight hints of chocolate and dark fruit but nothing really jumps out and grabs me. The flavor is somewhat bitter but slight fruity qualities. A decent beer but I probably wont seek out again.

12oz bottle poured into my Bruery tulip...Dark brown with a nice medium brown head, pretty nice retention but lacking on the lacing...Light aroma, I can sorta see the dubbel notes; alcohol, plums, sugar and spiced mixed with coffee, and strangely clove...More dubbel characters but this has way to much alcohol for me, candied sugar, dark fruits and spice. Light chalk finish.

Dont hate but dont love it. Not a drain pour but wouldnt have it again.

12oz bottle in a shaker.  Pours dark brown with a beige head.  Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, nuts, and spicy yeast.  Flavor different from most dubbels, with more roasted and chocolate malts.  Average texture.  A good beer for this style.

This beer has little carbonation, which may explain a near lack of aroma.  The color of the beer is nice and dark.  Very pleasing to the eye.  The initial taste give an expectation of chocolate, but a weak roasted coffee is what one receives.  There is a refreshing, if somewhat bitter finish. Leaves quite a few blegies in the bottom of the glass- perhaps a too vigorous pour to produce a head.

Bottle via Bonster, girl you are the man!  Hmmmm...you get what I mean.  In the recliner I find myself with this amusing label, my slippers, a teardrop glass and the remote control.  Big and hearty, this beer hits you from several angles at once.  Nose is strong spice and stonefruit.  Hazy in the glass (my fault) still adds to the seemingly jumbled appearance of this rich treat.  Went down quick as I enjoyed big mouthfuls of this elixir.  thanks for grabbing this one for me.
Pours pretty darn dark. Looks like a stout. Not quite as thick though. Lovely tart yeasty fruit. Plenty of coffee and dark chocolate. Great new world spin on the dubbel.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2011 Bottle in KC, courtesy of foppa78. Black appearance with a smallish light tan head. Dark, sweet Belgian malty, slightly spicy nose. Sweet, slightly caramelized dark candy sugar flavor. Also some flavors of toffee, chocolate, and light yeast. Caramel, dark candy sugar finish. Nice brew.

12 oz bottle, batch 9999!

It ours a dense, dark brown/black with a foamy tan head that sticks for a good bit. It is very firm and persistent. 

The smell is kind of all over the place. It almost reminds me of a dunkelweizen rather than a belgian strong dark. It has a significant amount of bubblegum and banana in the scent. There is also some fruitiness and clovy spice. There is the slightest hint of black malts.

The flavor is all over the place as well. Lots of bubblegum, some chocolate, clove, coffee. It just isnt a flavor that i can get in tune with.

The mouthfeel is a bit thin and watery.

A failed experiment in my book.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-10-2010 06:05:33

Pours very dark opaque brown with a moderately tall head that slowly recedes. Smells of jerked stonefruit from a hikers lunch box. Full nectar with a nice creamy texture, good carbonation. Jerked and smoky, this double is on the extreme end of its spectrum. Id call it a strong ale actually. I can definitely sense the A.D. persona. Rich and malty pushing abused and tortured banana pulp with a sliver of medicine. A nice acidic twitch to balance and the blubbery malt.

This is a great beer.  Pours thick and almost black with a slight tan head.   The aromas are sweet and malty, with hints of caramel and vanilla.  This beer has a nice, smoky flavor with hints of toffee and vanilla.  This will definitely be going on my "favorite beers" list.
A medium bodied malty beer. Dark fruits and some vanilla in the flavor and aroma. Light taste of alcohol in the finish. Not overly sweet. Highly drinkable and very good.

12oz. bottle. Batch 9999. Bottle conditioned. Served in a Duvel tulip. Poured a deep reddish brown with a finger of tan head. Aroma of dark malts and a hint of smoke. Medium bodied. Lots of carmelized sugar in the flavor, along with more smoke. Carmelized sugar lingers in the finish. Didnt get much Belgian characteristics from this. Glad I only bought the single.
Bottle.  Pours brown with virtually no head.  Aroma of yeast and chocolate.  Taste of cocoa, Belgian yeast, and candied sugar.  Decent but was expecting more.

Bottle courtesy of Doodler poured a clear dark brown with a lasting brown head. Aromas of cocoa, cola, carmel and dak fruit. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of cocoa, vanilla, cola and carmel with a smooth lingering cocoa finish.

Bottle pours deep brown with a creamy khaki head.  Aroma shows notes of figs, dates, cocoa, and coffee.Flavor shows the same with additional notes of plum and molasses. Overall body is moderate and creamy.

Batch 9999. Pours thin, almost black with one finger tan head that quickly fades to a slight ring around the edge of the glass. Appearance is similar to the average porter. There is almost no lace on the glass. Nose is of black cherry, toasted malt, plum, and clove. Taste of decaf coffee, smoke, fig and earth; not as much on the yeast side as expected. but still thin on the mouthfeel; Chalky finish.

Poured from a 12oz bottle from Manny57.  Pours a nice mahogany color with little head.  Smell is figs and chocolate and lots of abbey yeast.  Taste is slightly sweet with a ton of belgian yeast flavor.  Not a bad effort really...not the best I have had, but far from the worst.

Very dark brown pour with a great tan head. Aroma is amazing...all over the place. Spices, honey, figs, raisins, molasses, cocoa and more. Flavors are melded pretty well together. Dark fruits, spices, some honey and molasses. I like it very much!!

Pours very dark brown color with little head. Smells mostly of chocolate and Belgian yeast. Flavors of dark fruit, chocolate, spices, yeast and some vanilla. Fizzy mouthfeel and kind of thin. A pretty good Dubbel but lacking in body and appearance.

Pours dark brown, close to black... very dark for an abbey dubbel. Aroma is of spice, dark fruits, and a little bit of toffee. Flavor is of cloves, Belgian yeast, licorice. Medium bodied with a spicy finish and a slight fruit aftertaste.
Little Roastedness, lots of Belgian sugar and Belgian chocolate flavors, quite fizzy. This is more dubbel than stout, but I really like it. Its just not over the top, too easy to drink.

12oz bottle from Chevy Chase in DC.  Pours a dark brown, almost black, color with a very small tan head.  The aroma is massive anise, along with coffee and spices.  Pretty nice.  The flavor is not as good, a little amateur/homebrew-like.  Loads of licorice, Twizzler-like, with roast and a slight Belgian yeasty note as well as spice.  Medium body with spicy tingling and lower carbonation.  A very interesting beer, but Im not really the biggest fan.

Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured thick, black and oily with a large very dark brown head that left some lacing. The aroam was sweet cherries, cocoa, cola, vanilla and nut. The flavor was semi sweet with nutty malts, bread, cherries, cocoa, vanilla, cola and basil. The finish was long and dryish with notes of cocao, nut, cola and vanilla lingering. Thick and smoot body. Very nice.

Smells and sweet, earthy, roasty.

Pours dark black, like a stout with an off-white head.  Some lace, mostly just above the top of the pour.  After a sip, the lace quickly slides down the glass and disappears.

Its a little too sharply carbonated in that it takes away from the flavor. Leaves a dry aftertaste.

This is an almost-stout. Light roastiness, coffee, something sweet and tangy as well.  It drinks heavy. It is basically a stout. Its not quite as heavy and not quite as roasty as most stouts.
Pours a dark haze. Maybe I drank this too cold. Pours a dark opaque brown/black. Aroma is somewhat sweet.  Just not a huge fan.

Pours a dark chocolate brown with little head to speak of. Aorma a little on the sweet side, not strong enough to make a good anaylsis. Taste is a smooth hint of licorice, not outstanding but solid. My bottle maybe on the verge of going skunk, along with my bottle of Mikkeller Rauch Geek Breakfast. So I am giving this beer a higher rating than I would have normally.

The looks of a stout and the taste of a Belgian. Faint aroma of dark fruits and chocolate. Medium body with a thin texture. Lots going on with this one, Chocolate, roasted malts, plums and to a much lesser degree, some faint coffee notes are present. NUMMY!

Pours dark brown almost purple with thin off white head.  Do not drink this cold, but once warm aromas include some roast, anise, some spices and yeast.  Taste is some sweet plum, anise, dark fruit, some roast and biscuity notes, spicy and yeast finish.  Pretty good, complex, but a bit too sweet.

Tallahassee, Fl - Liquor Loft - 12 oz bottle. Deep purple fading to jet black viscous pour with a very slight off-white head. Aroma is faint, but sweet with some slight molasses hints and a hint of chocolate. Flavor is rich and full-bodied with some dark chocolate, prunes, a hint of red wine, some roasted flavor and a bit of coffee. Mouthfeel is thick and rich. Excellent winter warmer.
Pours very dark brown with tan head. Aromas of roasted malts and dark fruits. Roasty flavor with a touch of sweet plums and some bitter chocolate. Medium to full body with average carbonation.

12oz bottle.  Pours deep & dark like a porter with a thin creamy head.  Aromas are faint but probably open up once the beer warms.  Tastes of Robust sweet malts, with dark chocolatey malts on top. A mild hopness which doesnt over power the delicious malty goodness.  I really enjoy this beer and would buy it again.

With drak brown full body, Hell Hath No Fury looks like a porter, but drank like an American Strong Ale.  However, it had the breadiness that Id expect in an Abbey Dubbel.    Roasted malts and licorice bring in the stout like qualities.  Well built beer, just not sure if there is a specific season its supposed to represent.   Winter works for me.

Draft at redlight redlight. Pours a dark mahogany brown color and topped by a small, smooth head of tan colored foam that recedes quickly to a thin film. The aroma is fairly complex with notes of dark fruits, toasted caramel, dark chocolate, tobacco, and some earthy hop bitterness. The flavor follows suit with the dark fruits, earthy hops and spices, toasted caramel, and chocolate roast. Full bodied, smooth with balanced carbonation that leads to a dry, roasty finish. This is a nice hybrid dubbel with some porter/stout character to it as well. Really nice and tasty beer.

this is as odd a beer to say the least, a belgian with stout like qualities. the pour is beautiful with a dark brown head and an oily appearance. aroma is roasted grains and somewhat piney. flavor is wild, i taste earthy notes of pumpernickel bread and grilled grapefruit, with some dry cocoa mixed with some typical belgian astringency. finish is fairly light and clean with only a mild greasy finish. weird and not something i could drink a lot, but still pretty interesting all the same.

Pours dark brown with a tan head. Nose is roasty, chocolate, spices and slight sweetness. Flavor is nice roasted malts, with chocolate flavors as well. Follows up with slight spice flavor and ends with a bit of bitterness. Nice creaminess to it as well. Nice beer.

12 ounce bottle from Tops in Tempe in Chimay glass.  Almost black with tan ring.  Roasty earthy mild coffee and spicy yeasty aroma.  Earthy roasty coffee chocolate with medium Belgian fruitiness and roasty spicy bitter finish.  Definitely very much like described above. Almost a Belgian stout.  And it really works well in this one,  Delicious.

Bells batch 9999.  Trying alongside batch 10,000.  Congratulations to Bells!  Pours black with a thin tan head.  Aroma is roasted malt, a hint of chocolate, and candy.  Flavor is remarkably smooth and mellow, with plenty of malt sweetness, a little dried fruit, and some alcohol warmth in the finish.

Deep brown-red coloring.  Aroma is fairly complex with roasted malts, rye bread, and pumpernickel with a whisp of banana/clove at the end.  Taste is Belgian candy, gingerbread and finishes with some nice roastiness.  Bitter, dry finish.  Medium palate.

On tap at the Brick Store Pub. The pour is black, with a small tan head that leaves plenty of lacing. The scent is most like a baltic porter, with roasted malts, coffee, caramel and a hint of sea salt. The Belgian dubbel peeks through the stout and adds an undercurrent of fruits and spices. The flavor is malty, with a little bitterness. The body is medium to heavy, and the mouthfeel is a little thin. Overall, more like a slightly subtle stout than a dark dubbel.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2010 Bottle. Dark brown pour with a big carbonation head. Carbonation abounds - clings to the inside of the glass. Sediment seen at the bottom. Aroma is mainly raisin/fig, with yeast. But there is also a roasty chocolate component. Mouthfeel is creamy and bubbly. Taste is chocolate, coffee, and fruit/yeast. Very good.
Smokey flavor.  For a smoked barley not bad.  But minimal still on the smoked side.  Probably would be excellent with a steak but alone, a bit overwhelming.

Bottle split with Linh on Thanksgiving. Pours a darkened reddish brown body with nice haze. Aroma is sweet malt, cocoa, bitter chocolate, and clove. Flavor is very malt-based with notes of yeast, chocolate malts, slight coffee and clove

Bottle; poured a darker than expected, brown to black with not much head.  Aroma was sweet with cocoa, sugar, smarties, cocoa and earth.  Flavor of cocoa, fruit and sugar.  Some chalkiness.  Flavor had a little less sweetness.

On tap at Lunar Brewing Co., and served to a snifter with darkest brown color, modest, light tan head foam that gradually diminished to a ring and film, and left some nice rings of draping lace, punctuated by some clingy spots. The aroma was smooth malt, dark fruit as plum, and light roastiness. The flavor was similar, with some dry cocoa, only a medium body, but a soft finish. A nice meeting of Dubbel and Stout, with the Stout notes taking the lead.

Pour is a black with a average tan head.  Aroma is a nice roasted malt with a lingering Belgian yeast in the backround.  Flavor is again roasted malt with a little anise and black licorice.  This is a very different and well made beer.  Not really a dubbel.  More of an American stong ale at best.

(12oz bottle).  Pours near black with w finger tan head.  Floaties.  Aroma of wood, belgian yeast, caramel.  Taste is sweet with some roasty bitterness.  Medium bodied with creamy texture.  Finish is bitter.  A bit water). Interesting beer.

A: Very dark with a brownish head. Pretty good lacing.

S: Roasted malt along with some sweet fruits. A bit of hops.

T: Chocolate and dark fruit; dark malts and some style-specific yeast characteristics.

M: Full body and medium carbonation. Fairly chewy.

D: Definitely one to be sipped, but all around very enjoyable.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-25-2009

As others have already said, its somewhere between a stout and an abbey. A nice roasted character to it with a yeasty, dark fruit finish. Very unique beer--I think Ill need another to really figure out.

Aroma is strong and yeasty with fruity and caramel hints. It pours a dark chocolate brown with a fairly thick and fine-bubbled tan head, looking rather like a stout or porter. Rich, mouth-filling flavor is mainly yeasty with tones of caramel, roast coffee and chocolate, as well as a hint of hop bitterness. Sublime texture is thick, oily and fizzy. I strongly recommend this one!
Bottle from craft beer outlet. Nice dark brown pour with a good aroma of bread and roasted malt. Nice rich chocolate taste with hints of caramel, roast and coffee. Interesting brew.
Roasty, chocolate, and some coffee.  Dark brown in color with little head.  Taste is smooth with some chocolate, cloves, coffee, and roast.

Batch 9999
Dark pour with a brown head. Aroma is dark fruits, candi sugar, yeast. Taste is like the aroma but creamy. Very easy to drink for 7.5% .

The aroma is very toasted and a little bit smokey with hefe like fruity yeast. The appearance is dark brown with a large foamy head. The taste is like the aroma. The palate is average. Overall I am of the opinion that this is an interesting beer but not a great one.

16 oz bottle Pours a very dark, deep brown with tan head. Aroma is like a imperial stout almost, Dark roast, a little nuttiness. Flavor is different, its like a stout and Abbey double blend very unique. Dark roast, some nuttiness, malty, some dark fruit, some hop, Mouth feel is medium-heavy body with low carbonation. Very nice showing to bad I only have one bottle.

Pours dark brown with a small off white head. Lightly carbonic aroma with some sweetness. Flavor is roasted nutty and slight sweet with a creeping heat from the chili. Great mouthfeel. Bells does good work.

12oz bottle, batch #9999, from grape & gourmet. pours a dark brown with a thin, whispy, beige head and bubbly lace. aroma is very nice with sweet, dark fruit notes of prune, fig, and dates backed by candi sugar, yeast, and light chocolate notes with a hint of roasted, nutty coffee. flavor is a delicious meshwork of dubbel and stout with notes of cedar, yeast, clove, and dark fruit notes of raisin and cherry up front backed by dusty, roasted malts, coffee, and bitter cocoa. palate is medium bodied with high carbonation leaving a dry, roasted, fruity finish. overall, a very unique take on a dubbel.
dark ruby with modest head and little lacing, sweet with belgian fruit notes this is a very drinkable version of a double.  A little coffe and caramel notes but little peat or smoke.

Pours a dark black with a small head that disappears quickly. Smells of dark fruits, caramel and sugar. Palate starts off with a dry tobbaco flavor  that works into a sweet bannana, clove, and sugar with a bit of hops and acidity to finish. Not my style, but not bad at all.
pretty classic dark belgian. pretty dark pour. dark fruity, clove nose and typical related taste. this was a good dubbel but nothing too out of the ordinary.

Pours dark, dark brown almost black with a thinnish head. Has an interesting nose of malt and dried fruits with a hint of spice. The nose on this beer seems to open up as it sits. Tastes of fruity Belgian yeast, raisins, a hint of coffee and Dutch processed cocoa, with just a tease of alcohol underlying. Has a creamy palate with medium carbonation and finishes slightly dry. All in all a pretty good beer but seems like it leans a little to the dry stout side rather than being a straightforward dubbel.

bottle - batch 9999.  pours a deep black with a 1 finger tan head.  dark fruit aromas with some cloves and a touch of smoke.  medium body with layers of figs, raisin, Belgian yeast notes and sweet chocolate malts.  finishes sweet, with some light coffee notes along with more chocolate and dark fruit.  really nice hybrid stout / dubbel.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2015 Pours Coffee Brown with moderate tan head.  Fig/Clove/Malt Nose.  Aged fruit Belgian base with some Smokey Coffee Porter overtones.  I great combination of flavors resulting in an awesome brew.  Palate is full bodied with lasting finish.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a goblet.
Batch 9999; #10000 must be coming soon (I hope it doesnt take as long as 9000).

A: Pours an opaque dark brown with a tan head, leaving solid lacing.
S: Smells like dark fruits, like plums, figs, and raisins, with a bit of brown sugar/molasses to follow.
T: Some sort of mix between the aforementioned dark fruits and chocolate; no alcohol bite. What a delicious blend.
M: Medium carbonation and on the heavy side for the body.
D: This tastes like a blend between a porter and an abbey dubbel, like chocolate covered raisins. Its a nice dessert to follow up a hearty dinner.
Bottle pours a pitch black with a thin brown head. Scent is sweet malts and roastey. Taste is sweet roasted malts. Seems more like a stout and that is a good thing.
Medium body and a small head. The flavor consist of figs, chocolate, and has a bit of a roasted flavor.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from Fireworks. 
Aroma: The nose is a mix of roasted malt, molasses, a bit of yeast, and subtle clove notes. 
Appearance: I pours a deep black color with a thin, foamy, brown head. 
Taste: The flavor is dark cocoa powder, a very slight fruitiness, spice, yeastiness, and fresh baked chocolate cake.  A very straightforward mix of a belgian and a dry stout in my mind. 
Palate: Medium bodied with an almost creamy mouthfeel leading to a dusty chocolate finish. 
Overall: I found this blending of concepts delicious and well executed.  Definitely worth a go.

12oz bottle.Batch 9999.Pours a murky balck with red hues and a thick brownish red head.Nose is bright,dried fruits,toasted oak and even some smoke.Taste is heavy belgian fruity yeasts that give way to dry chocolate and coffee flavors.Wow!What a balance and complex beer.Bells is an outstanding brewery!!

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2010 Bottle.

A - Dark mahogany with a smaller than average, creamy, sticky, sandy head. Average retention with a nice layer of lace left.

S - Usual Belgian Dark Ale. Sweet dark malt, with a nice molasses and dark candi sugar sweetness. A nice bubblegum, and some phenol aroma. Hints of dark fruit, but not as much as I would expect. Also some sweet chocolate in there.

T - Less of a dark Belgian ale flavor than the nose suggest, and a little less flavorful. Still dark sweet malt and molasses/dark candi sugar, but it is more subdued. More chocolate and some coffee flavors coming out compared to the nose. Also a healthy amount of yeast comes out in the flavor, especially toward the finish. Phenol flavors moderate strength with only a little bubblegum. Malt, chocolate, coffee, and yeast all together outweigh the rest of the Belgian flavors. Some Belgian spice (especially clove) also present.

M - Moderate body with about average carbonation. Pretty smooth and creamy feel. Really nice feel.

D - Pretty drinkable with nice flavor (although a little lacking). Great body and feel though. Easy to drink and has a nice lingering taste.

Notes: Not a bad BSDA, and definitely had potential. Unfortunately the taste fell just a bit short for me. As it warmed, the flavor improved and had more Belgiany flavors (outside the yeast which was always pretty strong). I liked it, but probably wont get it unless it is on sale. Worth a try though.

batch 9999. Nose is very fruity up front with evident Belgian yeast character. Malt and roast in the nose. Taste is extremely pleasant with lots of esters, malts, raisins, nuts, roasted caramel, chocolate, and roasted malt. Thick and smoothe on the palate. Carbonation is low for a Belgian but nice. The lace at first makes you think it will stick but does not. and easy drinking unique Belgian.
