(null)

12oz bottle, batch 9999, bottled Sept 21, 2010.  Pours very dark brown, almost black with a two finger light brown foamy head that holds a good cap and leaves some small spots of lacing.  Aroma is heavy on dark fruit, some grass & herbal quality, a little chocolate and coffee, some alcohol.  Moderate to good strength.  Rich flavor of dark chocolate, coffee, dark fruits, plums, figs, raisins, black cherries, minimal alcohol, semi-sweet.  Rich, full, creamy and smooth mouthfeel with soft carbonation.  A very unique and delicious brew, excellent stuff.

A: Pours a nice brown with amber tones showing through. Very small off white head.

S: Aromas of mild roasted malt, belgian yeast, chocolate, and spice.

T: Yeasty goodness with a nice bold spice character. Chocolate and mild coffee tones. Clove really stands out.

M: Medium in body, light on the carbonation.

12oz.  Amazing art.  Phenomenal Belgie nose w/ hints of More lurking deep inside.  After the smell, I really didnt expect something so dark, but it was gorgeous. Taste was upfront smoke w/ roast.... wait this shiz claims to be a dubbel?  Still fun, even thou stouty. One was enough for me though.

Bottle. 12 oz. Pours an opaqe amber brown with a tan, reddish frothy foam head. Aroma of milk, chocolate, coffee beans, sweet dough, rasins, soft smoke, and hints of marshmallow. Full bodied with a really intensely smooth, suave, velvety palate. The beer sticks to the tongue, filling up with chewiness and a nice sweet finish. Very original take on a dubbel. Great brew.

10/23/10. 12oz bottle.  Very dark brown pour with a small brown head.  Dark, brown sugar, molasses, a hint of banana, and big dark fruits in the aroma.  Similar flavor but with noticable bitter malts and coffee as well.  Not bad!

Bottle.  Pour is deep dark brown with a medium tan head.  Aroma is rich roasted malt, light Belgian spice components, light coffee, and a touch of cinnamon.  Flavor is quite smooth with notes of Belgian spice, roasted malt, light cinnamon, and an initially sweet then dry finish.  Very easy to drink and very good looking beer.

On tap pours black with little or no head.  Aroma is more clove like than anything.  Medium mouthfeel.  Flavor is roast, belgian yeast, chocolate, and finishes with clove and a touch of dark fruit.  A nice beer.

Fruit, roast, and chocolate aromas make this beer very enticing from the start. Dark brown color is complimented  with a tan head. Chocolate, roasted malts, and a slight fruity sweetness combine to make this one of the smoothest beers Ive had recently. Very complex, rich, and smooth yet very drinkable.

Bottle at Fireworks.  Very dark brown, small tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, raisins.  Taste has vanilla, bitter cocoa, dark roast coffee, cinnamon.  Not over the top, a great example of a well made Belgian style stout.

12oz bottle. Pours a very deep brown, almost black body with a thin, creamy, dark brown head that dissipates quickly and leaves a nice lacing thats easily aroused with a few swirls. Aroma is sweet and malty with dark fruits, caramel, Belgian yeast, roast, banana esters, maple syrup, and some chocolate. Flavor is similar. Sweet malts and dark fruits with the roast coming out a bit more hard, but still in the background of the smooth dubbel style malts. More Belgian yeast and banana esters along with some pear, clove, raisin, chocolate, maple syrup, and brown sugar. Finishes smooth and malty sweet with a very light bitterness from the roasts and maybe a hint of earth. Just a tad bit dry with a fairly lengthy, malty/yeasty/roasty aftertaste following a malty, smooth, creamy, medium body and a light carbonation. Nice feel to this. Overall, a pretty interesting and unique beer. Cool blend of styles and well balanced between them all. Not bad.

12oz bottle.  batch 9999.  almost black...very black for the style under a medium, creamy, light brown head.  aroma has the fruity elements of a dubbel but the dark, roasty notes of a stout.  aroma reminds me of chocolate covered pineapple.  flavor has notes of banana and clove with a distinct belgian yeast and, of course, lots of chocolate.  palate is creamy and body is medium.  dry finish.

Bottle. Poured dark but thinner than expected with small creamy head. Aroma was roasty, unidentifiable fruit, and spice. Taste of dark chocolate, fruit, some roasted coffee, sweet malt, and the belgian yeast. Thin on the palate, with little hops, and mostly sweet with a little bitterness. 
Not knowing what this beer was, I was confused by what I thought was a stout. I couldnt pinpoint the flavor until I found out Belgian yeasts were used an it all made sense. Excellent experimentation by Bells.

Bottle, batch 9999.  Pretty pumped that I found an unrated Bells.  Dark pour, nice looking beige head.  Left a collar of foam from beginning to end.  Aroma was big and malty, lots of roast, some notes of burnt toast and cocoa.  Flavors were delightful.  A wonderful mix of dark malts, not super roasted, some subtle fruity nuances came through, I guess from the yeast.  The mouthfeel on thing one is incredible, about a smooth as it gets.  Im no expert on this style but this was just fantastic.  Gonna join my list of goto brews to drink when it starts to get cold outside.

Opaque black with a small light brown/ tan head that diminishes into a small ring rather quickly. The aroma is strong coffee, with dark chocolate, dark fruit, and Belgian yeast. The flavor is actually different than the aroma suggests. Very sweet, with dark fruit, and toffee upfront, it then fades into roasty coffee with a hint of chocolate. Full, smooth body with soft carbonation and a wet, balanced finish. Interesting change of pace. Very tasty.

Bottle. Picked it up having no idea what it was, but its Bells and I hadnt had it, so a no-brainer. Nose was surprising - fruity/roasty/sweet with a slight astringent heat. Flavor was really nice roasty up front, with the chocolate milk sweetness middle and a pleasantly warm, fruity finish. Nice touches of earthiness throughout. Really nice beer.

Bottle from Sams in Durham.  Pours more like a stout than a dubbel; dark, dark brown without much light coming through and a beautiful mocha head.  Nose shows chocolate, dark fruits, and generous Belgian yeasts.  Some anise notes. Tastes similar, with more of the yeast and fruit coming out as well as some spice.  Unique and delicious.  Full but not heavy palate.
Tap at Redlight. Pours black with a thin head. Spicy rye, chocolate aroma. Smooth chocolate, hints of coffee and some Belgian yeast notes in the taste.

I picked this up from Archer Liquors in Chicago, IL, enjoyed on a Sunday afternoon while watching football.  Not what I was expecting.  Pour is pitch black with a thin tan head.  Aroma of cloves, Belgian yeast, roasted malt, and a hint of chocolate.  This one packs a punch in a good way, tastes like a high ABV brew but not in an overpowering way.  Smooth with a bit of a bite in terms of a slight spice appearance, with the Belgian yeast, coffee, and clove present in the mix.  Theres a lot going on with this one, very good beer.

355mL batch 9999. A major want item for quite awhile. Pours a muddy deep brune almost black looking in the tulip with a very dark brown head more like a stout than Abbey Dubbel. Semi-rockiness gives way to little or no lacing. Aroma is smoked meats, cerise noire, slight alcohol, sweet abbey yeast, lots of Belgian yeast esters. Taste is roasty, dry, cocoa powder, dark chocolate bitter. Dry, chewy palate. Carbonation is very low.

Wow, this was a surprise.  It is very dark brown (could pass for a porter or stout) and has a tan/brown head.  Smells like coffee and yeasty funk.  Body is lighter than anticipated with a nice touch of black malt, burnt, and, surprisingly enough, a distinctive smokiness.  A light touch of hop bitterness, and a moderate combination of yeast spice and fruit makes this an oddball double.  Yay!  I love tasting stuff like this!

Poured from 12oz bottle, pours a dark brown with a fizzy tan head thats about 2 fingers thick, aroma is sweet and has hints of caramel in it, the flavor is commplex with caramel, nuts and earthy notes.  Glad I really got my hands on this one!

Bottle. Batch 9999!  Pours a really dark brown color with a nice 1 finger tight tan head. Almost has a slight smokey taste to the nose along with dark chocolate and some spice. Nice lace left on my Duvel glass as the head gets jostled around. Biscuity, roasty, a little smokey, and some sweetness is how I would describe this beer. Medium mouthfeel. Ends pretty cleany. For 7.7% the3 alcohol is decently hidden with only a glimmer popping up if you are looking for it. Overall, a decent beer although I cold do without the slight smokeness it has.

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2010 Pours black with a brownish tint, head is a caramel color and disapates quickly, carbonation is minimal.  Aroma of caramel, slight chocolate and toasty nuts.  Taste is malty sweet and mildly bitter.  Its creamy and delicious.

12 oz. bottle from Ludlow Wines.  Batch 9999.  Pours a cloudy, smooth-looking dark brown color with a small tan head.  Aroma of caramel malts, maple syrup, banana, brown sugar, dark chocolate, and yeast.  Flavor of caramel malts, banana, maple syrup, cherries, rust, and brown sugar.  Medium-bodied, with a smooth, malty mouthfeel and fairly low carbonation.  Interesting take on a dubbel, and I really like this one.

I am always sort of fascinated by things that are exactly equal to the sum of their parts. Here we have a strong porter or perhaps a strong dry stout brewed w/ a Belgian yeast. It tastes pretty much exactly like what youd expect such a thing to taste like, which is neither as bad as you might fear nor as good as you might hope. The appearance is definitely that of a stout, nearly black w/ a tan head which lasts just a minute and leaves behind only a few spots of lace. Clove-like Belgian fruitiness is backed by a coffee-like roasted grain character. The flavor is pretty much the same mish-mash, paired w/ a medium to heavy body w/ somewhat spritzy carbonation. No magic--for good or for evil--comes to be as the joining of these sets of flavors.  Honestly, the main good I think this might do in the beer world is saving a few open minded homebrewers the trouble of doing something like this themselves just to see.

Bottle. Black with a small brown head. The beer was a little on the cool side when I poured it, and the aroma was initially yeasty. As it warmed I got a better sense of roasted malt, prune, and a funky earthy/woody smell. Flavor was coffee, roasted malt, molasses, and slightly spicy dry finish. As the beer warmed I got a yeasty banana flavor.Kind a weird beer.

Bottle.  Pours a dark, black color with a nice tan head.  Light syrupy texture.  Hints of bread, clove, coffee, and toast.  It tastes like a stout and a Belgian had a child.  Lighter bodied than a stout but certainly heavier than an ale.  Interesting and pretty tasty.

Bottle to snifter. Pour is very brown black with a creamy tan head that dissipates to a film on top. Aroma is strong coffee and coco with a nice roasted malt scent as well. Taste again is rich coffee and malt which comes off roasted. I really get alot of porter characteristics with this one. Palate is full and smooth which turns to chaulky and dry. Very interesting style, that I must say I enjoy greatly. Will buy more tomorrow!
12 ounce bottle purchased from tiffanys in kalamazoo, mich.  This is an interesting brew with unique flavor.  Not my favorite style by any means, but i enjoyed it none the less.
Bottle pours pitch black with a light chocolate, almost red head. Nice toasted malt flavors without a lot of sweetness along with dark fruit and spice. I can get behind that.
Wow, the roasted malt aroma is great.  Pours very dark with a tan head.  Taste is sweet malt with a great roasted flavor.  Very tiny bitterness, medium mouthfeel.  Very tasty and drinkable.

12oz btl. Pours medium bodied and very dark with almost a reddish undertone.Has a mild fruit aroma. Of maybe raisin or prunes. Great balanced taste with a nice roasted sweet start with nice spicy fruity hop in the middle then kicking up at the end. Really enjoyed this.

12 oz bottle from Princetons.  Dark chocolate colored pour with a big tan head.  Very complex aroma, I get fruity (of the darker variety), chocolatey and spicy.  Flavor is definitely more on the dubbel side, with the dark fruit and spices you find in a Belgian dubbel.  I get the chocolate a bit more in the finish, but more of a roasty, slightly hoppy finish.  Awesomely unique beer.

great aroma of sweet malt, barnyard yeast, chocolate, black cherry, and coffee.  pours jet black with a dark brown head.  tastes like a belgian brown ale mixed with a stout; sweet malt, dark chocolate, coffee, dark fruits with a roasty sweet malt finish.  palate is light- medium body, slick feel, some carbonation.

Coca-Cola color and head, huge maple syrup and molasses aroma, dark but not opaque-beautiful in the glass. brown sugar and maple - wow. malty, but not too sweet, not quite roasty, unique, spicy and rich. brings thoughts of maple and brown sugar oatmeal. long sweetish finish, much better than expected for such a malty brew

Poured from the Mellow Mushroom in Greensboro after the Summerfest Brews Festival.  Served from tap into a Chimay goblet.  Pours a deep dark brown with a one finger tan head.  Maintained excellent lacing throughout.  The aroma was comprised of bananas, alcohol, malt, and vanilla.  The flavor was of fruit, malt, caramel, alcohol, and vanilla.  It had a medium feel on the palate with low carbonation.  Overall this was a nice brew.  Went down quite smooth and was quite enjoyable even after a day FULL of drinking at the festival.  Had a very nice flavor, but just a decent aroma for its style.  Worth trying for sure.

Draft sample at Bells. Nothing exciting. Looks like a dubbel with orangey red brown body, quite clear with a fluffy head that dissipates. Nose is dusty and spicy with strong phenols. bottle courtesy of coyotehunter, thank you! batch 8739. dark brown to black pour with small brown head, some yeast flakes suspended and light lacing. aroma is very light, consisting of vanilla, fresh oak, a light cocoa and even a hint of toasty coconut every now and then. taste is toasty, nice creamy mouthfeel, a smooth drinker. i appreciate the carbonation and full body that last all the way through.

Bottle from pimpp, thanks patrick. Batch 8739, about a year old...Black wax? Black pour with a one finger sized head. Aroma of some oak, raisons, dark fruits and some maltiness. Doesnt taste like the nose... light coffee, roasted malts, and chocolate. Reminds me of a stout.... Texture is on the lighter side but still good. Bottle. Pour is deep brown (almost black) slight bitterness.  Dry on the finish with a bit of alcohol.  Big Flavors, caramel, vanilla, coffee.  Good Stuff.

Another lovely bottle thanks to coyotehunter.  Pours black with minimal foam.  What there was disappears almost immediately.  Aroma is coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, and vanilla booze.  Taste is the same.  There is an odd flatness to the flavor that Im not sure what to make of.  It is tasty, and the ABV is well hidden until right at the very tail end of the palate.  Its an almost metallic quality that Ive encountered in a few beers of late and makes me wonder if something hasnt gone slightly wrong with this one.  Still, the emphasis should be on "slighty".  Its a medium bodied brew that brings a fine smokey quality and plenty of flavor to the table.  Like a woman, well worth weathering the rough patches for the moments of glory in between.

Bottle, thanks to ballewblake.  The smell is malts, chocolate, coffee, roasty, smoke, and nice.  The look is brown to black in color with a decent beige colored head.  The taste is malts, coffee, choclate, and roast.

Nice brew from Bells.  Dont get me wrong, this is a really tasty beer, but not necessarily true to style.  First off, head retention was a little weak.  Belgian yeast character not very prominent.  In a blind taste test I would wager that more often than not people would pin it as a baltic/imperial porter than a belgian dubbel.    Rich dark chocolate with heavy to medium roast malt with some lingering hop on the back end.

6-Pack from Capones, Norristown, PA...bottle pours dark brown with a bit of reddish tinge around the edges, small tan head...smell of malts, dark fruits and brown sugar...flavor included much of the same with a hint of licorice and black cherry, bit of alcohol on the back-end...nice smooth mouthfeel...another really good offering from Bells...Id enjoy it even more in the colder months.

Hell hath no fury like a woman scorned.


Certainly a terminology all of us are familiar with. Bells Brewing out of Comstock, Michigan fully understands that there is no hell like the hell born of a woman scorned, hence their delightfully dark and stormy ale, Hell Hath No Fury. One of the few beers of Bells I have not quaffed yet, it was graciously gifted to me by a near and dear beer friend. Truly, friends are one of a beer geeks greatest assets. That being said, enough blathering, it is time to get to drinking.


She descended a deep dark brown with a furious head of brown thunderclouds hanging low and ominous upon my helpless person frozen in fear. As I hunker down for the long haul, she crackles across my glass with veritable lightning strikes of brown lace. Like all Bells beers, she is not filtered, so I make sure to further aggravate her person and gaze in lip-smacking delight as little chunky bits float suspended, dissolving slowly as they descend to the bottom of my glass. With no end in sight, her nose slaps me in the face, splitting a huge grin of delight from ear to ear. Prunes, prune juice, black licorice, figs, plums, black cherries, pineapple raw and spiky, and bakers chocolate ride atop a wave of graham crackers, pure cracked cacao beans, tobacco leaves which exude cigar humidor esters, and finally, tree bark, dry and earthy. Heavy and rich, I wilt under the weight, descending into her blackish brown depths where none have escaped. Immediately mouth-coating, she doesnt leave much lace, but instead a thin film of brown tears immediately coat my glass. Prunes, prune juice, figs, dates, and pitted black cherries lead into licorice root and tobacco leaves that linger long into the finish. Licking my lips, I revel in creamy milk chocolate, truffle powder, and brilliantly bitter bakers chocolate. As my palate slowly starts to dry, earth and bark keep me grounded as her watershed of exhilarating flavors threatens to sweep me away. If this is Hells Fury, then I have nothing to fear but fear itself. Each quaff layers on the brown tears while she sticks to the back of my throat with further tobacco leaf notes. I would love to pair this beer with a hearty, rich, and earthy cigar. A faint presence of spice lingers in my breath, a final kiss as I bid my Hell Hath No Fury good-bye.


I had no idea what to expect going into this beer, and everything was a pleasant surprise. While no one in their right mind would ever want to cross the wrong woman, I will gladly cross this one any day of the week. I lived through the storm once; I am sure I can weather another and another and another.

Some vanilla, smoke, yeast and even some light vegetable notes as well. It seems like there is a lot going on here, but its kind of muddled at the same time. An interesting mix of several traditional beer styles.

Good overall. When it poured it was much darker than I expected, almost as though it was a porter or a stout. And by no means is that a bad thing. The head is small, brown, and quick to dissipate. The taste is slightly of coffee and heavy on the roasted grains. I enjoyed this but Bells beers such as expedition stout are better.
bottle, thanks to ballewblake, dark brown color with coffee and cola aromas, flavors of licorice, caramel, vanilla smoothness, finish is lightly bitter

(12oz bottle thanks to ballewblake) Pours a dark chocolate brown with light tan head. Nose is coffee, beef jerky. Taste is smoky, dark cocoa. The mouthfeel is thick and velvety carbonation. The hops and milk chocolate finish round it out nicely. I actually had no clue this was a dubbel and reminded me more of a light bodied stout.

Bottle 12fl.oz. @ [ Tasting by cgarvieuk ].Clear dark red brown color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, chocolate, plum, caramel notes, wood notes. Flavor is moderate to lgiht heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a average to long duration, and a dry finish. Body is medium, texture is oily to creamy, carbonation is soft. [20090411]

Tastes deep with roasty, malty, and chocolatey goodness.  Again, light amounts of dark fruits and even some vanilla.  Dubbel?  Seems more like an old ale or even a porter.  Aye, a dilema of styles for sure!  Not that it matters; still a delicious treat.

Batch 8739 thanks to coyotehunter. Pours with a huge brown head over a murky brown body. Aroma of coffee, mocha, dark fruits, earthiness, and vanilla. Taste is roasty with raisins, yeast, currants and chocolate. Light bubbles, creamy mouthfeel.

Aromas are throw off some sweet malts, brown sugars with a touch of burnt and dark fruits, initial throws creamy sweetness, dark fruits and banana, light clove, some light belgian spice. Light banana bread appeal with chocolate, bitterness and a touch of coffee. Finishes bitter chocolate and coffee dominant. Interesting brew from Bells. Cheers.

Dark strong cafe aulait (almost stouty) aromas of warm coffee, steamed milk that moves to nutty maltiness.  The palate shifts to caramel and dark candi sugar.  Roasted nuttiness returns and dominates the finish as this strange beer ends on a sweet/ bitter finish.
Pours a dark brown with a tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, malts and nuts.  Flavor -mostly malts with chocolate, nuts, dark fruit and just a hint of malts.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of a trade with pnista.  Pours Very, very dark brown, nearly black with a thin-moderate tan head that lasted through the first three sips and left very little lace.  Mild aroma of malt, chocolate, and nuts.  The flavor is predominantly malt with just a bit of chocolate.  Cigar tobacco flavor emerges towards the finish and lingers briefly beyond the swallow.  Medium-full bodied.  An interesting beer, but I dont know if this is something I would drink with any regularity.
Pours black with a brown head. Aroma of coffee and light chocolate. Tastes much of the same with hints molasses. Hint of smoke in the finish. Weird.

In short: A nutty and caramelized Americanized dubbel.  Very enjoyable.
How: Bottle 12oz.  Many sources.  This bottle from MrChopin, thanks a lot Kevin
The look: Cloudy dark brown body topped by a medium tan had

As the beer warms up some dark fruits start coming through.  The medium carbonation and soft mouthfeel may not feel very Belgian but the flavours elements are very cohesive and spot-on.  This is a pleasant take on the style.  The mouthfeel may not feel really Belgian but I dont care when beers dont feel authentic as long as I enjoy them.  Same goes with breast.

Pours brown with a fizzy head.  Aroma of nuts and spices.  Middle of the road for Bells.  Not bad.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2009 12 oz bottle.  pours brown with a quickly receding tan head.  Im not a big girl/truck/ trailor song kind of guy- but who knows
12oz bottle. Pours very dark brown with very light head that seems to linger only around the edge of the glass. Flavor is caramel and coffee. This one feels very roasted. (16.99/6pk) Batch 8739

Bottle, batch 8739.  Pours a really dark mahogany brown with a glint of chestnut translucency at the outer edges.  The head is foamy and tan in color, receding quickly to a wispy film and leaving minimal spots behind.  The nose has alot going on, and shows more like a dubbel/porter hybrid than anything else, I would say.  Darkly roasted caramel and hints of smoky molasses are accompanied by notes of worn leather, tobacco, and earthen dark fruits.  Dark cocoa malts and hints of espresso beans bring in some of the aforementioned porter elements.  Flavors show more of the same, walking the tightrope between sweet and earthy dark fruits and choco-caramel roast.  The palate is smooth and substantial, hitting sweet peaks and dry valleys en route to an ultra-long, roasted finish.  Rating to style, this would not score well.  But I rate to my liking, and this is tasty stuff.

Bottle, batch #8739. A very dark brown to black color with a medium tan head. Aroma of roasted coffee,caramel,molasses,and a little doughy yeast. Very complex flavors of grain,chocolate caramel,coffee,cola,rasins,dates and maybe a hint of nuts, very earthy. A smooth rich palate medium carbonation,and a ever so slightly bitter finish. Very drinkable and very good.

dark brown with mild white head.  roasty and raisony. low carbonation for a belgian-style.  flavor of special b malt with dark candi sugar, a lot of residual sugar for a dubbel results in a rather full mouth feel and a syrupy finish.  the yeast is not well featured here, likely due to the lack of a dry finish.  not a well crafted belgian dubbel, unless this is a bad bottle

The caramel and malt dominance is nice this time of year but there is a bit of a balance with some light fruity hops.

Bottle from 5point liquor, Athens, GA.
Batch 8739.
Pours deep dark brown/black with a brown/mocha head.
Aroma chocolate, malty with light charcoal nose.
Taste, plenty of burnt malts, chocolate with a good load of dark fruits and sugary notes with underlying notes of grains and some light floral hops.
This is one damn amazing beer, I think it
gives a nice approach to an abbey dubbel as there is a strong emphasis on the malty and chocolate side.
Very dark with a decent head.  Chocolate nose with fudge and a light nuttiness.  Smooth, soft maltiness.  Light chocolate accent.  Light fruitiness.  Good mouthfeel.

Batch 7673 bottle poured murky brown with a small beige head. Aroma was chocolate, caramel, and a few yeasty notes. Flavor is much better than when it was fresh. Most of the belgiany notes are gone. Flavor is chocolaty and sweet with some vinous notes coming through in the finish.

Just a little age (its Feb 22 and this was brewed on Sept 22) has done it well.  The aroma is still an even balance of fruit and chocolate but the flavor is now primarily chocolate with a creamy palate.  It actually reminds me of a chocolate malt, like you would get at DQ.  The dark fruits are still there in the background, helping to balance and round out rather than confuse.  This is definitely not a standard abbey dubbel, so if thats what youre looking for steer clear.  However, i think it is a really good beer with a unique take on the style.

Maybe I had a bad bottle, but after drinking lots of amazing Belgian dubbels, Bells REALLY missed the mark on this one.

batch 7673.  black pour with a thin espresso head.  nose of cherries, roasted malts and coffee. great thickness with a nice flavor of coffee, chocolate and roasted malts.

Pours a dark cola brown with a nose of caramel, chocolate, coffee bitter, earth, yeast, and smoke.  Flavor is off-kilter: licorice, earth, coffee, some fruit, but a bitterness comes traipsing in. On tap, Ashleys in Ann Arbor.  Pours with nice aromatics, little white head.  Tastes boozy.
Bottle  batch 8739. Nearly black with a tan head. Big roasty, nutty aroma. Medium body. Rich, roasty malt flavors with some chocolate sweetness. Tasty brown ale.

batch 8739 bottle by way of moelikebeer.

pours dark plack with a nice mocha head and nice lacing.  aroma is mild but has notes of molasses.  nice flavor with hints of molasses or burnt toffee followed by anise and a touch smoke.  nice creamy mouthfeel.

Bottle from Once Upon a Vine - North on 10/18/2008. Batch 8739. Dark black body with ruby highlights and a medium creamy light brown head. Medium full body with moderate carbonation and a very creamy finish.

Bottle courtesy of moeliekbeer.

The roasted malts are smooth and subdued with a lingering sweetness. The body is full and creamy. Very stout like for a Belgian. Another impressive one from Bells.

A deep dark brown ale with a thin moka head.  In aroma, a rather nice aroma of plum and brown sugar. In mouth, defintely Belgian with dark chocolate, and Brett and vinous notes. Rich and complex, with those nice Brett. On tap at RFD, Jan. 6 2009.

Bottle. Pours a deep black with a small tan head. Rich almost sour aroma, of malt, bitter chocolate and under-ripe fruit. Taste is quite sweet, of malt, chocolate, and dark fruits. Lingering sweetness. Kind of strange and decent.

Personnally I thought this was great because it was not a standard dubbel, which I am not a fan of any of the Belgian styles really other than the quad.  Thought this was great on its own, but absolutely bad if you were looking for a crappy belgian.  Unique and worth trying, if you know what to expect.
I bet a barrel aged version of this could be interesting.

The mouthfeel is creamy, well balanced and finishes with a sticky dryness. Bells has some unique brews and is well worth seeking out.

Pours a deep rich brown with good rosy brown head.  Aroma is malty carmel sweetness with belgian yeast and a little toasty.  Flavor is sweet, anise, raisin, molassis, brown sugar, and some alcohol. Body is Medium with a slight creaminess, I wish it had been even creamier and fuller bodied. A bit of chocolate and abv warming on the finish.  It gets even better as it warms

Pours a way darker ruby than i would have expected... next to no head... coffee, roasty almost burnt malt aroma... The touch of smoke is definitely there... a bit of chocolate, bit of coffee... Im a bit confused now as to what actually classifies as an abbey dubbel... The last two i had were this and smuttynose winter ale, and neither would qualify as a traditional belgian abbey dubbel in my opinion... In this as well as the smutty, i dont get any of the traditional belgian flavor...
Smokey, dry, bitter coffee flavor. Thick but relatively easy to drink. Slightly tinny. Nice looking black beer with tan head.Nice beer for the wintertime. This was a gift from my father in law.

330ml bottle from Steve for Christmas
The aroma is strong malts and spicy yeast
Pours a dark brown with a huge tan long lasting head
The taste is malty with a touch of coffee and chocolate there is also a touch of smoke in there as well 
My first Bells beer and it did not disappoint

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of spices, cloves, light chocolate, roasted malts, leather, slight smoke, hops, resin, and yeast.  Poured black in color with a medium-sized dense, rocky, brown head that lasted throughout.  Opaque.  Sparkling.  Many large particles throughout.  Flavor is complex, lightly bitter, and slightly sweet.  Tastes of malts, yeast, chocolate, tar, roasting, slight coffee, light toffee, slight tobacco, slight smoke, hops, wood, and some resin.  Medium to full body.  Creamy, lightly sticky texture.  Average carbonation.  Roasted malt, chocolate, tar, and tobacco finish is a bit sticky.

Bottle.  Poured dark brown, with tan head.  Aroma is roasted malt, with some yeast and light hop.  Taste is also very roasted, with coffee and chocolate coming through.  Hop bitterness lightly in the finish.  Mouth is smooth and creamy, with a light alcohol dryness.  Nice beer, that is very unique.

Bottle into chalice. Pours a dark brown, reddish brown with the light peeking through around the edges, nice khaki head. Nose is a bit roasty, with a bit of yeast around the edges. Taste is roasty, with hints of dark brown sugar and dark fruits, nice and dry. yeast comes on more towards the finish, but the roastiness never really goes away - leaves just a bit of acidity with the dry, slightly roasty finish. Mouthfeel is smooth but still just a bit sharp, medium bodied. Really fascinating beer - delicious.

Pours dark, dark brown with a nice bubbly tan head. The aroma is pretty roasty and not really what I expect from a dubbel. Underneath the strong roasty aspects is some light chocolate and dark fruit sweetness as well as some spicy yeast. Flavors of dark roast, dark fruit, and nice estery spicy yeast. Some long lingering roast in this one. Smooth, creamy. I also though it had a lot of Bells stout base. Very interesting and nice.

Pours very dark brown with tan head. Chocolate, coffee, yeasty aroma. Taste is roasted malt, fruit, molasses, and smoke, ending with some hoppiness. Creamy mouthfeel. Very good. As afireinside noted below, has a lot of character from Bells stouts in it. This is all to the good.
12oz bottle, Batch #8739. Pours black in color with dark brown head. Aroma coffee, roasted malt, fruity and chocolate. Taste of coffee, roasted malt and dark chocolate with bitter finish.

Bottle served in a Duvel tulip. Poured a very dark brown with a half inch of tan head. Smells like dark chocolate, coffee, and biscuit. This is a Dubbel? Taste is chocolate, dark fruit, coffee, and earth. Wow, what an interesting take on the style. Has a thick creamy mouthfeel but is not cloying in the least. Carbonation is minimal but somehow excusable in this case. This stuff is delicious. It almost feels like Bells brewed up a Dubbel and blended it with a batch of Kalamazoo Stout. Interesting, unique, and most importantly, very tasty.

Bottle via trade.  It is definitely a different style of dubbel, but that is not bad. Pours a super dark brown colour with a chocolate milk head.  Aroma is bittersweet chocolate, coffee and toasted malt.  Very balanced flavour that one second is dark malt and the next a touch of hops.  Original but also shows a Belgian background.  I think I liked it better with every taste.

Pours a thick black from the bottle with a tint of ruby and a trim brown head.  Smells of smoked wood chips and oatmeal.  Tastes of rich molasses, mild hops, and faint smoke.  Heavy and earthy with a fair amount of sediment.  Great cold, but this one definitely bitters as it warms.

Draught at RFD, DC. Pours black with hints of red and a thin tan head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, and belgian yeast. Flavor has a lot of belgian funk, dark fruit, and something a bit like I imagine a barnyard would taste. Good mouthfeel. Decent brew.

Bottle in trade from bobby91w. Thanks! 

Pours a dark brown color with a light tan head. Smell is tobacco, smoky bubble gum, belgian yeast and dark fruity. Taste is gummy, dark fruit, lightly hopped and with belgian yeast and a dubbel like flavor overall with a rich tobacco like smokiness to it. Nice body and moderate carbonation. Very good for a style that isn’t one of my preferred.

Pours a very deep dark brown, topped with a smattering of brown foam that really turns out to be just a ring. Okay lacing. Dry chocolate malt in the aroma, but not a whole lot of it. A little maple in there too, though you really have to look for it. Sweetish beer, with chocolate malt, some peat, and then some dry roasted grain. Finish is also on the sweet side, with a chocolate-covered raisin presence. Medium to full body, mild carbonation.

A smoked belgian-style ale.  Odd, but tasty.  Aroma is smoke and toasted malts.  Pours a deep opaque brown, with a generous beige head that leaves a nice lacing.  On the tongue, smoke and bubblegum dominate, and are oddly balanced. Roast malts, citric hops, brown sugar, and general fruitiness also present.  Thick bodied, creamy on the palate.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2009 Bottle from jgd0608, thanks man!  Poured a deep brown color with a moderate, fluffy beige head that fades to a thin layer.  Aroma of chocolate, roasted malts, and a light fruitiness.  Smooth, moderately sweet entry with some bakers chocolate, some light roasted malts, some light molasses and a hint of smoke with undertones of light fruit.  Finishes lightly dry with a moderate yeastiness.  Low carbonation, smooth on the palate.  Definitely a different beer, but a Dubbel?  Still a beer I wouldnt mind having a couple of around.
Very interesting beer.  In a good way.  Black in color.  Aroma of Roasted malts and banana.  Complex flavor with hints of coffee and banana.  Creamy texture.  Very good beer.

Another brew provided by CrellMoset poured into a snifter.

Pours dark, dark brown with only the slightest amount of light passing through the edges. An aggressive pour produced a one-inch thick mocha head that dissipated to a small ring immediately leaving very little lacing.

The smoke is most distinctive part of the aroma as it is present throughout. There are also some dark roasted malts and chocolate with some sugary sweetness and dark fruits on top. All of this is underpinned by hints of yeast in the nose.

The taste starts out much sweeter than the aroma indicates with lots of candi sugar and dark fruits. The are generous sweeter dark malts and sweet chocolate in the middle. The smoke comes back in the finish and lingers on the palate between sips along with a hints of spices.

The mouthfeel is smooth with decent carbonation and has a dry, smoky feel in the finish.

This is one very interesting beer with the Belgian base and tons of malts and smoke on top. I really enjoyed it and think it’s one of the more unique beers I’ve had in a while.

This beer pours a deep amber brown with a thick brown head. The aroma is medium sweet with plum, raisin, anise and chocolate as well as a nice yeasty component. The flavor is initially fruity but more spicy towards the finish. Thick bodied, full mouthfeel. Finishes nicely sweet (chocolate and licorice) and somewhat long.

Pours a very dark stout brown to black, no daylight with a dense enough tan head.  The nose is fruity with little sweetness and a good bit of roast.  A bit of spice, maybe ginger and nutmeg with a touch of cinnamon.  Creamy enough mouthfeel, though nothing life changing.  Low carbonation, but not close to too low.  The flavors are in line with the flavor.  Not a knock out, but not bad either.  Very quaffable for the ABV.  Not too creamy, not too sweet, a bit fruity and dry with some solid roast, again that ginger.  This bears more than a passing resemblance to Anchor Our Special Ale.  Perhaps slightly sweeter with more of a lingering roast.  Better than I remember

12 oz bottle in pint glass. Opaque brown with billowing 2-3 finger long lasting head. Excellent lacing on glass. There are a lot of flavors going on here! Dark roasted malt, chocolate, and toffee followed by coffee and licorice. Very thick on the mouthfeel with little carbonation. This is obviously very well crafted; however, I’m not a big fan of licorice. For those who are this is definitely worth a try.

And Bells does it again, always making good brews.  Dark brown pour with a thin tan head.  Aroma is a Belgian malt character of dark fruits.  Flavor is the same of raisins, caramel, chocolate and plums.  Palate is creamy, sticky, slightly sweet.

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2008 12oz bottle. Pours dark brown with a small brown head. Moderate carbonation. Aroma is of toasty malt, candi sugars, yeast, & dark fruit. Taste starts of with a bitter hop bite, followed by sharp toasted malt, notes of yeast, raisins, caramel, and coffee. All these flavors are soaked within a very big breadiness. Very creamy and sticky mouthfeel. A tasty beer, but not very drinkable.

Bottle: pours a very dark reddish brown with just a thin ring of tan head around the rim of the goblet, aroma of chocolate, yeast, sweet dark fruits, taste is chocolate, dark fruits, not overly sweet which is nice, has a medium full mouthfeel, finishes smooth. I like this one quite a bit. Another great beer from Bell’s.

Based on the description, I expected a somewhat light beer.  Boy, when I poured it, I was surprised.  Dark, with a tan head.  Aromas of dried fruits and sweet roasted malts. Flavor is fruits, with a dose of chocolate. Another success from Bells.

I hate to gush but what an amazing beer!  Rich, smoky deep flavors that keep going and going.  Plenty of everything including a gorgeous brown head, sweet malt, medium hopped, and carbonated slightly more than average.

The only negative is the price! $15.99+TAX per six pack at my local liquor store.

Thanks to Honkeybra for this brew.  Nice pour, whatever the hell kinda beer this is.  Smokey, roasty chocolate is what Im getting out of this one.  Pretty intense actually.  Not quite sure what to make of it.
Very dark pour with a small head.  Aroma is heavy, cloying.  Dark molasses notes with dark fruits.  Taste matches aroma with a hint of bittering hops in the end.

Bottle.  Poured a dark, murky brown with a two finger tan head.  Aroma of spice, honey, dark fruit and maybe even some chocolate.  Flavor was a solid representation of the aroma, with a definate molasses/honey note.  Very good beer.

bottle from strykzone, thanks man!! Very dark brown pour with a great tan head.  Aroma is amazing...all over the place.  Spices, honey, figs, raisins, molasses, cocoa and more.  Flavors are melded pretty well together.  Dark fruits, spices, some honey and molasses.  I like it very much!!

Batch# 8739:  Pours dark brown with a fairly long lasting light brown head.  Not an overpowering aroma but I could pick up some flowers, yeast, fig and other various spices.  Medium-body, initial taste of deep roasted malt, some coffee and ripe fruits.  FInishes bittersweet, kind of a black licorice taste with a slight warming feeling.  Like countless others have said this is very complex and its hard to tell what taste Bells was going for.  Not bad though and certainly worth a try.

Bottle #8739.  Pours a very dark brown color with red hints.  Medium sized brown head with good lacing.  Very mild aroma of molassas.  Tastes of chocolate, molassas, fruit, and coffee.  Dry finish.  Weird mixture of sweet and bitter.  Read a number of the previous posts.  Glad to see that others agree that his is one strange beer.  All sorts of flavors mixed together.  Been wanting to try this for awhile and Im glad I picked up this 6 pack, but Im not in love with it.  Its like all the complexity gets mushed together and what is left is a hard to define.  I’ve drank two now.  Hopefully Maybe I’ll learn something new when drinking the last four.

First off, is this really an abbey dubel? Huh? Pours a deep brown with a creamy light brown head. Aroma is very smokey and malty with some pronounced oatmeal and dark roasted barley. Some leather and very earthy. I didn’t really get any fruitiness, maybe some raisin, maybe. Flavor is very sweet malty. Some of the smokiness carries into the flavor. Lots of baked biscuit or cookie flavors. Has a bit of a spice kick towards the finish that is abbey dubel-esque. Finishes very sweet and doesn’t really linger. Medium-full body and low-average carbonation. Not a bad beer but just very strange. Tastes like this beer is fresh from the oven!!!

Pours a very dark brown (complete with suspended yeast), with a lacing, tan head.  Sweet aroma of freshly ground coffee definitely doesn’t scream Belgian Dubbel to me, but nevertheless is excellent.  Big mouthfeel, lots of roasted goodness here, brown sugar, coffee, bread, its all in there.  Great finish...  the worst part is when its all gone!  One of the best I’ve had in a while!

As a dubbel, this beer is puzzling.  As a beer, it’s pretty damned good!  It doesn’t meet some of what I’d expect from a dubbel, but has other nice aspects that most dubbels lack.  So, I’ll judge it as it is.  Nose is really quite nice.  Sweet and rich, with strong notes of chocolate and a hint of  maple syrup.  Flavors are brown sugar, spice and dark fruits, with a nice carbonation.  

If considered as a dubbel, this beer might perplex.  And I’m willing to bet that its ratings have suffered for such a label.  But it is quite good, and one I’ll likely seek out again.

Strangest tasting beer I have had from Bells.  This does not taste much like a Abbey Dubbel to me.  The aftertaste is actually much better than the beer itself.  I might have drank this one at a temperature that was too low to bring out the complexity of the brew.  A mildly smokey flavor.  It definitely has some cherry fig and prune undertones.  The first sip of this beer was not pleasant but by the end it developed into a interesting mashup.  Pours way to dark for a Abbey Dubbel with a small medium tan head.  Carbonation is minimal and kind of flat.

Found this one bottled at Binny’s in St. Charles.  Very thick, oily dark brown pour with a thick tan head.  Spicy and fruity nose, with some apricot, raisin, allspice, walnut and toasted malt.  The flavor is complex as I expect a dubbel to be. Finish is strong, alcoholic, and spicy.  Another impressive brew by Bells, and welcome back to Illinois!

Tap @ Hopleaf. Poured dark, which was unexpected. Nice bubbly like brown head. Aroma of barley, malt, spice,  maple, and sugar. Flavor sugary at the start, roasty, chocolately. Hints of barley, nice malty backbone. Fruity (raisens and figs). Medium bodied. Carbonation was solid, as it tingled my tongue every so often. Easy to drink. Nice alcohol warming

From bottle.  Part of October Dayton beertasting event.  Pours dark brown with light brown head.  Aromas include caramel and sweet malt.  Tastes include smoke, chocolate and espresso.  More like a smoked porter...

I would say this beer is best described as a mind fuck It’s label says it’s a dubbel, but it looks kinda like a stout. The flavor is sweet and subtle kinda like a heffet. I don’t know, maybe I haven’t had enough dubbel’s. Despite all this, I really like this beer. It’s definitely the most perplexing beer I’ve ever had, but what can you expect from a brewer that has a place called the Eccentric Cafe. Cheers!

12oz  bottle, pours a really dark brown, close to black... has a tan head that dissipates quickly.  Flavors of chocolate, malt, coffee, cinnamon and smoke.  Starts a touch sweet and finishes dry.  Relatively low carbonation, which is good for this style.  This is a good beer, but the Belgian dubbels (e.g. Westmalle, Chimay Rouge) are far superior.  At $15 per 6, it’s also a bit expensive.

Woopty Woop! Great name, great beer. Pours a thick muddy dark brownish black colour with no head. Lacing left behind is sticky, resinous and turns crusty within a couple minutes of emptying the glass. Aroma is of smoke, oak, black licorice, coffee beans and earth. Taste is full, sweet, thick on the palate- again dark fruits and bbq, coffee notes and caramel. I only drank half of it before i accidentally kicked it all over the living room floor.

Living is Wisconsin, there’s no shame in me calling Michigan my favorite state when it comes to beers.  Bells may very well be on top of that Michigan list and Hell indeed has some fury.  Thick brown to black in color with a beige head that slowly fades away as I wait for this to warm just a touch.  Aroma is Dubbel all the way with fruit, raison, nuts, brown sugar and toasted malt.  Complex is the cliché, and complex it is.  The taste is solid with brown sugar, fruit, nuts and spice.  Sweet, but not too sweet, just another in the long line of quality beers from Kalamazoo.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2009 Bottle.  Aroma of yeast, candy sugar, bread, banana, raisins.  Black in the glass with an average sized light tan head that mostly diminished and left some lace.  Flavor is sweet and malty with yeasty musk on the short finish.  Palate has a watery light-medium body with some soft-lively carbonation.  Not bad for a Eurotrash style.

Bottle. Dark colored like a porter, with a somewhat bubbly espresso colored head. Flavor is bready malts, candy sugar, some yeastiness, banana, raisins, ripe fruit. Finish is initially sweet but develops into an extended dryness. Lingering dry hop bitterness. Some notes of alcohol also present. Medium bodied. Low carbonation. Yum.

Pours a dark, thick coffee with dark tan head. Aroma is largely malts, nuts and vanilla extract. Flavor is malts the bitterness of coffee without strong coffee notes. Flavor is definite roasted malts with hints of vanilla. Flavor has an interesting smokiness to it that mixes with alcohol. Body is creamy with medium carbonation.

Interesting beer.  Pours dark brown with a brownish-tan head, nose incorporates carmel and smokey malt, flavors of smoked malt with coffee and cacoa, finishes bitter with more smoke.  I don’t know if I’d label this a dubbel, it’s close but it drinks more like a lighter stout or porter.

12oz bottle courtesy of Gurst.  Pours a deep brown with a big but fleeting tan head.  Aroma is sweet and full, with hints of dark fruit, chocolate, brown sugar, and a slight bit of syrupy hops.  Taste is full and smooth, with an initially sweet flavor of chocolate, brown sugar, and coffee giving way to a crisper finish of roasted malt, warming alcohol, anise, and spices.  As much stout as dubbel with lovely results.

A definite anise-like aroma that reveals hints of toasted pecan and apple. Appearance is like that of cola with a deep tan head that quickly dissipates.
A remarkable flavor best likened to that of the acidity of cold press but with rich, savory, and smokey notes finishing into a thin minerality. Certainly a departure from the usual Dubbels, lacking the characteristic butterscotch-sweetness and light carbonation.
Hell Hath No Fury has a dense and complex flavor - match it with an equally complex cheese, maybe Grayson or Selles sur Chere.

Black with big, foamy brown head / Big, rich, dark fruit and caramel nose / Full, chewy, body with nice balance of big malts and hops, and very good finish / Flavors of raisins, figs, caramel, ripe apples (thanks Jokes!), chocolate, roast coffee, vanilla, and oak / A spectacular, if non traditional dubbel.

Bottle.  Hazy brown body with a thin, quickly diminishing tan head. The aroma is fruity and sweet with only a faint undertone of hoppy bitterness. Plums, raisins, brown sugar, ripe apples, whole-grain bread, fruity esters and a bit of cocoa. The body is full and smooth, with an elegant velvet sweep across the tongue. Starting sweet, the flavor shows malty depth all the way through. Sweet up front and transitioning into a nice, mild roasted malt finish. The alcohol is mostly imperceptible, but does lend a bit of licorice and a pleasing warmth. A different, but enjoyable, beer. Another good option from Kalamazoo.
bottle. pours almost black with a thin tan head. has a strong chocolate and coffee flavor. tasted more like a stout than an ale.

(bottle) Pours dark brown with a tan head.  The aroma is more like a weizenbock than an abbey dubbel, with a lot of chocolate, clove, and dark fruits.  Banana lurks underneath as well.  There’s also this light tart scent which I believe is wheat, and further leads me to believe this is a weizenbock.  This sometimes lends a lemon-like component to the aroma.  The taste is quite nice, a lot of dark fruit, candi sugar, banana, and chocolate. There’s a slight roast component here too.  The finish is lightly yeasty with that tartness in the aroma now showing up in the finish to give it a crisp ending.  Really quite drinkable.

12 oz bottle.  Pours extremely dark brown with a thin tan head.  Dark malty aroma with nuts, cherries, chocolate, dark fruits.  Flavors of nuts and anise, chocolate, smoke, cloves.  Finish is smoky and nutty.  Not sure how this fits into the definition of a dubbel, but hey, the flavor’s really quite tasty and unique.

A little underrated, this one was quite tasty. Pours a nice, deep purple, with a red hue. Minimal, but nice, lacing. Aroma is awesome, yeast, candy sugar, clove, and dark fruits. Flavor was quite the same, lots of yeast, with strong candy sugar and fruits. Nice touches of clove and spice. Maybe a dash of bannana and chocolate. Also noticed some barley notes. Very thick, with a creamy mouthfeel that never became overly sticky. Almost like biting into fruitbread. Delicious.

$13.99 a sixer and looks almost as dark as Expedition Stout and with a similar minimal brown head. I’m not sure I’ve ever had an abbey dubbel but I certainly enjoy this one. Feels luxurious in the mouth and tastes, as others have described it, as a bit roasted and spicy. There’s a lot of nuance here but I can’t see myself spending $13.99 for a sixer of this again (maybe when I’m rich--that’ll be the day).

Poured a brown color much darker than i expected with a nice off white head. Aroma was really sweet, some candy sugar, lots of roasted notes, and some spices. Flavor was much more complex than most dubbels. It was the nice sweetness of a dubbel, with the spices too, but also with a nice roasted nutty flavor. YUM!

Ah, it’s great that Bells is back in Chicago. This is the first new Bells that I have had since it has been reintroduced to our fair city. I was pleasantly surprised to find a new six pack that I haven’t had at my local liquor store. Had no idea about the beer. Quite surprised that it poured so dark out of the bottle. Minimum head: tan and chunky. Dark fruit, plum, chocolate, toffee nose. Very chewy, fruit, chocolate, bitter, sour, cherry flavors. A nice beer from Bells and well appreciated in Chicago.

Pours dark brown with a thin tan head.  I had no idea what type of beer I was getting into when I bought this 6 pack.  Aroma of yeast, molasses, some dark fruit.  A very interesting Abbey Dubbel.  Will enjoy the other bottles.

I wish that breweries would state the style of beer on the package.  I like Bells and all, but $14.99 for a six-pack of mystery beer?  As it turns out, I really like dubbels.  This is one is really nice and malty with that bready Belgian yeastiness that makes its distiction.  Im not sure I get the marketing though.

When I poured it, I immediately knew I shouldn’t have put a bottle in the fridge. Aroma is almonds, other nuts, molasses, fruit, maybe some tobacco. Flavor is sweet, with caramel, and some roaster burnt malt. The other reviews talk about this being an interesting take on the style, and I feel this is of note because I’m not sure I’d recognize this as a dubbel than just a strong, dark Belgian.

Pours thick dark, almost black, color with a thin tan head. Overall a smoky aroma, with dried fruits and molasses. Impressive array of flavors, including chocolate, dried fruit, molasses, coffee and smoky wood. Unique, but excellent interpretation of the style, another must try from Bells.

Pours a rich ruby color with thick frothy light brown head. Aroma is of intense smoke, molasses, brown sugar, light smoke and yeast.   Taste is of molasses, notes of dark fruit and carmelized sugars, and light chocolate. Light carbonation and a finish that hits you strong then fades away very quickly. A very interesting interpretation.

aroma of esters, funk and yeast. cascading pour is dark even for a dubbel but not black, still orange around the edges.  hops are sharp and upfront but very balanced overall.  less emphasis on dark fruits and more on dark sweetness: brown sugar, molasses.  still very fruity, a great example and spin on the style.

Bottle.  Poured dark, dark brown with red highlights. Damn, this is powerful stuff! Aroma of tobacco, malt and dark dried fruits.  Flavor has coffee and bakers’ chocolate in addition to figs and raisins.  Not a lot of sweetness at all, and a very dry finish.  Very little carbonation and a relatively light mouthfeel.  Overall, an enigmatic, enjoyable beer.

Dark reddish brown, creamy tan head.  Aromas of soft fig and brown sugar warm to hints of raisin and smoke.  Dried dark fruit flavor rides a light chocolate earth bitterness from beginning to end.  Medium bodied, soft carbonation, bittersweet finish.  Good stuff...

Looked at the bottle head and its even darker than last year.  Poured it out and man just impressive.  Not to sound nuts but in the light its a deep blood red.  A bit smokey with a coffee hint, but a smooth finish.  How the hell do they do that.  Very pleasant to the palate.

bottle dumps dark with reddish hints when held to light. tan disappearing head. aroma decaying fruit and smoke. tastes delicious very complex not enough characters allowed to describe sufficiently. quite different. quiet nice. another great bells beer.

Bottle pours black with a small tan head, no lace.  The aroma is dried plums, chocolate, and good coffee.  The flavor is sweet malt, dark fruits, molasses, milk chocolate, yeast, wood, vanilla, and some coffee in the linger.  The palate is lively - in a micro bubble sort of way, and smooth and rich.  Overall, this is a nice surprise.  I like it.

Pours an opaque black/brown with a thin creamy brown froth.  Aroma of roast and sweet cream.   Chalky mouthful, medium/full body with smooth carbonation.   Roast and chocolate, maybe some oatmeal, dark fruits, lightly nutty.  Finishes slightly smokey.    Long lasting coffee dry bitterness.   Reminds me of a dark-chocolate covered chocolate girl-scout cookie.  A little too weird for me, its either the alcohol or yeast that really throws it off.

Almost black with light red and a tan head than lasts only a minute or so.  A musty aroma with yeast and dark fruit.  Flavor has some bite to it.  Strong espresso, smoke, candi sugar, wood, yeast, dark fruit and alcohol.  All these combine to grab the taste buds with an initial zing that fades a bit in the mouth.  Taste gets a bit musty as it warms.  So complex and well crafted it provides layers of stimulation for the tongue.

The Dark rich creamy pour is surprisingly and pleasently lively on the palate.  Aromas of Coffee, bittersweet chocolate and roasted nuts, effortlessly carries to the palate with a pleasing effervesence.  The finish is smooth and clean.  With Milk chocolate notes and some coffee. Better than I expected!  Thanks Bells!

Thanks to Dkachur for this bottle! Batch 8739 (bottled 9/22/08). Dark brown pour with chestnut colored head and thick drippy lace. Dark fruit and roasty aroma.  Complex flavors; smoke, dark fruits, candy sugar, oak, and coffee.

Bottle.  Very dark, brown pour with a medium size tan head.  Smoky aroma with notes of roasted malt and brown sugar.  Flavor of roasted malt, dark chocolate and a little dark fruit.  Dry finish.  Smooth mouthfeel.  Very good beer!

Poured into about a half-pint snifter very dark with a solid light brown head.  Smelled of a rich mix of smoked coffee, chocolate, hops.  The flavor was strong yet not overpowering.  It was a good mix of flavors with the hint of smokiness making for a really good finish.  Despite its medium to even heavy body, this was a pretty drinkable brew, although a definite sipper.  Another great brew from Bells!
Pours a pitch black with a small ring of mocha head.  Aroma is toffee, coffee, candied sugar, and a smoky fire pit.  Taste is oak chips, coffee, and smoke.  An interesting brew.

Very dark brown opaque pour with a tan head.  Smoky roast aroma with hints of chocolate, coffee, and clove.  Some fruitiness as well.  Smoky flavor with bitter roasted malt and coffee.  This is an odd one.

12 oz bottle, pours dark as a stout.  Aroma not like any Belgian style I’ve ever smelled.  Smells of burnt coffee, and not much else.  Taste of coffee also.  Basically is a lighter-bodied coffee stout, not an abbey dubbel at all.  Just OK.

Draft:  Poured at the Trion Tavern, ridiculously dark brown/black with a medium-sized tan head.  Not much of a nose on this, very faint hints of candied sugar, belgian yeast and sweet dark malts...now the flavor though is something to behold.  Very rich and creamy palate, the taste consists of raisins, figs, candied sugar and sweet bready malts...the belgian yeast notes help to make it somewhat familiar to the style.  Quite good.

Sampled at Blacklick tasting 10/2/08:  Kind of an oddball here.  Very dark pour characteristic of a dubbel, maybe a bit darker.  Sticky caramel ring of head, even on plasic cup.  Aroma is raisin and prunes.  Little bit of alcohol in the nose.  Creamy roasted maltiness with the underlying Belgian yeast we’re familiar with.  Finishes with just a tinge of stale cardboard.  Interesting, but not my style.
user_location: I F&ckin hate those guys from, Ohio, USA

text: [Bottle] Pours a clear dark brown with a medium tan head. Aroma is lots of clove, a touch of wheat, and smells a little burnt and toasted like old coffee. Moderately thin mouthfeel. Toasted flavor comes through moderately strong, clove, coffee, and leaves with a dryish, moderately bitter finish. Seems a little more like a mild stout than the yeasty, fruity dubbels that I’m used to.

This pours a very, very dark brown, pretty much black in color.  I see it’s listed as a Dubbel, but I ain’t ever seen no dubbel this dark.  Smell is a bit of smoky, roasty malts.  Only a hint of the typical belgian yeast characteristic is there.  Really difficult to put my finger on this one.  You get a lot more of the Dubbel flavors, characteristics in the taste.  Mouthfeel is a bit bigger as well.  This is entirely different than anything I have ever had, and I kind of like it.  
There is a bit of dark fruit, raisin flavors.  Also a bit of a cola flavor as well.  Decent, full mouthfeel.  Decent beer.

On the dark side of what I would expect from a dubbel.   Pretty full aroma of roasted caramel, malt.  A hint chocolate is there as well.  Flavor is really smooth (thank you bottle conditioning).  There is a rich brown sugar, yeast and caramel flavor to this one.  Palate is extremely smooth up front, rich and robust, then ends with a slight bitterness.  Another excellent beer from our friends at Bells.
Pours dark with brown head and has a sweet chocolate flavor ending with a more robust dark coffee ending. Delicious Dubbel!
12oz. pours black with tan head. aroma is bitter sweet chocolate, coffee, and dried fruit. Mouthful is rich and full flavor with cocoa, coffee, molasses. very intense brew. nice.

2 year old bottle. Dark black with a thin beige head. Smells of molasses, chocolate, coffee, raisins, grapes, and dates. Strong, potent flavor with lots of cocoa, espresso, figs, plums, molasses, soy sauce, and vinegar. Aging nicely, actually better than I expected, and I bet it could go for a few more years..

Beautiful beer. Pours almost black.  Smells fruity and slightly of monk basement.  Tastes are many here:  chocolate, coffee, fruit, licorice and dirt finish.  I like it.  I think it’s a decent example of the style.

12 oz. bottle from Whole Foods Charlottesville, batch 8738. Dark brown color with a small head. Fruity aroma with some brown-sugar like malti notes along with maybe some candi sugar? Very dark taste with brown sugar, molasses, coffee, roasted grain. Full bodied.
Pours dark brown with light brown head.  Appearance is a bit deceiving, as flavor is fruity with cloves coming through as well as some coffee notes.
Very fruity and malty - both flavor and aroma.  Quite dark pour and minimal head.  Maybe a little too fruity for my taste but overall interesting and decent brew.

12 oz bottle from pineypower, thanks Dean, I hope I wasn’t supposed to save this one for us to drink together. Pours a solid black with deep reddish brown edges and a super quickly disipating bubbly beige head and some visible floaties that settled to the bottom of my Ommegang chalice. Slight metalic background with lots of dark fruit (plumb, fig, raisin), yeast, brown bread, bitter chocolate and molasses. Full bodied, light carbonation and a syrupy oily feel as you swallow, fantastic!! Flavor is very roasty with notes of dark fruits, brown bread and some bitter sweet notes as if some one dipped a slightly rotting strawberry in bakers chocolate. Once again Bells does not disappoint but come on an Abbey Dubbel, more like an Abbey Stout.

Bottle courtesy of BOLTZ7555.  Pours an opaque black with minimal head.  Nose is really mild with hints of dark fruits and malt.  Taste is mellow also with figs, roasted malts and burnt toffee with a slight hop finish.  Mouth feel is on the thin side.  Interesting beer  thanks Jason!
UPDATED: MAR 26, 2009 Nice Bottle Art.  Dark brown, and dark fruit. Plums and smoked flavor and some chocolate.  Nice caramel and creamy coffee body with a nice etoh warming.  Good offering.

Really enjoyed this...well crafted and extremely tasty.  This beer pours a dark mahogany with a ring for a head but leaves a bit of spotty lacing.  Aroma and flavor are dark fruit, molasses, and a hint of belgian chocolate.  Small yeasty bits floated throughout but were only visible when nearing the edge of the glass due to its dark color.  Yum...have loved everything from this brewery!!!
Drank at the Eccentric Cafe, 2007.  Nice Belgian Dubbel.  Taste of raisins and dark fruits.
On tap at Bells in Kalamazoo.  Great for a dubbel.  Not my favorite style.  Good maltiness and then alcahol.  Reminds me of a nice trappist style with a harsher finish
Had on tap at Brews Cafe. Pour was very dark, greenish brown, light tan head. Aroma of roasted malts. Flavor was sweet bread and carmel. With some light bitterness on the finish. This was very tasty!

dark dark brown, thin tan head.  aroma of malt, yeast, bread.  flavors are a mix of creamy caramel, sweet malt, chocolate, and even some coffee.  medium bodied.  a bit too mellow for me (give me a big hop kick in the side of the head), but it still remains a nice smooth brew. thanks to <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=1 

rayboy01 for this sample

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2008 Re-rate.  8739.  12oz.  Pours pretty dark brown/black, certainly Porter territory with a small, off-white head with poor retention.  The darkest of the style I have seen thus far.  Aroma is plum, chocolate, spicy, burnt sugar, slight popcorn.  The popcorn component is not buttery or diacetyl related, it is more like a burnt popcorn when you leave it in the microwave too long.  Interesting aroma overall, pretty roasty/chocolatey for the style but some estery fruity notes are definitely hidden underneath.  The taste is winey, fruity with a slick, smooth, thick mouthfeel.  Quick finish, quite slippery this one feels on the tongue.  This is like a good marriage of stout and Dubbel.  Super smooth and creamy.  I like this beer more than most people.
Bottle thanks to a trade. Shared with fordest and stefanje. I liked this one a lot. Some fruit like raisins, plums were present for me. Also some smoke.

12 oz bottle I have been wanting to try for a long time.  Thanks to Padrefan98 for making this available at a mini tasting between him, me, and stefanje.   Dark brown pour with just a bit of head.  Aromas were a bit subtle, but there was some dried fruit, some molasses, and caramel.  More intense but similar flavors with a smoky finish.  Pretty dang tasty.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2008 Courtesy of padrefan98. 12 oz bottle shared with fordest and padrefan. Poured an opaque dark brown with a big sudsy khaki head that lasted only a short while. The aroma was light with roasted malts and a bit of cola. The flavor mirrored the aroma with the dark roasted grains dominating and at times a smoky character showed through. The mouthfeel was full, smooth and satisfying. The finish was long with lingering roasted/burnt toast flavors. Overall: A very unusual dubbel, and a very enjoyable one. Recommended.

Dec. 2006 - Another fine Bells offering! Pour was dark brown with ruby highlights, smallish head, little lacing. The aroma was spices and fruits. The flavor was a nice balance of dark fruits, strong spices and a strong yeastiness. Developed a nice complexity as it warmed. Very enjoyable!
My favorite Bells brew. I love it, I nearly lived in the cafe when it came back for a few weeks earlier this winter.

Bottle courtesy of hopscotch. The pour reveals a murky dark brown color with a thin light brown head. Very nice aroma of chocolate, caramel and smoked malt. The flavor is very good, a good dose of smoked malt accompanies chocolate and caramel, theres mild bitterness in the end. The body has a light to medium thickness with a liquorous texture and gentle carbonation. This is a the border of scotch ales and dubbels and its very enjoyable, thanks Eric!

The color was dark brown.  The head was medium tan, fizzy, and laced some.  The aroma was malty and some spice.  The flavor was alcohol, age, yeast, and some spice.  The palate was carbronated and smooth.  The finish was warm.

Thanks miketd. Pours a dark black, uncharacteristically dark. Two finger creamy brown head. Toasted aroma, a little sweet, definitely Belgian malts, . The flavor has a teryaki taste to it, a bit sweet, definitely malty, a little belgian hint and some alcohol. Pretty easy to drink. An interesting brew.

On tap at the Eccentric Cafe and served in a snifter.  This beer poured a very dark brown with a one-finger thick head of tan foam that lasted throughout the entire glass.  Some excellent lacing was left behind.  The aroma of the beer was made up of dark fruits, caramel, light chocolate notes, and some earthy yeast esthers.  The flavor of the beer consisted of dark fruits, light cocoa, candi sugar, and also some lightly spicy/bready yeast esters.  The mouthfeel was medium to full-bodied with moderate carbonation.  This was a mildly complex beverage with an interesting flavor.  Quite enjoyable.

Very dark pour, almost stout-like in color with a smallish dark tan head.  Some sweet fruit, caramel, a bit of bubble gum, and hints of candy sugar all come out in the nose.  Medium bodied with light carbonation.  Flavor starts with toffee, some spiciness and earthiness in the middle, dry finish with a slight bitterness.

Poured a medium bodied darker brown color witha small white head that fizzles off pretty quick.  Aroma is sweet carmel malts with a little chocolate and some belgian yeast.  The flavor is brown sugar, toasted malts, spices, cookies, and a littlte chocolate roast.

Thanks to Chris O. for this treat--Poured a thick deep black-red body with a minuscule off-white head.  Roasted malts and spicy, yeasty nose.  Chocolaty bitter sweet finish.  Strange recipe, but one worth trying.
At eccentric.  Pours dark red/black with hardly any head.  Very thick palate and dark fruity taste.  Some alcohol detectable.  Enjoyable beer.

Pours a dark, ruby brown without much of a head.  The aroma is of dark fruits and sweet, slightly roasted malts.  The flavor is sort of directionless, but features some interesting cocoa and candi sugar flavors with a mild hop bitterness on the finish.  OK for an "anytime" beer, but certainly nothing super-special.

Rated blind from "Better Know a Style: Abbey Dubbel" tasting.  Black/dark brown color with almost non-existenttan head.  Roasty light aroma.  Chocolate flavor with roasted malt, slight spice and yeast as well.  Smooth medium body.  Out of style but very good.

Had this on tap at the Oyster Bar.  Not much aroma but very powerful maltiness and raisen flavor.  Alcohol is very apparent. A bitter finish lingers long.  Not much of a fan of this style but Im glad I tried it.

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2007 rated blind from "Better Know a Style: Abbey Dubbel" tasting. pours very dark w/ tan head. nose is roasty w/ yeasty spice to it. flavor is roasty, spicy, meaty, some fruits, chocolate. smooth. very stout like with belgian yeast. weird.

Pours a super rich dark dark brown. Small white head dicipates fast. Aroma of sweet malt, coffee, dark chocolate with a few hops in the background shining through. Nice bottle I guess, smooth and not too heavy body. Tastes great with some coffee and roasted malt, balanced by some hop bitterness. Halloween is coming, this wont scare anyone and I think I have the courage now.

The aroma is malty, sweet, slight alcohol, a little toffee slight raisin smell. Pours dark with light brown head, pretty much fully diminishing. The initial flavor is coffee, toffee and a slight bitter. The finish is short and a hint of alcohol. Bought this months ago and wasnt impressed, drank five bottles of the six pack and saved one to rate. Finally rating and now Im a little more impressed, the flavor is much better than I remembered - I was thinking I wouldnt buy this again, now if I can find another six pack Ill store it for a year and taste again.

bottle (batch 7673)....aroma: lots of sweet malt, toffee, and caramel along with some dark fruit.....appearance:  lively, cola-like black pour with thin light brown head.  very stoutish in appearance......taste: chocolate, malts, some bitter roast qualities with a dry and slightly bitter finish.  thin mouthfeel.  overall, i found this somewhat lacking although its quite drinkable but i wouldnt find myself reaching for another if it came down to it.

Dark brown pour with thin but well-retained mocha head, thin lacing. The nose is roasty, grainy, and chocolatey with notes of caramel apples, raspberries, raisins and red wine and wine yeast. The flavor isnt very inviting, mostly because its overly sweet and lopsided. Mild spice is introduced just as mellow roast takes a nosedive under caramel malt. hints of smoke quickly succumb to the fruity onslaught. On the backside, roast returns and leads into an off-dry finish. Roasted grains, dark fruits and alcohol burn linger, as well as touches of smoked tobacco. Medium body, light and soft carbonation, underwhelming mouthfeel overall. Boring.

Bottle courtesy nolankowal via trade. Dark brown, stout-like colored pour, tan to choco colored head that is thin, subsiding quickly to a ring around the edges of the glass at the beer/air/glass interface. The aroma is roasty, caramel, dark fruits, some alcohol also. The flavor is roasted choco, some even burnt choco, light ash, dark fruits, licorice, dry light sprucey / pine needle type spices at the end. Mouthfeel is a little acidic and dry, perhaps not as fully attenuated as it could be, yet not candi-sugared up. A neat beer, a better twist on a stout (even a Belgian-style stout) than a dubbel, but whatever. Thanks, John, for the trade!

Draught, at MacKenzies, Minneapolis, June 2007. Very dark brown with just a thin collar of beige foam. Surprisingly, the aroma is not particularly powerful, with subtle caramel and raisin notes in evidence. More dried fruit and burnt caramel in the flavours. Smooth mouthfeel but rather dry for a dubbel, if that is indeed what it is.

12oz bottle packaged on 10/11/06. Served in a NB snifter @ 59° Aroma is cocoa, milk chocolate, earthiness, lactose, and dark fruits. The beer is black with a wispy head and lots of particulate matter in the bottom of the glass. The taste is sweet malt, cinnamon, dark fruits, smoke?, and alcohol. Finish is sweet and tart with dark fruits, roast, and alcohol. This is the 6th of a six pack I bought a LONG time ago. I didnt have a problem drinking the first 5 beers, but I never got around to rating this. Im sure many people have mentioned that it is not to style for an abbey dubbel, but that doesnt bother me in the least. My rating is based on my enjoyment of the beer and despite being a nice drinking beer, it is fairly simple and the roast seems to muddle the other flavors. I doubt Ill buy another six pack.

Porter-like dark malt aromas, chocolate malt in particular, along with subtle Belgian-type phenolics, a little leathery.  Looks like a stout, very dark brown with a tight, thin tan head.  Flavor actually reminds me of English pipe tobacco - smokey and leathery with a subtle spiciness.  Medium body with medium carbonation.  Interesting, but not a beer Id buy again.

Pours a dark brown with a creamy tan head. Aroma is yeasty, bready malts with metallic undertones. Flavor is of belgian yeast, roasted malts, and aged fruits. Palate is a bit too thin to be a Dubbel. Not a bad attempt on the style, and definitely a change from the standard.

Thin brown head sits atop a black body. No lace. Nose is lightly sweet malts, hint roasty, earthy and fruity. Body is med/light, oily palate. Light chocolate flavors with notes of roast, cocoa, licorice dark fruits. Finish is lightly sweet and a touch tangy. Abbey Dubbel? Props to OhioDad for the bottle.

Pours a deep brown hue with a decent espresso head, similar to a stout,  Aromas of flowers/floral, a light yeastiness, prunes.  Mouthfeel is medium to full -bodied with flavors or roasted cofffee, a little smoke, again prunes with a drying finish.  Very interesting as this is more a stout/dubble than just a straight dubble due to the lack of belgian yeast characteristics (mouthfeel and finish) and the flavors.

(Bottle via trade with <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=2 target=blank>OhioDad, thanks Scott!) Wow this is one interesting beer...Looks deep red/burgundy coming out of bottle, then becomes almost black, very dark reddish brown in the glass. 1/2" of smooth khaki head settles to a very thin layer. Aroma brings red wine, dark chocolate, yeast, sweet cherry and dark fruits. Mouthfeel is quite smooth, light but full, small bubbly carbonation (bottle conditioned?). Rings of lacing form and then melt away. Flavor is dark chocolate on top of Belgian yeast dark fruitiness. Dark chocolate merges together wonderfully with the sweet and dark fruit taste. Ive drank stouts that have tried to merge the chocolate and fruity flavors together but this beer does it much better presumably by skillful use of the yeast and elimination of the roastiness and coffee flavor of the stouts. Nice lingering dark/light bitter chocolate aftertaste.

Bottled. Dark reddish brown coloured. Small light brown head. Aroma of liqourice, caramel, chocolate and some fruits and alcohol. Flavour is quite yeasty and has liqourice and chocolate. Is medium bodied. Quite dry. Ends on a frutiy and light roasty note. Easy to drink. Thanks to Immy for this.

Pours black with a creamy brown head. Aromas of sweet roasted malt, a hint of chocolate and a hint of alcohol. Fairly creamy yet firm on the palate. Dry and yeasty flavor profile. Hint of candied fruits and roasted malt. Finishes with a blast of yeasty dryness. Odd beer. How is this a Dubbel?

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Pours an opaque black with a creamy, beige head leaving some lacework. Sweetish, fruity, plum-like nose. Rather full-bodied with sweetish, roasted malt, some dried fruit - prunes. A slightly burned edge. A rather unusual beer - somewhere in the borderland between a stout and a belgian ale. 280507

Bottled. A pitch black beer with a thin brown head. The aroma is sweet with notes of vegetables, and roasted malt, as well as light notes of alcohol. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of vegetables, alcohol, and hard roasted malt, the alcohol leaves a slight burn on the tongue. No where near an Abbey dubbel in my universe - my guess was a cross between a stout and a spice/herb/vegetable beer.

Rated 11/11/06:  Interesting take on this style and an all around conforting brew. Aroma is mild and uneventful, some richness and dark fruits. Real dark brown pour, sizeable light brown head that soon turns to a fine film. Mouthfeel is rich and creamy with an exceptional dry finish. Flavor is also dry with some nice mild spice mixed in with dark fruit, burnt chocolate, and rich caramel. Very good sipper.

Blackish-brown pour with a nice tan head.  Aroma is roasty with some light chocolate and a hint of Candi sugar.  Flavor is an odd mix of coffee, coke zero, and light chocolate.  This one is pretty good, but the wacky flavor keeps it from being a good porter/stout and a nice Dubbel or other Belgian as well.  Nice experiment, and thats exactly what I like about Bells - solid "standard" offerings with some unique stuff that they are willing to bottle.

12oz bottle that poured out dark and very stout like with light brown head. I noticed a brown slick of sediment left behind in the bottle.
