Initially the aroma is stout like with malt roastiness, sweetness and smoke. Then I get a bit of spice and yeast and alcohol and faint lemony tartness and some funk. Like the aroma the flavor starts with rich molasses sweetness, some malt roastiness and some fruitiness. Then near midway I get some tart notes along with a hint of Lambic funk and a sense of alcohol. As the finish of the taste approaches a plum note becomes more pronounced. Once that begins to fade I get a burlap sack sense. Into the after taste a very nice stout flavor returns with sweet molasses mixed with highly roasted to burnt malts. Very interesting brew with lots and lots going on.

I was mislead into thinking that this was a belgian dark strong.  Aroma was  of roasted malts, chocolate, even smoky.  The flavor was the same as the aroma.  Not very complex.  There was a definite alcohol presence.  It reminded me of a one-sided baltic porter.  Perhaps being thrown for a loop affected my perception but I had to pass it off to a neighbor.

Pours out a dark brown with a light brown head. This beer is cool it looks like a porter but smells like a belgian dubbel should with yeast and spice dominating in the aroma. The taste is yet another twist as you get roasted flavors and chocolate, maybe even a bit of coffee instead of your typical doughy yeasty flavor. I think I like this beer just because of all the twists and how unique it is not for its "style".
UPDATED: MAY 19, 2007 One beer from Bells I found that I do not like one bit.  Pours black with a brown head and smells like coffee.  I dont know why but I didnt enjoy this.
Pours black with a brown head. Smells of coffee and light chocolate. Tastes much of the same with hints molasses. Also kind of smokey.
DARK with off brown head.  Nose of chocolate and roasted coffee.  Flavor much the same, yet the hint of smoke lingers in the back of the tongue.  Nice malty finish.

This beer confused me.  It didnt really taste like a dubbel to me.  dark brown with dark fruits and some spice.  There was something in the flavor I really didnt like.  Ok beer, not what I was expecting.

bottle: pours a black colour wtih a big tan head. aroma is malty with a little roastedness and yeasty. flavour i s roasted and molasses with a hint of dark fruits and spices in the finish. do not really know what to make of this. does not seem like a abbey double though. i am confused.
Lots of yeast and corriander in the aroma.Pours a dark brown with a medium light tan head.The spices really dominate the flavor.Medium mouthfeel with a yeast/spice finish.

12 oz bottle, batch 7673, courtesy oakbluff. Near completely opaque dark brown colour with glints of ruby. Fully diminishing creamy tan head. Yeasty, chocolate, roasty coffee, lightly vinous and plummy aroma. Roasty, plummy, raisin, burnt sugar, molasses, lightly smoky, and cream flavours. Finishes roasty, dry, and lightly acidic. Full bodied, prickly and creamy mouthfeel. Incredibly unusual aroma and flavour - aroma works really well for me, the flavour good but doesnt work quite as much as the aroma. Best summation I can come up with is this is what would result if Unibroue brewed a smoked stout.

Everytime I go to Bells I order up the same beers, but not today. After passing this one over many-a-time, today I decided to give it a try and I left feeling quite pleased although Im sure the 9% the Fury packs helped me out. The beer poured an opaque black with a creamy, inviting tan head which faded to a small ring around the glass. The initial smell is roasted malts and coffee. At first the taste followed and then a cola-like sweetness developed about half way through. Not as thick as some of the others like Expedition (mmm!), but still a solid body on this one. The cola flavor also became evident in the smell as did a tangy sour extension to the roastiness. This probably wont replace any of my fallbacks, but was a nice change of pace today.

Dark reddish brown. Tan / brown head. Smokey grain aroma. Sweet fruit notes. Flavor has some of the same... its well put together. Smokey berries, some woody honey. Some wheaty and fruity malt. Not much of a abbey ale by my definition, but its a good version of one for sure.
Grainy nose on this pitch black beer with clingy brown head.  Vague coffee flavor.

Dark Dark Brown Color with Sandy Ring.  Burnt Caramel and Tobacco Aroma.  Initially a Fair Amount of Sweetness and Carbonation.  Tobacco Dry Aftertaste.. Burnt Caramel Notes Througout...Medium Mouthfeel.   A Love it or Hate it Beer.
wow, this is another great dark beer from bells with plenty of flavor. only downside here was a lingering aftertaste of alcohol.

From a 12 oz. bottle with a short blurb and batch number 7673, packaged on Oct/11/2006, on the back label, sampled at cellar temperature in a tulip glass.

Poured a syrupy blackish brown with a tight foamy tan head that settled into a thin sudsy lacing, minimal amount of laced sticking.

Aromas of dark berries, earthy coffee, hints of sweet caramel and burnt chocolate, nutty and softly spicy, and whiffs of medicinal alcohol.

Moderate carbonation and a softly malty crisp, dryish, creamy medium bodied mouthfeel.

Roasted malty taste, roasted light coffee, caramelized sugar and milk chocolate, a hint of smoky, toasted nuts, a sweet berry fruitiness, a soft spiciness with a pinch of pepper, a warming medicinal alcohol the stays in the background, and a dry salty, fruity, roasted malty finish.

Another unique offering from Bells, not one of my favorites, but worth trying.

Bottle, Trappist Glass, pours a very dark black color, with a dark tan head. Sweetness, thats almost cloying but not to prevalent, its balanced against spicy yeasts with plenty of pepper and clove. Roasted grains are quite prevalent. Hops have a slight degree of bitterness. Thanks MrRomero.
Dark brown pour, small beige head. Sweet malts, some roastiness, spices, candi sugar, dark fruits, slight chocolate, warming alcohol kick, and spicy hops.

Bottle - Black pour with minimal head that dissipates quickly.  Musty aroma of smoke and charcoal.  Flavor is unmistakably burnt roasted marshmallows with roasted malt notes and hints of molasses and caramels.  Medium palate.  Abbey dubbel? er...not really but a very unusual and interesting beer when viewed in its own category.

Draft A dark black body with small size head. Smoky aroma with a nice malt profile. Flavor was smooth but smoky - smoked malt dominated the flavor with a small amount of yeast being there. Nice aftertaste and was pleasant on the tongue. This is not dubbel, its a stout!

Bottle: Dark brown in color, moderate light brown head, fizzy, sparce lacing. &nbsp Strong burnt malt nose, campfire, charcoal, necco wafer (the white or black one).  Odd dark pitted fruit start, but moreso smokey. &nbsp This comes across as more of a rauchbier. &nbsp Heavy malts, burnt the point of charcoal. &nbsp Some licorice root and earthy aspect. &nbsp Moderate body, moderate to heavy mouthfeel &nbsp Interesting stuff to say the least, and certainly less like a Dubbel than a Smoked beer. &nbsp Meh... &nbsp Thanks Ben for the bottle!

12 oz bottle, via joebrew.  Pours an inappropriately dark brown, almost black, body under a small foamy brown head that fell to a thin ring.  Lots of sediment in the bottle.  Aroma is of roast, fruity esters, chocolate, yeast, coffee, and light alcohol.  Flavor is just as eclectic as the aroma.  Roasty and fruity up front with some dry roasted coffee, chalk, bananas, and yeast on the finish.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with a slightly creamy texture up front and moderate fizzy carbonation.  Finishes with a little stickiness.  Overall, Im not all too sure what Ive got here, but its drinkable and interesting.  OK for a beer, but pretty bad for an Abbey Dubbel.

Pretty good beer.  Lots going on, maybe too much.  Sweet spiceyness, like jamaican BBQ(not the heat of course).  Molasses with some all spice noted malts?? is that right.  my guess.  seems to be a porter to me.

Sampled February 2007
Pours with a three finger thick, light brown cooled head that sits atop a perfectly porter colored beer.  That is the beer is quite dark, really almost a perfect black color, that showed a dark brown, clear hue as I was pouring it.  The aroma has fruity notes of plum to it up front, plus some roasted / burnt notes to it.  Some faint earthy spice notes round things out; a sort of damp earth and clove amalgam of aromatic notes.

The beer is quite sweet and thick, in fact it is very chewy.  Way too thick for a Belgian Dubbel, but hey this was already a beer outside any stylistic guides from the get go.  The flavor is finished off by a burnt fig / raisin note, as well as notes of blackened caramel.  While this is fairly sweet, I would not describe it in any way as saccharinely sweet.  Instead the sweetness is from a plethora of complex malt sugars, which also serve to make this beer quite chewy.  Light notes of clove, a touch of allspice, some hints of white pepper all fight to be noticed as they are buried underneath all of the malt.  The malt character is at times toasty, definitely caramel like, with touches of toffee and burnt bread crust, really it reminds me in some ways of a traditional, black, German, holiday sweet bread.

If I had not been forewarned, I would have been sorely disappointed in this beer as it is so far from a traditional Belgian Ale, much less a Dubbel.  Having said that though, I actually enjoyed this brew.  Its biggest flaw is that it is too thick, it is almost a meal and even calling it chewy underestimates it.

12 oz bottle, courtesy of StompBrockmore - pours almost black and without the huuuuuge head that usually complements a dubbel.  Actually resembles a stout.  Tons of floating chunks that settle and coat the bottom of the glass.  Aroma of dark fruits and some smokiness as well - very faintly yeasty, as befits a dubbel.  Has that dry roasty finish of an imperial stout as well.  Sweet roasted malt, dry cocoa and some very subtle spice in the mouth.  Sort of thin mouthfeel.  Alcohol is present.  Really seems like a strong yeasty spiced stout rather than a dubbel, but hey, names are just names and this is pretty darn delicious.  I like it!

I seriously had to struggle to even give this a rating as high as I did.  Maybe a had a bad bottle; most Bells offerings have struck me as at least decent.  This one---horrible.  Aroma was watery asparagus and broccolli, and some sugary malt.  Flacor - BURNT broccolli (somehow worse than non-burnt broccolli in a beer, evidently), other vegetables creeping in, and some completely random sweet malts.  This beer is astonishingly bad; I really should give it a lower rating but I wont.

I had to bust a bottle out of my cellar as I haven;t reviewed this yet.  Pours a dark brownish black with a decent tan head.  Nice smokey hints on the nose as well as some dark fruit, banana, biscuit, and a hint of chocolate.  Decent kinda watery mouthfeel for the color with hints of the dubbel-like spiciness.  Decent creamy mouthfeel, but nothing spectacular.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: Dark brown/black and 1.5cm of frothy, light brown head. Nose like a roasted dubbel- dark fruits, toffee cookie malt, fresh grains, tangy and lightly spicy yeast- then all of it roasted. Flavor adds some stout or porter like notes- bittersweet chocolate, light vanilla- and bready elements to the yeast. Medium body, well carbonated. Unique brew, very nice.

bottle. thanks, brent. black pour with a light brown  thick head. weird funky roast nose that is intriguing. yeasty pineapple chocolate, and roast flavor. reminds me a bit of a dunkel. slight sourness in there that is a bit out of whack with everything else. an interesting concoction.

Thanks to Buckybeer. Damn, this poured very dark, I would call the look more like a porter/stout. Fluffy tan head. Nose has yeast and caramel and more porter and stout hints. The taste is very much stout likee, there is a belgian candy taste here, but also roasted malts and cream. Strange dubbel, would love to try this again.

Sampled at Larry Bells Brickskeller event. Dark opaque brown with a fading light brown head. Nice roasty and lightly estery nose (not as spicy/fruity as traditional dubbels). Flavor has notes of heavy caramel, full non-harsh roastiness, chocolate, light yeasty fruitiness. Kind of stout-like actually. Full, viscous creamy body with subtle carbonation. Very enjoyable. I have a full bottle so itll be interesting to see if my rating changes.

Batch 7673. Pours dark with medium tan head.  Aroma is molasses, raisin, and yeast.  Im not sure if I am rating this properly because Im confused that its a dubbel.  The yeast is expected, the caramel, molasses, and other flavors I cant place are not.  This was good but not great.

"Hell hath no fury like a woman scorn for sega." 

Pours near pitch black, and forms into a nice dark tan head. A little fizzy looking, and that translates to the palate. Very drinkable, and a very good brew.

Cola body topped by beige head.  Aroma is medium sweet, raisin, some caramel, Belgian yeast.  Taste is medium sweet, raisin, Belgian yeast, some caramel, light roast.  Watery medium body, alcohol well hidden.

on tap @ flanagans ale house.  a clean, dark color.  i was unable to perceivce any depth in color because of the low lighting at the bar. tasted like chocolate and molasses. an almost minty aroma was paired with roasted nuts and hop.

In the bottle from the Brown Derby International Wine Center. Pours black with a rapidly diminishing light brown head. The aroma is spruce and lemon grass. Has a medicinal aroma. The dominant flavor at first is mint. Then it gets a biscuity cocoa taste. Finish is like quinine. Tingly mildly fizzy palate. Rich and mouth-coating. Strange brew. Smells like a marigold when warm. Very yeasty.

I was not expecting what I got when I poured it, thats for sure.  I thought this was going to be an IPA--probably my mental confusion with the recent Tyranena Bitter Woman From Hell Extra IPA.  So when it came out black with a large dark brown head...whoa.  This is a kitchen-sink brew: not that it is going down the kitchen sink but rather that there is everything except the kitchen sink in here.  Molasses, smoke, hops, candi sugar; dark fruit is overwhelmed.  Tastes more like the Bells Batch 6000 (Double IPA/Barleywine + Imperial Stout).  Thick and velvety on the tongue, long finish of charcoal made from a rare South American wood.  Not bad at all, though too much for most of my drinking pleasure.

Tastes like they poured an imp. stout into a dubbel ale. Lots of molasses, spices, dark cherries and roasted cashews. Has the body and color of an imperial with no head and little alcohol. Finishes syrupy and thick with a plastic or bandaid aftertaste, maybe from the smoke.
Bottle courtesy of nolankowal.  Pours brown with a tan thin head.  Smells boozy with nuts, spices, caramel and dark fruit.  Tastes of sugar, molasses and some fruit.  Decent, but not their best.

12oz bottle.  Batch 7673.  Deep brown opaque with tan layer of head.  Floral and musty aromas with a slight hint of coffee.  Bitter acidic smokey grainy wheaty flavors.  Full bodied and initially smooth.  Rather spicy.  Burnt malts.  Berry nuances.  Touch of vanilla.  Sticky and long finish.  Something about this hit me wrong.   I will return to this again...

This is a dubbel?  OK, then.  Pours a nearly pitch brown, head thins to lace quickly.  Aroma is somewhat vague, I smell some molasses, coffee, and thats about it.  Flavor is nice, rich belgian yeast notes accent a smoky ham flavor, coffee and chocolate undertones, grassy hops and a hint of lemon on the end.  Very nice, very unique.
Very unexciting aroma is slightly malty, beet sugars and some dry caramel. A bit more interesting flavor-wise, warming and thick, buttery green malts and a nice pruney kind of roundness.

12oz bottle, from my friends dad. Pours a dark brown with small head nearing no head,  Seems like alot of others like a stout than a dubbel. some roasty flavors some malt flavor.. good beer overall not sure on the style tho.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2007 12oz bottle from the Foodery. Pours very deep brown, nearly opaque with a small tan head. Nice aroma - dried fruits, yeast, pepper and spice. Big roasted malt flavor along with some cocoa and spice. Dry finish; a bit astringent. Unique abbey double.

Pours dark and headless with amber shallows.  The aroma harbors raspberry marshmallows, graham crackers and vanilla.  The flavor is rather dry with vanilla highlights and a subtle smokiness.  I keep searching deeper for substance, but continue to come up empty.  A kind of hollow empty void pervades this beer as though it were longing for the earthy yeast of its breathern.  Overall, seems more like a failed attempt at something bigger rather than what it, at last, is.

Deep burgundy body with some oily viscosity, but retains a tight, silky,  ruddy-tan head.  Aroma suggests substantial caramelization and special B characters along with notes of light soy, dark honey, fried bananas, and port.  Grapey malt and Belgian yeast flavors.  Like a cross between a Bells Stout, a Belgian dubbel, and grape Hubba Bubba.  Yet another fine beer from Kalamazoo.

(Bottle, Oliver Twist, Stockholm) Dark brown, almost black, colour with brief, frothy, brown head. Roasted, malty, rather spicy nose with notes of liquorice, yeast and hints of rubber. Roasted, spicy taste with liquorice, dark chocolate, freshly ground coffee and slighty vinous, yeasty notes. Rather short finish, slightly thinner than expected. Not one of their best, but very nice. However, seems to lack something extra.

Deep brown appearance with an average size mocha colored head and little lacing.  Porter-like smokey, roasted malt aroma with hints of coffee, dark fruit, licorice and caramel.  Mild sweet flavors with a lot of fruit evolve into a drier, more bitter taste with spices becoming more evident.  Medium to full bodied, modestly carbonated mouthfeel.
Bottle. Thanks to BillVanE. Poured a dark reddish orange color with a tan head. Aroma of malt and a little of smoke. Taste is malty with a hop kinda finsh and a touch of smoke.

Very dark ruby-brown with a moderate, light brown head. Stains the glassxi 
  yellow.
  Aroma is hops, malt, smokiness, molasses, and mocha.
  Full-bodied, smooth mouthfeel, hoppy, but well balanced with roasted malt.
  Very flavorful but not so overpowering that it has to be sipped. Gorgeous and
  delicious. More like a light imperial stout
 than a dubbel.

Draft @ HDG. Pours dark brown with a medium sized head. Aroma is dried fruits with caramel and toast. Flavor is dominated with cherries and spicy hops only rounded out with smoky malts. A nice brew but also a bit on the sweet side.

Bottle, courtesy JimboWood - thanks! Pours an opaque blackish brown with a substantial tan head. Aroma of caramel, fruit and spice. Medium body and fine carbonation. The taste starts sweet, with fruit and molasses, but quickly yields to licorice and ginger. Warm and spicy finish.

12oz, Batch 7673.  Been waiting a while to try this one.  Black body with a one finger brown head, quickly fading to a ring.  I smell a fair amount more than what I think I should get with a dubbel.  This is a bit too cold right now, but before warming it up all I really smell is Belgian yeast and roasty malts.  After warming I get dark fruits (raisins and figs), faint honey, a bit of char.  Flavor has char up front with some roasted malts, some vinous presence that makes the alcohol wamer than it probably is.  The yeast takes a bit of a back seat to the big roast, though the fruits fare a little better.  Body is medium with soft carbonation.  Not too bad of a beer at all.     Thanks to Cliff (GrbDg) for the bonus!
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: 12 oz bottel, batch #7673.  Pours almost black, with roasty notes and a hint of spice and fairly assertive hopiness.  Seems to be a cross between an Abbey beer and robust porter with its assertive character.  Nice beer, but nothing special.
wow this is thick.  tan to brown head when poured.  nice rich flavor.  tastes very yummy
Thanks to Santa for the bottle.  Brown to the point of black, thin brown head.  Nose is caramel, muddled fruit.  Flavor is rich malt, alcohol, cherry/fruit.  Slight sour tinge.  Meh.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2009 Pours nearly opaque with a thin head.  Aroma is roasty for a dubbel, and so is the taste!  This is quite a unique dubbel indeed.  Very roasty chocolate flavors and aftertaste. Very good.

12oz. bottle.  Batch# 7673.  Interesting aroma, being lightly roasty and sweet, with hints of dark chocolate, molasses, flowers, grainy, toasty malts (perhaps even slightly burnt) and a very faint oaky, vinous touch deep in the background.  Some yeast in the nose, as well.  Impenetrable black color, fully opaque with a fading, tan head and minimal lacing.  Flavor is about what the aroma would suggest, roasty and full of semi-sweet chocolate character, a degree of tanginess noted here, along with more molasses on the finish and suggestions of black walnut, fig and a certain unfamiliar spiciness.  Smoothly carbonated and drying mouthfeel, with a long-lingering roasty aftertaste.  Body is medium-full.  This is certainly not a Dubbel style, nor does it fit any other style that Im familiar with.  Seems most like a Foreign Stout/Belgian Ale hybrid, though.  Worth a try, but definitely not mind-blowing.

12 oz. Bottle: Pours dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma has hints of fruits, malts and yeasts. Flavor is sweet and malty with hints of fruits and spices. Mouthfeel is thin but warming. Overall, very good representation of a Belgium style.

This is a hybrid rating.  I had both on tap and in bottle and I can say that tap was superior.  Overall the density of the beer is incredible, something to behold.  I found the richness to be great, though savored.  Roasty, malty, and slightly fruity like figs or dates.  Very complex beer, well worth trying.

Bottle from Sprinkle. Pours a deep black color. Darkest dubbel Ive seen. Dark roasted malty aroma, along with a hint of yeastiness and dark fruit. Flavor up front is somewhat smoke, with roasted maltiness. Alot like a stout with some yeast and spiciness. Ineresting and enjoyable. Well hidden alcohol.

Well, this is interesting! 12oz from a trade with drewbeerme - thanks! Having some of the "its a stout masquerading as a dubbel" reviews I have to say Im a bit persuaded. As I opened this and poured it into a snifter, I got a strong aroma of clove and vanilla. As it warmed a bit there was a definite anise presence, with a bit of roastiness to boot. Lovely oily brown body, with a slightly too-thin mouthfeel (barely any lacing). But as you get deeper into this beer its dubbel through and through. Really quirky and something Id love to try again.
Pours dark with little head. Dark malty, alcoholic, coffee aroma. Malty flavor of chocolate, tobacco, and wood. Strong warm alcoholic quality, very appropriate title.

Bottled. Pitch black colour with small brown head. Aroma is tar, alcohol, roasted malts and coffee and slight leatheryness. Flavour is leather, roasted malts, licorace, smoked wet wood. Quite lots of anything in it.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2007 12oz. bottle - pours pretty much black, with a decent tan head that dissipated quickly. This looks like a porter or a stout...not really like a dubbel. Aroma is...uh...also like a porter or stout. At least much more than it reminds me of an abbey ale. But its good. Roasted malt and woody smoke in the aroma, along with some traces of dark fruit. Ah hah - flavour amplifies these same qualities, but the fruity character comes through much more at the back and in the finish. In the foreground is that same woody smoke, but also intensified. Sweet and malty throughout. Some nice bitterness in the finish as well, with a good lingering aftertaste. Really unique brew, and very drinkable. A strange marriage of styles, but it works. Certainly unlike anything Ive had before.
Pours brown with a nice tan head. Taste is nutty and somewhat spicy. An OK offering from Bells.

Bottled
Almot opaque black color, small tan head. Strong tar and smoke in the nose. Full bodied, licorice, tar and smokey malts in the flavor, but quite simple palate. Kind of sticky mouthfeel. Its a good brew, but too simple for my liking.

From a 12-ounce bottle, poured an opaque dark brown with a noticable tan head and lace. Creamy mouthfeel and medium body. Cant place the style. Slight estery notes, nice chocolatey character, early touch of hops bitterness, very rich, even dry/sweet  dark malt overall flavor balance. A nice beer for the winter.

Little to no nose on this puppy.  I cant see through the glass kinda color that I like with a limited tan head.  Thick molasses with a bit of chocolate malt ending.  I want to like this Bells brew, but it is not too exciting for a special release.  This beer is all over the radar.  Looks great, but could be more flavorful.
On tap. An ok Abbey Dubbel.  Hoppy, malty, and caramel flavors.  Finishes creamy and sticky.

Bottle shared with and courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours a very dark brown, almost black, with an average size light-brown head -- this is an Abbey Dubbel? Aroma of slightly roasted malt, dark fruit, spices and yeast. Flavours malty and yeasty with spices, dark fruit and a decent bitter finish -- reads a lot like the aroma but tastes surprisingly different. Medium to full bodied. Very unique and interesting -- good stuff!

This is a surprisingly dark beer that poured like motor oil and is opaque with brownish hints around the edges.  Thin whispy oil slick of a head.  The nose initially reminded me of smoking a clove cigarette.  That burnt clove sensation continues into the flavor.  Lots of ash, burnt molassess, tar, and wood smoke.  This is an odd beer, and definitely a sipping beer.  Noticable green bitterness in the finish.  Maybe I like it because it does remind me of smoking cloves.  I need to go get me some cigarettes.

A big thanks to Tish for bringing this one to Beer Church!  I really enjoyed this one!  Aroma has a biscuity, roastiness, with a hint of spice and fruit (figs).  Pours a very dark brown.  There is a distinct roasted flavor paired with a great brown sugar.  There is some hop spice in there too.  Very enjoyable.

Bottle (12oz).  Shared with blankboy, via trade with TURDFERGUSON.  Wow!  Thick black-red pour, opaque, light brown average rocky head - looks like a decent stout!  Dark roast aroma, sharp spicy yeast, scorched bandaid sulphur notes, eventually some stewed prunes and thick stewed prunes on warming.  Taste is quite different - near-burnt sugar, sweet spices, light floral hops and a variety of bready/sharp yeast tones - finishes roasty and sweet.  Thick and smooth body, very malty with a slight woodsmoke aftertaste - really interesting, massive disconnect between aroma and taste.

On tap at HDG. Dark brown color with a small beige head. Strange mix of aromas. Banana, bubblegum, dried fruits, as well as dark roasted malts that was more like a porter. Flavor was lightly sweet, with some fruity esthers, mild banana, roasted malts and dried fruit. Interesting beer. Wasnt bad, just not sure what to make of it.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2007 Bottle.  Deep brown, almost black with a hint of red.  Late developing 2 inch head, with some legs.  Aroma is roasted malt and fruit sweetness.  Initial taste was mostly the roasted coffee, though there was some fruit (apple or pear) sweetness there too.  Body was nice on this, though would expect a bit for texture for an Abbey Dubbel.  My only confusion on this beer is style.  It almost tasted like a stout blended with an amber ale, with Belgian overtones.  Interesting brew.

Bottle; pours a deep espresso black with a slight ruby tint, moderate tan head that dissipates to a thin ring; no lacing.  Sweeter malty aroma of chocolate, cherry, raisin and molasses. Taste is fairly carbonated, with the alcohol coming out first, followed by some malts and yeast.  You can sense the more mature flavors trying to come together in there but they just dont quite make it.  Overall it ends up being a bit mediciney on the palate.  Im a big fan of Bells but this is off the mark.

Bottled: Dark brown to black, big tan head, chocolate and burnt malt aroma, some dark fruits as well, flavor is sweet, chocolate and roasted malts, hints of some dark fruits, very different from any belgian i had ever had with the exception of the de dolle stout.

Pours with a black body topped by a medium thick, quickly disappearing head with some lacing left behind.  Its slightly sweet and malty with a very slight roastiness and a nice dark fruit note with a hint of anise.  Full bodied and smooth yet slightly warming.

Draft at KClingers.  Pitch black; it sat for a while so Im not sure on the head.  What was left was tan and thin.  Nice thick dark beer; bit of an anise aroma, well-rounded roasty flavors wtih a bit of a licorice twist.  Well done.  (#2650, 1/14/07)

Nearly black body with only a few small bubbles dispersed at the top of the sample. Aroma is sweet berries and malts. Flavor of dark fruits and chocolate. Some spice on the tongue. Strange stuff but not at all bad.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2010 Bottle.   Chocolate caramel malt and bitter grass aroma.  Dark black-brown color with small head - pours like a stout.  Sweet chocolate malt and licorice flavor.  Plastic aftertaste.  Better than the first bottle I had but still not great.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2007 12 oz bottle.  via trade with Hellomynameis.  Pours dark amber brown almost black.  There is a small thin light brown head as well.  The aroma is sweet, malty and strong.  The taste is malty and sweet and tasty but really not too amazing.  I have to say I really like everything Ive had from Bells but this falls a little short.   It has a belgian feeling but isnt quite there.

Pours a very deep dark brown, topped with a smattering of brown foam that really turns out to be just a ring. Okay lacing. Dry chocolate malt in the aroma, but not a whole lot of it. A little maple in there too, though you really have to look for it.

Sweetish beer, with chocolate malt, some peat, and then some dry roasted grain. Finish is also on the sweet side, with a chocolate-covered raisin presence. Medium to full body, mild carbonation.

Dark pour, dirty head.  Aroma and taste rather characteristic of the belgian "origin."  Strange mouthfeel.  Not what i was expecting.  Nothing about this beer is impressive, although nothing about it is terrible.  I wouldnt purchase a 6 pack.  The label is funny though.  The woman is Larrys second wife...

Poured a dark brown, with a small, off white, creamy head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of dried fruits, caramel malts, some toffee, nuts, and roasted malts.  Much of the same in the taste, with a near cloying mouthfeel. Cocoa, roasted malts, candy sugar, raisins, caramel, with a hint of alcohol in the finish.

Thanks to SS for this one.
The color of this one approaches black.
Average sized, creamy brown head.
Typical Belgian aroma, fruity, vinous. Raisins and rum.
Flavor follows the aroma. Sweet with a dry finish.

Im new to rating, but I want to keep a log and become more educated. 

Bells is a favorite of mine and since I got one of the last six packs at the Keg, I had to bring some back from my trip to IN/KY.
user_location: In transition at the moment, Indiana, USA

text: The first thing I notice about this heavy dark brown brew is that it sort of looks like a porter and lacks the large head that I expect from a Dubbel. No matter, Im more concerned with how it tastes. The aroma is at once sort of chocolatey while hinting at a bit of dark fruit and sweet bread. The flavor is somewhat yeasty but not really Belgian tasting. Hints of chocolate, almond, brown sugar, and fresh bread come through the most. Lively carbonation tickles the tongue with each sip. I wouldnt guess this one to be a Dubbel but I still found this incredibly enjoyable.

12 oz bottle
This was picked up on a run to Kentucky since the price was right ($1.50).  I may have to pick up some more before supplies dry out - this was an excellent Abbey Dubbel from someone I would not have expected it from.  Granted, most Bells releases are solid so maybe I should not have been so suprised.
Aroma / Appearance - The tropical nose released roasted malts, peaches, hazel, cocoa and berries to my eager nose.  The body giving off these wonderful scents was a deep brown with a sandy head.
Flavor / Palate - A creamy thick mouthfeel coated the insides of my mouth.  The first hit was pure coffee but it soon faded to cream, smoke, chocolate truffles and raisins.  In some ways it felt more like an imperial stout than an abbey dubbel.  The aftertaste was very smoky with a trace of peanut butter and cherry liquer.  Despite being extremely dense it was also easy to drink.  While still a sipping beer, this is one that you do not need to spend an hour on unless you want to enjoy the complexity.
Dark mahogany pour with a frothy tan head.  Smells of smoky malt and sweet dark fruit.  Sweet dark fruits up front with a lingering roasty malt  finish.  Medium palate with little carbonation.

Bottle (courtesy of Tpaglia): Poured a pitch-black color ale with a small brown foamy head with minimum retention and lacing. Aroma of light sweet malt and candi sugar. Taste of sweet malt and candi sugar with no spices or yeast characteristics being noticeable. Body is about average with no alcohol being discernable. I though that this beer was generally lacking in character and not that close to the style and definitely sub par from this usually great brewery.

I guessed wrong when I poured this one, as it looked like a stout or a porter. Deep brown almost black body with a thin tan head and just about no lacing.  Dark chocolatey malts with hints of licorace, and molasses along with some dates and raisins.  The flavor was quite good with dark breads chocolate, dried figs and rasisns coming through.  A clean finish as well.  Very solid beer.

Bells challenges convention yet again!  Pours a nearly black dark brown and thick.  Its like a belgian/porter hybrid.  Not quite as fruity as I would like, but a pretty well crafted beer, whatever the hell it is.

12 ounce bottle.  Pours opaque black with a fudgy dense brown head.  Aroma is pretty phenolic.  Sort of rummy.  Dark fruits, but all are muddled.  Raisin and cherry and a good bit of bitterness are in the flavor.  Kind of a wierd tongue scrubbing palate.  Ill pass on a second.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2007 Smell good, quite tatsy it is.

Alas, alas, it lacks the fizz.

Dark and enticing.

Very inviting.

Delivers a nice buzz.

Drink too much, your brain will be fuzz.

Would recommend to a friend,

Might even buy it again!

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2007 Bottled at Oliver Twist, Stockholm.  Black, small pale brown head. Aroma of lingonberries and roasty malt. Rather sweet, tar and asphalt are evident. Underneath lies some tropical fruits and a solid core of malt. The mouthfeel is clean and it finishes with medium bitterness. Atypical flavours for basically anything - I like it!

Bottled. Dark brown pour, with a foamy, medium-brown head. Nose is malt, yeast, alcohol, cocoa. Flavor is raisiny, malty, smoky, with a hint of chocolate. Finish is nicely hoppy with a hint of alcohol. Quite good, but then isnt everything from Bells top notch?

Pour is opaque dark dark dark brown with a small tight bubbled dense tan head...smell is strongly of cocoa and yeast...smell is far from anything normally Beligian....smells like an awesome porter...taste is rich and roasty with some earth fruits and dirty flavors...I dont get much anything Dubbel or Belgian from this...it is definately tasty though....nice chewy roasty mouthfeel....tastes slick...

Dark pour with a tan head and lacing.  Aroma of hops n the pour.  I swear the aftertaste is one of apples!  The hop flavor doesnt come through as strong as the aroma, nice bitterness and coffee undertones with some fruit flavors.  I really enjoyed this and the higher alcohol content is not really noticable.  Another definite plus for Bells!

2006 bottle consumed on 11/22/06Medium-beige head is rather well-aerated/fluffy, only about one-finger in height and recedes to cover fairly quickly.  Retention is moderate, not as great as is usual from Bells.  Still, sediment I present on the bottom, and the beer is a dark maroon-purple-mahogany, with crimson and beige hues as well.  Pleny of carbonation in the liquid.  Light lacing left on the glass.Dry roast and peppery phenols dot the nose as first with a definite helping of bananas overtop mushy walnut/almond flavored brown bread.  The roast helps enliven or harden, I should say, the otherwise sluggish maltiness, while little hops are present, as it should be.  Reminds me of the wheat series, particularly wheat 8.  Nothing over-the-top in any category, and some definite berry skins, clove, banana and light raisins as expected from a dubbel.  Warming brings with it a light touch of fusels, but I see this in almost every dubbel Ive ever had.  Not incredibly aromatic, with the phenolic dryness and husky roast/toasted malt giving a slight blandness and quick finish.Chewy prunes and lighter plum notes open up the flavor as sharp, but light acids dig in to the back of the palate.  A rather oily texture, with somewhat prickly carbonation does not seem to help form any softness.  And softness would seem much needed.  I get a bit of pale malt sweetness, but its quickly dissolved by a harder roastiness and strong clove-pepper phenolic dryness.  Light bananas and some fusels sit awkwardly on the finish, with a bit of piquant raisins (which unfortunately throw more astringency/oiliness out).  All in all, it seems to have the right flavors for a dubbel, but everything seems rather unrefined and disjointed.  Not too impressed with the texture/carbonation either.  Thats usually a bright spot with Bells beer.  Maybe another month or two will help even things out.  Will revisit.

Not even close to an abbey dubbel.  Almost pitch black, oily deep brown colored body with a dark brown head.  Bourbon and smoky charred plums, soy sauce, dates and nuts in the nose.  A large dose of motor oil and burnt malts galore.  A bit pale and bland, not Belgian like, just a bit empty on the tongue, a bit brash and simple.  Resembles a robust or smoked porter.  Smells almost like nothing, very faint... like you mixed a million different colors only to create a perfectly bland shade of white.
Pours black with a thin brown head. Malt and candy nose. The taste is a blend of roasted flavors, a mild chocolate, sugar.

12-oz bottle from moejuck.  Pours very near opaque with a tall fizzy and foamy brown head, mostly diminishing with spare lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (toasted meal, bread, nutty), light hops (flowers), average yeast (dough) with notes of dark fruit, chocolate and caramel.  Average duration, moderate sweetness, light acidity and bitterness; creamy chocolate malt and caramel flavor.  Full bodied, lively carbonation, creamy texture and a smooth finish.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2011 Another entry from Bell.  Ive seen this in the beer store many times but it took a tap to make me try it.  On tap at the Bocktown Bar in the Robinson Township shopping complex.  Interesting label of a man being belittled and put into the dog house by a woman who is apparently his wife. Veary pleasing aroma - almost like good sugary candy of some sort.  Pours very dark, possibley black in my glass.  Nice darkish head. Very burnt roasty initial flavor like it was filtered in a barrel that was charred inside. Almost like lye soap and dont ask how I know what that taste like.  Too much astringent bitternessfor my poor taste buds.  Long lingering bitterness is too much for my liking.

text: UPDATED: SEP 15, 2007 very dark. but with color. awesome head. smells of wood, some ash. really woody taste. smoky too. jeez.  very slightly thin. some dark fruit emerges as it warms, deep in the profile. balanced though.  rerate: draft at maduro, madison. dark prunes. horrible fish smell. shitty malt balls. tobacco flavor. eat a dick.

12oz bottle-pours a thick creamy brown head and black color.  Aroma is dark malt.  Taste is dark malt-dark chocolate/licorice, dark fruit, smoky, secondary hops, yeast.  Could be a strong, sweet porter.  OK carbonation.  Occasional.

Its a very dark beer, even holding it up to light, I saw no hint of color.  Very small, quickly fading head.  The initial aroma is off sugar, with a chocolate/coffee bitterness lurking behind it.  It has a mild sweet flavor, but not cloying.  Not a bad beer overall, but not one Im going to run after again soon (especially at the cost: $15/6 pack 12 oz.).

Bottle from trade with OhioDad. Thanks Scott. Pour is dark brown with small off white head and a nice lacing.  nose is sweet belgian sugary malt and yeast. Taste is surprisingly smokey, with dark fruit notes and a bit of alcohol and yeast flavors. An interesting mix of flavor that leaves the palate wondering what is this? An abbey dubbel? not sure about that. Decent, but not my favorite from Bells.

Surprised to see this is supposed to be a dubbel.  Coffee cappucino aroma with light sugar.  mahogany, with short tan head.  fuel flavor gummy fruit, molasses and raisinets, almost belgian.  modest palate.  Not really sure what they were going for with this one.  Didnt make much of an impression.
(sample from irishboy)dark brown  body.i got tobaco,smoke,belgian yeast,and wheat out of the aroma and flavor.i cant say im impressed.

Bottle from ogglethorpe; Nose of sweet vanilla candy, caramel, and dark fruit; black with a medium glass-lacing tan head; flavor of light coffee, chocolate, dark fruits, and some hops in the medium body, the hops lasting into the finish.

Black with a thin, creamy head. Fruity malt and some candied sugar in the nose. Flavor is sweet, dark fruit with sugary, chocolately, lightly roasted goodness. Pleasant on the palate: substantial and smooth. Very enjoyable.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2010 Pours black, with a deep tan head.  Aroma is of dark fruits, molasses, citrus, and brown sugar.  Mouth is medium thickness with some carbonation.  Flavor has frutis, brown sugar, yeast, malts, and spices.  It looks more intimidating than it is.  Its easy to drink, and tasty.  A good brew.

Suprisingly black pour with a quickly diinishing cream head. Aroma is kina fruity, almost belgianish.  I had only head the name and I thought this was going to be a hop bomb.  Guess I was wrong. Flavor is a complex mix of chocolate, fruit, yeast and some alcohol. Not sure what is so abusive about this beer, its very easy to drink.

Vapory in aroma with brown sugar and chocolate. Fruity hops with a note of citrus. Belgian yeast and a wee bit of grapefruit. Dark black oily body, impossible to see through. Has a thin medium tan wispy head. Medium heavy watery body, a bit oily but not predominant. Medium carbonation with a bit of alcohol warming. Starts with heavy malt flavors. Brown sugar and chocolate but also some raw grains. Bitterness is dry with some coffee tang and burnt nuts. Theres an odd combination of a dry stout and dubbel going on. Estery notes with good yeastiness. Fruity hops to finish. Dry chocolate nutty after.
Had this on draft at the Herot.Hit you up front with a cross between a hoppy porter and a stout but is considered an American Dubbel. Surprising smooth and very drinkable..

12oz bottle, courtesy of Ty5592.  Thanks, Ty!  Pours a dark-dark brown with a medium tan head; decent lacing and retention at the edges.  Yeasty, maple sugar aroma.  Medium mouthfeel: plenty of yeast, brown sugar, dried fruit and spice; basic malty, abbey-dubbel profile; seems to lack a bit of complexity.  Finish shows cloves and pepper, very malty.

Bottle from The_Man.  Ultra-brown to black in color, nice light brown head which fades moderately and leaves decent lacing.  Aroma is malty with raisins and plums coming to mind.  Medium to full bodied, softer carbonation.  Malty flavors seem to dominate taste, fig, plum and raisin.  Decent hop bitterness to balance at the finish.  Decently done.

Smokey malty nose goes with this deep, brown pour.  No lasting head to speak of.  More malt than most dubbels Ive had.  Makes it pretty interesting.  Spice and smoke go with the substantial body well.   Finish is sweet and slightly alcoholic.  Nice.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2008 What a confusing beer.  Im not sure what style this is, but I am fairly confident it is not a dubbel.  Pours almost black with a garnet hue when held to the light and a head that is rich dark orange / brown.  This looks strikingly like many of their stouts.  The aroma has heavily roasted malt, some Belgium earthiness, candi sugar, hints of dark fruits and some cocoa.  Most of the flavors listed are fairly hidden behind the thick malt.  Body is slightly heavier than medium and fairly smooth with light semi-sharp carbonation.  Flavors start with lots of the roasted malt and traces of the Belgium earthiness.  It is quite dry.  There are some lightly detectable dark fruits.  The finish of the beer has more of a roasted taste that is close to tasting charred.  Further down it starts getting chalking and starts tasting like a cross between a porter and a stout than it does anything Belgium.  The body starts to lose some of its sturdiness as well.  This was a nice to try and experience, but I wouldnt want much.  It started off good and seemed to drop in enjoyment for me the whole way down. (8/3/7/3/14 - 3.5)   Rerate notes:  I guess I’m ’getting’ this more in 2008.  Aroma this year has no candi sugar notes, slight coffee and over the top roast.  Most of the notes previously are still accurate, but I feel the numbers need to be bumped up for the enjoyability and overall uniqueness.  Why this is still listed a a dubbel is baffling.  Not sure exactly what it is, but dubbel is nowhere near the top of the list.

#971, On tap at Buffalo Wild Wings in Indianapolis IN. Brownish with a medium sized brown head. Nose is very hoppy and crisp. The taste is much more malty and creamy than hoppy but interesting to say the least.

Had at 3 sons tasting.  Poured a very dark brown color with slight amount of bubbly activity on top.  Aroma is strong caramel malt characteristics and spices...kinda raisiny.  Flavor is off...Im not sure how Id put it, but it definitely didnt taste how I thought it would as an "abbey double."  Very sweet and carmely, earthy, and piney.  Overall, not a fan.

My first drain pour from Bells.  The aroma only hints at the quite horrible malt flavor and yeast artifacts, both of which really accumulate upon further drinking.  This shares malt character with Java Stout, which fortunately uses a better yeast.
Spicy and roasty.  Very smooth with hints of coffee, fruiuts, and smokiness.  Aftertast is bittersweet.  This is kind of like a stout, but more complex....

12 oz bottle - thanks to NolanKowal for this one!  This one sits in the glass thick, black and opaque with a creamy tan head.   Interesting smokey and roasty aromas, coffee and herbs, licorice, clove and salty figs.  Again I detect a smokey, roastiness in the flavor, molasses, very herby, prune juicce, soy, seaweed and funky yeasts - but not in a bad way.  Full body, creamy and smooth.  Very unique and tasty brew.
bottle.  Pours dark with carmel head.  wheat and yeast.  dark fruit and aprocot.
Poured a dark dark brown with almost not head.  Aroma was of dark fruits and spices, little sweet.  Flavor was much the same with a nice smokey roasted maltyness to it as well.

Jeez, this stuff is a black hole! dark and stormy! Smells like booze to me, but the taste is slighly sweet I thought. I dont think i have ever had this style before, but since it was made by Bells i figure it would be good, and it was farily par! I liked the devil on the bottle too!

Bottle. Courtesy of Alan at Coastal Wine. Pours near black. Sturdy tan froth on the surface. Nose is almost smoky in spots. Roasted malts, dark fruits and a hint of sweetened barbecue pork (burnt and caramelized molasses based sauce). Like others, I didnt think dubbel and rather thought Imperial Stout or Porter. Taste is malty and rich with dark fruits and light smokiness. Some light spice and an odd flavor I cant place my finger on. Body is medium and creamy. Dense and above average carbonation. Finishes much like it began - more roasted malts, dark fruits and some smoky notes. Not bad but not really to style.

Thanks to shigadeyo giving me this in a trade. Pours almost black with faint head. I thought I was pouring an IMPY stout. Flavor is malts with some mild spice and a touch of smoke. Tastes more like a stout than an Dubbel. It is pretty good.

Shared with Naven while watching the Broncos get smoked like a Virginia ham.  A nice Belgian dubbel here.  Nothing amazing, but at the same time, its perfect to style without having to get creative on the ingredients.  If you like a solid dubbel, youll like this.  I certainly did.

12 oz bottle acquired via trades with Northerntimber and Jimbowood.   First thing I noticed was how great this looked and smelled.  The flavors are bold and relentless.  Lots of belgian yeast, malt and raisin.  Some spices in the finish.  Pretty good.

This looks more like a porter or stout than an abbey dubbel, and, while the flavor profile doesnt match the great Belgian Dubbels, this is a very enjoyable beer nonetheless. Flavor begins deep and malty, some chocolate, moves on to dark raisiny fruit flavors, then spices and hops, and finishes with a slight taste of yeast and some roatiness. Different and good.

Thanks santa. Pours out a dark brown color with a thin white lacing head. Aroma is of fruit and slight yeast. Taste is mostly of chocolate, dark fruit and slight spice. Slight roasty flavor lingering on the finish
UPDATED: OCT 13, 2007 Good looking dark dark brown, very small light brown head.  Faint aroma. Flavor is nice and not overwhelming. Tons of fruit and malts.

Simple and great for whatever it is. Black with almost no head. Dark chocolate malt, heavy carbonation, refreshingly hits the spot. Cross style, not great for a Belgian as light on the yeast. Malty but not on sweet side.Tad roast, licorice .

12 oz bottle thanks to NEB.  Pours a thick and dark charcoal black color with a tanned head with excellent retention.  The aroma brings out a smokey roastiness with a baked ham, and almost a little bit of nuttiness.  The flavor begins and stays incredibly dark malt moving into that very smoked hammy flavor.  Bits of yeast, raisins, and light spice infiltrate the body, while it lands into a very Earthy liquorice root flavor.  The finish goes back to the smokey ham for me.  Definitely lingers.  Mediumed bodied and ends fairly light.  Not much carbonation.  Definitely NOT an Abbey Dubbel - this is a Rauchbier for sure.  While good, its a bit too hammy for me.

Foggy brown color with no head present.  Aroma is caramel, dried fruit, light bit of roastiness also.  Taste has an interesting light up front hop presence, along with light cocoa, yeast contributes a good amount of taste to it also.

12oz. bottle.  Murky dark brown with a thin film of light brown head.  Spicey and candied fruit ester aroma, some doughy malt as well.  Alefruit and caramel up front, raisinbread malt character manifests with bubblegum and clove.  Spicy, estery flavors persist in the finish with a lasting sweetness.  Mouthfeel is a heavy medium, somewhat sticky.

Black as hell, with a lot of sludge at the end (about as close to Westmalle dubbel as to Imperial Stout...); small darker tan head. Resiny hops, quite a lot of liquorice, algae or other seaweed, with definitely iodium. Liquorice,  drop , but this time its the  zoute drop variety, the salted version that is so popular in Holland. This beer is truly salty, and retronasal it becomes as a gingerbread cake with sushi-seaweed. Bit of soy sauce included, and there are tuns of masked sugars. Quite well-bodied, thick-oily and slick. Very surprising beer. Its not a real porter, nor a real stout, or an old ale. But whatever comes closest, it wont be Westmalle dubbel, for heavens sake.  Thanks, David and Liza!

12 oz. Goblet at the Eccentric. Rating #999! Ah, my last taste of mortality before I ascend to Beer Godhood! Damn, this one is black! More like an impy porter, mocking me with its tan head. Yet it has just a mild dubbel smell with no alcohol trace, just a fresh bit of yeast. I taste dark malts, with no roasties or tannins. Way off style, but Im handing it a high mark there, anyway, casue it just looks to clever. I catch a tounch of unmodified wheat, then here comes that more faimilar Belgian taste. A big, surprisingly complex beer with an impressive finish. They were all out of bottles at Bells store, I could only get this on tap before it disappeared.

07.12.06  12oz bottle batch 7673, thanks be to OhioDad.  This is a lovely beer.  Dark, lush, and nearly opaque prune-juice brown with medium sized beige head of tight foam.  Aroma is less yeasty than expected, and more, maybe, like a porter, but a Belgian one, from Michigan, with nice bananas foster notes and burnt marshmallow.  Um, it smells nice, but not typically dubbel-like.  Esters emerge with temp and so do the yumy dark fruits, raisin, prune, bandaid, bubblegum.  Creamy and full bodied, maybe more than expected and maybe too full, but its nice nonetheless and lastingly coating.  Its the kind of beer that causes me to make up adverbs like lastingly.  Roasty and some lightly bitter chocolate flavors wround it out with a mellow but dry bitterness to foil the potential overly sweet finish.  Its good, not great.

Bottled at Oliver Twist, Stockholm. pours out in a hazy dark brown colour with a small tan head. Yeasty and powdery aroma of cocoapowder, almond and old leather. Sweet and ueasty flavour of melted chocolate and almonds. Finishes quite sweet of syrup and dusty yeasts. Interesting take on the style but its a bit too sweet but still drinkable.
Pours dark brown with thin head.  Some sweet malt in aroma.  Yeasty and dry.  Raisin, nuts in flavor as well.  Light and slightly bitter.

Solid brown body, opaque, thin, but lasting layer of cocoa-tan foam above. Solid look for a dubbel. 

Nose is all cocoa powder, with suggestions of maple, nuts, & other sweet, dark and tasty things.

Taste is more of the same, with an appreciated heft to the feel. Comes on and grows spicy on the tongue, coats the palate with a slick, chocolately, syrupy sweetness. Cloys a tad, but still delights.
Thins out a touch and dries nicely in the finish.

From a 12oz Bottle, Batch 7673.  To start off with, I love the label.  Pours a dark black color with a medium layer of toasted marshmellow head.  Very dark, with only a subtle tannic acid hue to keep this from being completely opaque.  A light yeasty character wafts from the glass, bringing some doughy gingerbread cookies and bubblegummy pheonlic characters as well - smooth and not spicy.  Smells like the Chimay strain to me.  A nice round of caramels and chocolate nougat blends with a hint of lightly roasted coffee, creating a fantastic malty base.  Medium bodied, silky mouthfeel.  Rich, dark malty body that brings out flavors of pumpernickel bread, unsweetened belgian cocoa, a hint of tobacco, and a smidgen of molasses.  A mellowed, yet distinctly belgian yeasty character smooths out the finish, eliminating the possibility of any dry malty edges and ending without spice in a velvety final smack.  A hint of pruney residue is left on the tongue.  Only Bells could make a dubbel taste like this.  Thanks, Tom!

From bottle. Batch 7673. Poured dark, which was unexpected.  Nice bubbly like brown head.  Aroma of barley, malt, spice, cardamon, maple, and sugar.  Flavor sugary at the start, roasty, chocolately.  Hints of barley, nice malt backbone.  Fruity (raisens and figs), and a nutmeg tingle on the tongue.  Medium bodied. Carbonation was solid, as it tingled my tongue every so often.  Easy to drink.  Nice alcohol warming, perfect for a chilly night.  Another beer from Bells that doesnt disappoint!
Nice Deep brown pour, thin light brown head.  Aroma is pleasent hop and roasty malt mixture.  Sweet nose, quickly disapating roasty malt finish.  Pretty darn good.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2009 Batch 7620, er so, almost 2 years on it.  Bottle.   Pours a cloudy dark brown with a tan head that dissipates fairly quickly.   Aroma of chocolate, malt, yeast.    Taste is doughy, malty, chocolate, dreid fruit.   Body is medium+, sorta creamy.   Seems to like somewhere between a porter and abbey dubbel.   I find this different in a good way.   Better with some age.

12 oz bottle courtesy of Craig.  Pours a dark brown color with a medium tan head.  Aroma of mocha and banana with hints of dates.  Flavor is slightly spicy with nutmeg and banana overtones as well as hints of malt and chocolate.  Pretty good.

Dubbels tend to taste the same to me, but this is a great exception. Subtle flavor that leans toward the malt but with just the right amount of hops, Im picking up some light hints of mocha, grass, dates, and maybe its just me but a little bit of greasy bacon as well. Great dubbel from a great brewery.
slight malty flavor, and a little on the thick side. Some tastes of berries in there as well, a nice beer for cold weather

12 oz bottle.  Pours a walnut color with black charcoal black leanings.  No head.  Oily looking.  The aroma is malt, ash, toasted notes with hints of dates.  Flavor is very enjoyable and I thought this would go well with a chocolate dessert.  Complex grain flavors with hints of sweetness (very subdued and pleasant), charcoal toastedness and hints of dark fruit.  Very nice and perfect for a cold day.  Medium body with a light creaminess.
Draft. Dark brown with big tan head. Aroma of bananas and spicy. Smooth mouthful with dry aftertaste.
Pours a dark brown with off white head.  Roasted malt aroma.  Roasty malt taste that has a smoky finish.  Good beer.

12 oz bottle.  Dark chocolate brown kicks up a mocha head that leaves a ring.  Yeasty raisins and spice.  Fruitcake and plums.  Weird taste.  Chocolate prunes leads to scotch and juniper.  Dry Belgian funk lingers on the palate. Medium carb, smooth body.  A dubbel-tripel hybrid?
Pours the color of cola, with very thin white head.  Fruity aroma, perhaps molasses or plum.  Very complex, full beer.  Unusual finish that I cannot put my finger on.  Very unusual, but enjoyable.

On tap @ the Brew Kettle 11/28-12/02 so far:  Dark brown beer/ w/ purplish highlights and a lasting light tan head.  Aroma is initially toasty malt and clovey/peppery yeast, but the yeast is a minor roll.  Some bready malts;  the hint of plum fruitiness is a bit disappointing as I was expecting more, however the overall character of the aroma is quite pleasant.  Breay and toasty malt flavor in the well balanced beer, drier finish, with some dark fruity flavors (plums, hint of raisins) but they are really light!  Well balanced overall, and it takes a little bit for the dry finish to grow on you, but its nice.  Medium carbonation, Id prefer it to be higher for an abbey dubbel, medium full mouthfeel, and well hidden alcohol contribute to a smooth, velvety mouthfeel.  Very drinkable given the ABV which I guess is what matters most!  Not a great abbey dubbel, but a pretty good beer!
Bottle. Pours tar with thin tan head. Aroma is molasses, licorice, pine, malt. Flavor is coffee, molasses, pine, malt, chocolate, caramel, bitter.

Very dark black/brown beer with a light brown head.  The aroma is roasty and toasty with hints of light smoke.  Yeast shows soft banana and clovey spiciness behind intensely roasty maltiness.  Earthy malts, heavy roast showing slightly salty soy and licorice character.  Sweet smokiness with a long intense roasty finish.  Tastes like a Bells stout fermented with a Belgian yeast.

Draft from DRE.  Pretty black pour, with a nice half-finger tan brown head.  Aroma of roasty malt, banana, spice, funky peaty earthy malt, cacao, some brown sugar.  Smells a bit like Avery 13 and Stone 666.  The flavor is roasty malty, with a smooth palate, nice complexity, and taste notes of rauchy peaty malt, some banana, figgy fruit, and candi sugar.

Dark brown, almost black.  Tan/brown foam.  Aroma is sugary, maybe an odor of vanilla extract.  Not bad.  Taste is a bit strange for a dubbel - a bit smokey perhaps.  Not bad, just not what I expected.  More of a porter than an abbey dubbel.

Appears a toasted, dark brown with russett highlights when held to the light. A small, tan head quickly fizzles out into a collar. Small amounts of spotty lace slide back into the brew.
Smell is of cocoa beans, brown sugar, toasted malt, oven roasted oatmeal, and Bells signature funkadelic house yeast found in nearly all their brews that reminds me of stale bread.
Taste is of cocoa, caramel, brown sugar, toasted bread, figs, and cola.
Mouthfeel is sweet, sugary, fizzy up front, all in a yeasty, medium bodied brew. Cocoa powder and sugar tickles the tongue during the finish with a mild warmness.

Pretty good stuff from Bells. The ancillary qualities of this beer are a bit better than the core qualities, but overall its not bad. A fruity aroma with plums and raisins being the most pronounced. The mouthfeel was excellent with a nice creaminess that I found quite enjoyable. The flavors were dark fruits, a bit spicy with quite a bit of candi sugar character. Overall, not bad although I thought it was more akin to an Old Ale than a Abbey Dubbel.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2008 12 oz bottle pours a dark black with a tan head.  The nose is very belgian yeasty candie sugar sweet some spices pretty decent but the flavor is just weird to me for the style.  Although I like the body on this the flavor seems so out of style.  Its almost like a sweet stout with belgian yeast, chocolate, sweet carmel, molasses, bitter sweet nutty finish.  If I dont know what style its supposed to be goin for, I really cant get into it.   rated blind from "Better Know a Style: Abbey Dubbel" tasting.  Pours brown black with a beige head.  Alcohol, phenols, roasty, chocolate nose.  Flavors of chocolate stout like.  Roasted, milk chocolate city, creamy, spicy, and lightly bitter.  Really drying in the finish. 7/3/7/3/14 = 3.4

Bottle.  Minimal head.  I can tell this is not your average abbey dubbel.  Smokey aroma, chocolate, sweet molasses, raisin, and some belgian yeast.  Slightly bitter finish.  Very dark brown body.  Very interesting and different.  Unlike any other abbey dubbel Ive had.  I would almost characterize this as a blended smoked porter and dubbel combination.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown color with a medium off white head. Aroma of yeast, molassess, nuts and caramel. Taste similiar to a nut brown ale. The flavors of fermented fruit, roasted malt and chocolate are very well balanced. This is a nice complex brew from Bells.

On tap at the Drafting Room in Springhouse.  Pours a dark brown almost black with some ruby when held to the light. Creamy dark tan sustaining and lacing head.  Aroma of toasty malts, dark fruits, Belgian yeast and spices, along wiht some roasted malts and chocolate.  Flavor was also toasty, dark fruits, candi sugar, Belgian yeast fruitiness and chocolate.
UPDATED: NOV 1, 2010 So basically it tastes like they brewed a stout and fermented it with a Belgian yeast.  How could that suck?

An excellent looking brew from one of the best.  Poured a greasy black with a brown head that stuck to ringing itself around the edge.  No lacing.  Aroma was of sweet dark maltiness.  First impression was the nice bite that came off the tongue.  A nice balance of hops and coffee.  Its been awhile since Ive had an Abbey Dubbel, and this beer makes me want to seek out more.

Is this beer or is it carbonated coffee? This beer does not pour..it eases. Im not very familiar with this style but soon will be. If this beer had a subtitle it would be "Dark n Delicious". Looks more black than brown with a good amount of carbonation to give it a bite. Coffee, coffee, coffee...indulge in the dark!
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: a very tastey dubbel, though i think it bordered on a dunkel or something wheatier.  Aromas and flavors of roasted malt, chocolate, figs, apricots, and a slight hint of grapes and smoke.  tastey.

I just got this today as part of my Secret Santa and couldnt wait to try something!  I had no idea what this was until I read about it on the site.  I agree that this is an unusual dubbel and wouldve thought stout if it werent for the huge candied sugar taste.  Nice deep black color.  Sharp hop and fusel aroma with hints of caramel.  Whoa, too much alcohol present which then gives way to an overly aggressive hop presence.  Bizarre that I taste so much fusel oils considering this isnt what I would consider a "Big Beer".  Later, raisens, figs and dark candi sugar make their presence known.  Decent mouthfeel, but my palate was disappointed by the lack of complexity which I so love in this style.  I enjoy the fact that they obviously experemented away from a traditional dubbel and give them points for that.  However, Id advise against drinking this young.  Perhaps a good year on this will tone down the fusel oils and aggressive hop profile.  Overall, tasty and very interesting, but I think it needs time to age the immediate flaws which are present.

Probably the best name for a beer, i was excited to try a bells.  The last i had was the imperial stout, so my expectations were high. dark drown pour with very thin coffee head.  sweet and earthy aromas.  i couldnt quite place the taste, so this is what i came up with: licorice, chocolate, figs, apricot, dark berries, but mostly smoky apricots.

A Dubbel? Really? If I didnt know I would have called it a porter or stout or something like that. Dark brown, verging on black. Thick brown head that quickly dissipates. Woodsy, smokey smells, mixed with some coffee, too. Rich palate. Flavors of coffee and molasses, maybe some cocoa, too. Very tasty stuff. Thanks, Secret Santa!
Pours murky dark brown with a thin light brown head. Mild aroma of brown sugar, bitter toffee, cloves and cookie dough. Mouthfeel is medium to heavy bodied with smooth carbonation.

If this didnt pour completely black, then its the darkest brown Ive ever seen.  Thin tan head.  The aroma is pretty killer.  Chocolate, yeasty and a little fruity with perhaps a pinch of smoke.  The taste is hard to nail down... definitely a sweeter malt base, but more bitter hops than I would expect from a Dubbel.  Very faint fruit.  Doughy?  Good, but the aroma was better than the taste, sadly enough.
Dark, deep brown with moderate coffee-colored head, sweet smoky aroma, tastes like dried fruit and sweet malt with smoky finish.

Bottle thanks to RagallachMC. Pours almost black with a big head, although the head doesnt last as long as youd think. It leaves some lacing behind. Aroma is Belgian clove type yeast, and sweet fruit malts. Taste is smoky and caramel malt sweet.  An oh, so interesting brew from Bells.

From bottle courtesy of Wheninhell, thanks Andy!  Dark, thick pour with foamy coffee head.  Nose is burnt sugar, hints of smoke that increases as it warms.  Flavor is burnt toffee, bitter finish and some spruce.  Nice creamy palate.  Dubbel?

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2006 Bottle.  Im watching this thick, viscous dark brown liquid pouring into my glass when a pretty good smokey blast hit my nostrils.  Then a peat scent and then as I draw closer I find a thick porter like mixture of dark chocolate/coffee and peat.  I really wasnt expecting this.  The smoke is all but gone for now.  A dense, but thin head laces a bit as it dies down.  Ahh... the first sip.  The smoke is back, and then the peat and a bit of that alcohol burn as it goes down.  Maybe a touch of dark fruit in the background here.  Very smooth in spite of the smoke/peat/alcohol content/etc.  This is absolutely a fabulous mix of flavors that I would have guessed for a Dubbel.  Bravo!
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Pours quite dark and very thick with a big head and lots of lacing. Rich malty toffee aroma. Flavor is strong maltieness with chocolate and toffee and some wintery spices.  Finishes moderatly bitter with an odd thick creamieness.

An almost black pour with very little tan head. An aroma of chocolate, raisins, and alcohol. A flavor that says alcohol first followed by a light choco then a rasininess. A bit of bitterness at the finish. The palate is full but it comes down to a bit of graininess that is not bad but is different. A good beer thanks Ty5592.

Well, the honeymoon is over...A Bells product that I dont like.  Appearance is black with a frothy brown head.  Smells of yeast, licorice and corriander.  Palate is medium and oily.  Strong anise taste and that corriander comes through as well.  Very strong aftertaste.  A mixed up mess in my humble opinion.

12 oz bottle: Pours an opaque black with a large sized tan head.  The aroma was of cloves, plums, a bit of chocolate and a definite alcohol presence.  A fruity raisin and plum mixture nicely spiced with a woodsy note.  There is a definite chocolate taste and some roasted malts.  Palate is medium bodied, somewhat sticky, and lightly soft.  Overall, I thought this beer was a departure from what Bells usually brews and is a welcomed change in my opinion

Whats in a name?  Would a stout my anyother name taste as good?  Ok wheres the hops then?  This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a large sized head of foamy finely sized brown colored bubbles that were long lasting and left behind a no visible carbonation black colored body. The mild dark malt aroma contained mild chocolate and dark malt notes. The mouth feel was thick semi-flat and smooth. The flavor contained notes of dark malt mild licorice and brown malt. A decent one but not one that I would consider buying again.

Thick and dark, almost stout like in the slowly developing thick brown head.  The aroma is not stout like, combining malt and sour yeast.  Thick and heavy, with a flat, almost metallic flavor.  A short dry finish.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: Thick pour, dark brown color.  Smell of honey, coffee, chocolate, male, cherries and alcohol.  Smells almost like robitusium cough syrup.  Taste of malt, coffee, honey, chocolate, hops, rye, alcohol, fruit, and a very dry bitterness at the end .Very different beer here but I like it.

Brown body with medium sized, tan head. The aroma is figs, raisins, brown sugar and cloves. The flavor is molases, prunes, roast, cocoa, spice and a touch of alcohol. Medium body, fairly dry, smooth texture and a warm finish.

Very nice color, it looked more like a stout. As it warms up I tasted a lot of cinnamon which made this taste spicy.  As for lacingnone.  It is worth trying but not I would not spend a lot of money trying to get your hands on this one.

On tap. Poured a dark, dark brown color with a small sized off white head. Aromas of dark fruits, chocolate and some roast. Tastes of stronger dark fruits (plums and raisins), cocoa, and roast. Medium sweet with light alcohol in the finish. Light lacing left on the glass.

12oz - batch 7673 - Very roasty dark malt aroma with some coffee, chocolate and a touch of hops.  Pours cola colored with a small lasting brown head and great lacing.  Flavor matches with an alcohol bite I didnt expect for 7.7%.  Palate is sticky and chalky.  More of a porter IMO.  Still pretty tasty.
Bottle courtesy of hippie4beer  Dark pour.  Much darker than I expected.  Tons of chocolate, coffee, and licorish.  Doesnt fit well into the style.  Not what I was expecting.

An Abbey Dubbel??? Reminds me more of a stout IMO. Medium sized tan head that mostly diminished, poor lacing, opaque, minimal carbonation, and a dark brown hue. Malty, roasty, smokey, chocolate, and coffee notes for the aroma and ditto for the flavor. Fairly smooth mouthfeel, but somewhat dry. Medium body.  The appearance reminded me of a stout.  Lost some points due to the appearance and taste. Not a brew that I would drink on a regular basis or one that Ill seek out in the future.

Bottle. The aroma is complex, malty sweet, and sharp. The beer pours black with a red hue and a small amount of tan head. It looks like a porter or even a stout. The flavor is sweet and chocolatey with a slight lemony sourness and floral accents. It is very nice for a malt-accented brew, but I need more hops. It tastes like a cross between a sweet stout and a doppelbock. I would not have identified it as an abbey dubbel if not for the ratebeer.com designation, although it does have a bit of the hard-to-describe spiciness that I have come to expect in most Belgian styles, especially in the aroma. It is smooth and medium-bodied to the palate in a nice but unremarkable way. The aftertaste has a coffee bitterness that the main taste lacks. This is clearly a well made brew. It is a bit sweet for my tastes, but not in a cloying or nauseating way. Its worth a try, but it is not an every day beer. It loses a point or two in my overall score because it is a bit of a challenge to finish. I have found that the best Belgian-type beers, no matter how high in alcohol content, are eminently drinkable.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2006 Not much head for a Dubbel although there was a nice layer of yeast on bottom of bottle.  Aroma of yeast, chocolate.  Taste of dark bread, some chocolate.  Some fruit but very slight in aroma.  Dry finish, not much sweetness.  A Bells take on the style, which is when in doubt, go stout.
Re-tried: yea this is a stout.

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2009 Batch 7673 ~ Packaged on October 11, 2006
11/18/2006:  Bells Hell Hath No Fury pours a very opaque, very dark brown color.  It pretty much looks black in the glass.  The head is large, foamy, and brown in color.  There is a scant amount of lacing.  At colder temperatures the aroma is cherry and charred wood.  I have noticed that the aroma becomes more earthy and scents of roasted fruit and some alcohol come out at warmer temperatures.  The semi-sweet flavor is a wonderful meddly of rich malt, smoke, roasted fruits, some molasses, and a weak chocolate/coffee blend.  The flavor profile is really quite deep and complex, so its difficult to explain all of the different flavors in this beer!  Some alcohol flavor is present as well, but it complements the other flavors nicely.  There is a slight dry bitterness in the long, warming finish.  Very nice!  As far as mouthfeel and palate, this beer coats the entire mouth and is medium to full bodied.  It is quite smooth and very enjoyable!  I am impressed with the depth, richness, and complexity of this beer.  Hell Hath No Fury might not be as fruity as other Dubbels, but Bells interpretation of the style is very favorable, in my opinion!  Overall, Bells Hell Hath No Fury is quite rich and complex.  At warmer temperatures the aroma is more earthy and contains roasted fruits.

Pured a hazy very dark brown with a brown head.  Aroma of very smokey raisins.  As the beer warmed coffee notes grew out as well as some phenols.  Not sure what yeast was used so I dont know if it is the yeast giving that aroma.  Some sweetness that leads to a fair amount of smoke and phenolics flavors.  I am bouncing back and forth trying to decide if it is cloves or band-aids I taste.  Maybe a combo.  The sweetness drys out at the finish.  Medium bodied.

Bottle.  Very interesting.  Apearance is thick black - a rich brew - maybe only my first or second of this type.  Woody, smoky and acidic bitter, much like a bitter coffee, bitter dark chocolate notes as well.  Stays bitter right through the finish when you are expecting just a bit of a malty balance, but never comes through.  Lively carbonation with a minimal head.  Needs further investigation.

Heavily malted and dry with an interesting array of aromas and flavors, this dubbel is an enjoyable sipping beer. Dark, muddy brown pour with short and diminishing tan head. The nose is earthy with hints of wood, smoke, chocolate and roast. Slightly sweet in taste with a slightly bitter aftertaste. Some fruitiness under the roast and burnt wood flavor. Thick body with oily mouthfeel. The alcohol comes forward in the finish.

These days I typically stray away from most Belgian styles...even more so if its an american brewer. Not to say that they dont make fine examples of the styles...Im just a bot bored with yeast, orange peel, and coriander sometimes with sweet or fruity maltiness. Although some stand out either with great balance of flavor(like Pannepot or some of the South Hampton brews) or just something different, which would be this brew here. Pours an oily dark brown with a fizzy and somewhat creamy mocha head. A good bit of yeast fills the aroma and is backed with some smoke, roasted malts, some rasin, some spice...pretty earthy. The flavor has a nice roasted malt quality...some smokiness that I think gives the usual fruity sweetness and yeast profile some breathing room to where they arent as dominate as I wouldve expected. Nice body, rich and slick with a solid amount of carbonation that doesnt go overboard and works very nicely with the roasted malt character. Tons of malt with hints of fruit ove the tounge with a almost chocolately/roasty/dry finish. A very interesting take on the style, almost like a smoked-dubbel...which would explain the fire and demon on the label.

Dubbels always catch me off guard, pouring way darker than I expected - this one is deep brown nearing black with a fantastic mocha colored head.  The yeast dominates the nose, wet earth, supported by caramel malt sweetness.  Softly carbed.  Lots of dark chocolate, burnt caramel, vanilla tanins and plum in the body.  Overall, this is pretty heavy on the tongue for a dubbel IMO, but damn drinkable none-the-less.

12 oz bottle. Black with a tan head. Sweet, plum/prune nose, fruity, brown sugar. Sweet dark fruit flavor, prune, raisin, currant, brown sugar and spice notes. Yeasty finish, light toasty malt. Very good!

Pours black with a nice sized tan head. Aroma reminded me of beef jerky at first, rather weird and unappealing. There is a smokey malt, dark chocolate aroma that eventually comes out the longer it sits. Some bitterness at the finish. Disappointing.

11/15/06: Bottle.  Black as hell body with a devilishly beautiful, caramel-tan head.  Head is ample and quickly fades to a thin ring of carbonation.  Some lace.  Nose of toasted/burnt malt and caramel.  Flavor is smoky, bitter and somewhat burnt.  Tones of burnt fruit (plum) and black coffee are also noticed.  Finish is bitter.
Great dark brown with small head.  Dark fruit such as plum sweet with a decent alchol kick. Creamy with just a hint of coffee  Another solid Bells brew.

Im with everyone else on this one.
